CROSS REFERENCES
Sewerage rates - see Ohio R.C. 729.49 et seq.
Management and control of sewerage system - see Ohio R.C. 729.50
Sewerage system connection fees - see S.U. & P.S.
925.04
 
929.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the terms “sanitary sewage”, “acceptable
industrial wastes” and “nonacceptable industrial wastes” shall be defined as
follows:
   (a)   “Sanitary sewage” means the waste from water closets, urinals,
lavatories, sinks, bath tubs, showers, household laundries, cellar floor
drains, bars, soda foundations, cuspidors, refrigerator drips, drinking
fountains and any other water- borne waste not constituting an industrial
waste.
   (b)   “Acceptable industrial wastes” means liquid organic waste materials
not containing toxic or explosive elements, injurious to sewers or sewage
treatment processes, which result from any commercial, manufacturing or
industrial operation or process.
   (c)   “Nonacceptable industrial wastes” means liquid wastes in which are
incorporated materials, oil, acid, toxic, metallic or chemical substances
resulting from any commercial, manufacturing or industrial operation or
process.
      (Ord. 1634. Passed 6-9-58.)
   (d)   “City” means the Village of Mingo Junction.
   (e)   “Quarter” or “quarterly” means three months or over a three month
period.
      (Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
929.02 NECESSITY FOR CHARGES.
   It is hereby determined and declared necessary for the due protection of the
public health, safety and welfare of the Village, to establish and collect
charges for the use of the sewer system upon all lots, lands and premises
served or capable of being served by or having connection with the system.
(Ord. 1634. Passed 6-9-58.)
929.03 ALLOCATION OF FUNDS.
   The funds received from the collection of the rates and charges hereinafter
provided shall be deposited as received with the Village Clerk who shall keep
the same in a separate fund designated Sewer Revenue Fund. Subject to the
provisions of any ordinance or indenture of mortgage authorizing the issuance
of and securing mortgage revenue bonds for such system, monies in the Fund
shall be used for the payment of the cost and expense of operation,
maintenance, repair, and management of the system and for payment of debt
charges on bonds issued for extensions and improvements of the system. Any
surplus in such Fund over and above the requirements hereinbefore mentioned may
be used for enlargements of and replacements to the system and parts thereof.
(Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
929.04 SEWER RATES ESTABLISHED.
   For the purposes provided in Section
929.03, there is hereby levied and charged upon each lot, parcel of land or
premises having a connection with the system or otherwise discharging sewage,
industrial wastes, water or other liquids either directly or indirectly into
the system, or capable of being served by such system, sewage charges payable
as hereinafter provided in amounts to be determined as follows, effective with
all bills rendered on or after July 1, 2009:
   (a)   Except as hereinafter provided, sewer charges at the rates provided in
this section with respect to any premises shall be based upon the water
consumption for such premises, as herein defined for the billing period
applicable to such premises. “Water consumption” means the amount of water
consumed upon such premises and discharged into the system measured as provided
in Section
929.06 during the applicable sewer charge billing period.
      (Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-20-09.)
   (b)   The sewer rates for the Village of Mingo Junction shall be established
as follows:
      (1)   A capital improvement charge of twelve dollars ($12.00) per month
to be deposited in the Sewer Improvement Fund (formerly the Sewer Equipment
Replacement Fund).
      (2)   A minimum charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month for the
first 2,000 gallons, or fraction thereof, of water used.
      (3)   A charge of five dollars ($5.00) per thousand gallon of water usage
above the minimum usage.
         (Ord. 2020-6. Passed 3-10-20.)
   (c)   The surcharge of “extra-strength” waste shall be established annually
by the Village Administrator in accordance with the Village’s User Charge
System, formerly known as the “City’s User Charge System” and Sewer Use Code.
      (Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
   
929.041 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT CHARGE.
   A capital improvement charge of eight dollars ($8.00) per month to be
deposited in the Sewer Improvements Fund (formerly the Sewer Equipment
Replacement Fund).
(Ord. 2014-3. Passed 2-25-14.)
929.05 SPECIAL AGREEMENT FOR INDUSTRIAL WASTE.
   Over and above the rates and charges established by Section
929.04 there may be established in special instances and upon special agreement
between the Village and the owner of any premises served by the system, such
additional charges for industrial wastes of unusual strength or composition or
for other unduly burdensome discharges into the system which are accepted by
the Village for treatment as may be determined to be fair and equitable. Each
such special agreement and the charges established thereby shall not become
effective until ratified by ordinance duly passed by Council.
(Ord.1634. Passed 6-9-58.)
929.06 MEASURES FOR DETERMINING SEWER CHARGES.
   The following measures shall be used to determine sewer charges provided by
Section
929.04 upon all premises served by the system:
   (a)   On premises using water exclusively supplied by the Village, water
consumption shall be measured by water meter acceptable to the Village
Administrator.
   (b)   On premises using water supplied either in whole or in part from
sources other than the waterworks of the Village, the Village Administrator may
require the owner or other interested party to install water meters
satisfactory to the Village Administrator to the extent necessary to measure
all such supplies of water, and the quantity of water consumed on such premises
shall be deemed to be the aggregate amount disclosed by such meters.
   (c)   In the event it can be shown to the satisfaction of the Village
Administrator with respect to any premises that a portion of the water from any
source consumed on such premises does not and cannot enter the system, then in
each such case, the owner or other interested party may at his expense install
and maintain separate metering devices to the extent necessary to demonstrate
to the satisfaction of the Village Administrator the portion of the water
consumed on the premises which is discharged into the system, which portion
shall constitute the basis for measuring the sewer charges for the premises
under Section
929.04.
      (Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
929.07 PAYMENT; PENALTY.
   The sewer charges levied at the rates established by Section
929.04 shall be billed and become payable in the following manner: Charges
levied with respect to premises served by the Village’s waterworks system shall
be included in and be payable with the Village’s water bill to such premises
and shall be billed quarterly or monthly in accordance with the billing period
for the Village water furnished to such premises. In respect of premises not
served by the Village’s waterworks system, such charges shall be billed and
payable quarterly, unless, upon application to the Village Administrator, he
shall approve a monthly billing period for such premises, and in either case,
shall be payable at the same time, respectively, as water bills are rendered
and become payable. In case of failure to pay any bill for sewer charges when
due, a penalty of five percent of the charges shall be added to such bill.
(Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
929.08 CHARGES MADE A LIEN; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   Each sewer charge levied pursuant to this chapter is hereby made a lien upon
the premises charged therewith, and if the same is not paid within thirty days
after it shall be due and payable, it shall be certified to the Auditor of
Jefferson County, who shall place the same on the tax duplicate with the
interest and penalties allowed by law, and be collected as other municipal
taxes are collected. The Village shall also have the right, in event of
nonpayment as aforesaid to discontinue service to such premises of water
supplied by the Village’s waterworks system, until such unpaid sewer charges
have been fully paid.
(Ord. 1634. Passed 6-9-58.)
929.09 NONACCEPTABLE WASTES PROHIBITED; TREATMENT.
   The discharge of non-acceptable industrial wastes as herein defined, into
the system, whether directly or indirectly, is hereby prohibited. Where
investigation reveals the presence in the system of non-acceptable industrial
wastes emanating from any lot, land, building or premises located within or
without the corporate limits of the Village, the owner, lessor, tenant or
occupant of such lot, land, building or premises shall be required to treat,
neutralize or in other ways prepare the noxious substance therein to the
satisfaction of the Village Administrator, in order to convert the same into
acceptable industrial wastes.
(Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
929.10 VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR TO MAKE AND ENFORCE REGULATIONS.
   The Village Administrator shall make and enforce such rules and regulations
as he may deem necessary for the enforcement of the provisions hereof, for the
proper determination and collection of the rates and charges herein provided
and for the safe, efficient and economical management of the system. Such rules
and regulations, when not repugnant to existing ordinances of the Village or
laws of the State shall have the same force and effect as ordinances of
Council.
(Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
929.11 MUNICIPALITY’S PREMISES AND WATER EXEMPTED.
   Except as otherwise provided in any ordinance authorizing an indenture
securing revenue bonds issued for construction of the system or portion
thereof, no lot, parcel of land, building or premises now or hereafter used by
the Village for municipal purposes shall be subject to the sewer charges hereby
established, nor shall any water supplied by the Municipal waterworks system
for extinguishing fires, cleaning fire apparatus or furnishing or supplying
water to fire hydrants be used to determine any sewer charge provided in
Section
929.04.
(Ord. 1634. Passed 6-9-58.)
929.12 CONNECTIONS OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   The Village Administrator shall, upon application, be empowered to serve
lots, lands, buildings or premises outside the limits of the Village where such
service is desired by the owner of such lots, lands, buildings or premises
provided the owner connects to the sewerage system of the Village at his own
expense. Such sewers and other works installed by such persons shall be built
to specifications as provided by the Village and shall be in conformity with
all laws, regulations and specifications as may be promulgated by the Village,
County, State or other governmental agencies having authority.
(Ord. 2009-20. Passed 7-28-09.)
CHAPTER 933
Water

933.02   Discontinuance of service.

743.01
Compulsory water connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23
Management and control of water works - see Ohio R.C. 743.02 et seq.
Tampering with water meters prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
541.09
 
933.01 WATER SERVICE.
   (a)   A deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be required
from any customer requesting water service from the Village who is not the
owner of the property for which service is to be provided.
   (b)   No service shall be provided to any customer who is not the owner of
the property to which service is provided until the owner of said property
agrees to accept responsibility for any charges not paid by the customer in
excess of the available deposit.
   (c)   The owner of any property may request that a deposit not be required
of a tenant provided that the owner shall accept complete responsibility for
any charges accrued by said tenant. The Village Administrator will determine on
a case by case basis if any deposit shall be waived.
   (d)   The owner of any property receiving water service in the Village shall
notify the Village of any change in occupancy within five (5) days of said
charge. The failure of an owner to notify the Village of said change shall
result in the owner being responsible for any outstanding balance.
   (e)   No service shall be provided to any property whose owner is delinquent
in any amount, whether for the property for which service is requested or any
other property served by the Village.
(Ord. 2012-11. Passed 6-12-12.)
933.02 DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   (a)   Any amount due for water and sewage services that is not paid within
fifteen (15) days of the due date shall be subject to discontinuance of
service. Prior to discontinuing service the Village shall notify the customer
of the unpaid amount and that the service will be subject to termination after
10 days.
   (b)   The customer and/or the owner may appeal such notice in writing to the
Village Administrator who shall meet with the customer/owner and determine if
and when the termination of service shall occur.
   (c)   Any termination of service shall occur between the hours of 8:00 a.m.
and 2:00 p.m. on Monday through Thursday.
   (d)   There is hereby established a reconnection charge of fifty dollars
($50.00) to reconnect water service to any customer of the Village by the
Village for failure to pay water and sewage services or for the violation of
any water and sewage regulations established by the Village provided that said
reconnection is done during normal business hours. Any reconnection done
outside of normal business hours shall be subject to a charge of seventy-five
dollars ($75.00).
   (e)   Any reconnection charge shall be paid prior to the reconnection of
water service.
(Ord. 2012-11. Passed 6-12-12.)
933.03 BACKFLOW PROTECTION.
   (a)   If, in the judgement of the Superintendent of Water, an approved
backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water
system, the Superintendent of Water will give notice to the water consumer to
install such an approved device immediately. The water consumer shall, at his
own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner
approved by the Superintendent of Water and shall have inspections and tests
made of such approved devices as required by the Superintendent of Water.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply or other than the regular public
water supply of Mingo Junction may enter the supply or distributing system of
said Municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and
the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
Superintendent of Water of Mingo Junction and by the Ohio Environmental
Protection Agency.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of the Superintendent of Water to cause surveys
and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply where actual or potential hazards to the public water
supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of
public record and shall be repeated as often as the Superintendent of Water
shall deem necessary.
   (d)   The Superintendent of Water or his or its duly authorized
representative shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any
property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution
system of Mingo Junction for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or
systems thereof. On demand the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so
served shall furnish to the Superintendent of Water any information which he
may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such
property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the
discretion of the Superintendent, be deemed evidence of the presence of
improper connections as provided in this section.
   (e)   The Superintendent of Water is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
section is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he
may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water
distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until
such conditions shall have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the
provisions of this section.
(Ord. 1995-15. Passed 5-25-95.)
933.04 CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL PROGRAM.
   The Village herein adopts the Cross Connection Control Program and
accompanying regulations as prepared by CT Consultants, a copy of which is
attached to Ordinance 1998-31 and made a part of this section.
933.05 RATES.
   (a)   A debt service fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per month shall be
charged to all customers of the Village.
   (b)   The rate for the purchase of water from the Village is established at
eleven dollars and fifty cents ($11.50) per thousand gallons for customers
within the Village.
   
   (c)   The rate for the purchase of water from the Village in excess of one
hundred fifty thousand gallons (150,000) per month is established at five
dollars and seventy-five cents ($5.75) per thousand gallons for amounts over
one hundred fifty thousand (150,000).
   (d)   The rate for the purchase of water from the Village is established at
twelve dollars and sixty-five cents ($12.65) per thousand gallons for customers
outside of the Village.
   (e)   A capital improvement charge of two dollars ($2.00) per month to be
deposited in the Water Improvement Fund (formerly the Water Equipment
Replacement Fund).
   (f)   Water and Sewage charges shall be billed as monthly and shall be
payable by the fifteenth day of the month of billing. Failure to pay the
required amount by the fifteenth of each month shall incur a ten percent (10%)
penalty.
   (g)   The Village Administrator is hereby authorized to negotiate fees for
large or bulk water users, subject to the approval of Village Council.
(Ord. 2017-6. Passed 4-25-17.)
   (h)   The rate for bulk water shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per thousand
gallons.
(Ord. 2010-14. Passed 10-26-10.)
TITLE FIVE - Other Public Services
Chap.
953. Oakland Cemetery.
Chap.
955. Garbage and Rubbish Collection.
CHAPTER 953
Oakland Cemetery
953.01   Charge to open and close grave.
953.02   Cost of grave plot.
953.03   Vaults.
953.04   Nonresidents.
953.05   Charges to accompany burial permit.
953.06   Paupers.
953.07   Payment of lots purchased; resale.
953.08   Regulations for operation.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Management and control of cemeteries - see Ohio R.C. 759.09
Burial permits - see Ohio R.C. 3705.24 et seq.
Burial of indigent persons - see Ohio R.C. 5113.15
 
953.01 CHARGE TO OPEN AND CLOSE GRAVE.
   (a)   The charges for the opening and closing of graves at Oakland Cemetery
are as follows:
      (1)   Adult Grave: Four hundred fifty dollars on weekdays and five
hundred dollars on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
      (2)   Infant Grave: Four hundred dollars on weekdays, and four hundred
fifty dollars on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
      (3)   Crematory Grave: Two hundred seventy-five dollars on weekdays, and
three hundred dollars on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
   (b)   The Village Administrator is authorized to charge for the opening and
closing of graves at Oakland Cemetery in accordance with subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 2010-3. Passed 2-23-10.)
953.02 COST OF GRAVE PLOT.
   (a)   Regardless of the type of burial involved, the charge for a single
plot (one lot) at Oakland Cemetery is increased to two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00). If multiple single plots are purchased, the charge for each single
plot shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   (b)   The Village Administrator is authorized to make a charge for the sale
of the plots in Oakland Cemetery in accordance with subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 2004-29. Passed 1-11-05.)
953.03 VAULTS.
   Vaults made of wood or wood content shall be prohibited in Cemetery Sections
1, 2 and 3 or any future section that may be opened for burials. This does not
apply to individual sections as specified by the trustees or Village
Administrator.
(Ord. 1970-66. Passed 11-19-70.)
953.04 NONRESIDENTS.
   Due to the limited number of burial plots still available, no burial plot
shall be sold to a nonresident of the City.
(Ord. 1970-66. Passed 11-19-70.)
953.05 CHARGES TO ACCOMPANY BURIAL PERMIT.
   All opening and closing charges shall be payable at the time of burial and
accompany the burial permit.
(Ord. 1970-66. Passed 11-19-70.)
953.06 PAUPERS.
   Free lots for paupers shall be available as determined by the Cemetery
Committee of Council.
(Ord. 1970-66. Passed 11-19-70.)
953.07 PAYMENT OF LOTS PURCHASED; RESALE.
   Payment of lots purchased shall be made in full at the time the deed is
issued. Time payments can be made at the discretion of the Village
Administrator, but in no event shall such time payments exceed a period of six
months. Purchasers of lots in the cemetery who desire to sell such lots must
first offer them to the Village for purchase before offering the same to the
general public. The Village shall repurchase such lots for the price being
charged by the Village for comparable lots.
(Ord. 1988-41. Passed 5-12-88.)
953.08 REGULATIONS FOR OPERATION.
   (a)   All markers or monuments placed in Oakland Cemetery shall not exceed
thirty-six inches in height and shall be of granite, marble, stone, brass,
bronze, stainless steel or other material which will not deteriorate due to
time or weather.
   (b)   All markers or monuments shall be placed at the head of the grave.
Footstones or memorials may be placed at the foot of the grave only if they are
installed level with the existing grounds.
   (c)   All plots shall be marked at the corners of the plot by suitable
markers approved by the Village Administrator.
   (d)   No memorial or marker shall be placed on any grave without its
placement being approved by the Village Administrator or his designated
representative.
   (e)   No trees or shrubs shall be planted on any grave. Existing trees and
shrubs may remain provided they are properly maintained and trimmed. Any tree
or shrub which is not properly maintained or which interferes with the
maintenance of the cemetery may be removed at the discretion of the Village
Administrator.
   (f)   No coping, curbing, fencing, or enclosures of any type will be
permitted on any lot. No stones, marble chips or similar material will be
permitted on any lot.
   (g)   All plantings shall be made in front of the grave marker only and
shall be in metal or other unbreakable containers. No artificial plants or
flowers will be permitted between April 1 through October 31.
   (h)   No vehicles may be driven or placed off of the paved areas of the
cemeteries without the permission of the Village Administrator.
   (i)   Any item placed in Oakland Cemetery in violation of the above
regulations may be removed at the direction of the Village Administrator.
   (j)   Variances from the above regulations may be granted only upon written
request to and approval by the Cemetery Committee of Council.
(Ord. 1990-39. Passed 6-14-90.)
CHAPTER 955
Garbage and Rubbish Collection
955.01   Definitions.
955.02   Regular pick-up.
955.03   Accumulation of uncollected garbage prohibited.
955.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et seq.
Vehicle loads dropping, sifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08,
339.09
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
 
955.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Garbage” means all putrescible wastes, except human excreta, sewage
and other water-carried wastes, including vegetable and animal offal and
carcasses of dead animals, and includes all such substances from all public and
private establishments, and from all residences.
   (b)   “Other refuse” means ashes, grass, glass, crockery, tin and aluminum
cans, paper, boxes, rags and old clothing and other similar nonputrescible
wastes. The term does not include any materials such as earth, sand, trees,
tree trunks, tree stumps, shrubs, tires, electronics (such as but not limited
to televisions and computers), concrete, brick, roofing, tile, stone,
plasterboard, oil and other automotive fluids, paint and paint-related
products, household hazardous waste (including but not limited to lawn and
garden chemicals), plaster, dry wall, lumber, wood, carpet or other similar
substances that may accumulate as a result of remodeling or construction
projects.
   (c)   “Bulk waste” means hot water tanks, mattresses, box springs, freezers,
dishwashers, washers, dryers, unusable furniture, stoves, ovens and
refrigerators. The term does not include any materials such as earth, sand,
trees, tree trunks, tree stumps, shrubs, tires, electronics (such as but not
limited to televisions and computers), concrete, brick, roofing, tile, stone,
plasterboard, oil and other automotive fluids, paint and paint-related
products, household hazardous waste (including but not limited to lawn and
garden chemicals), plaster, dry wall, lumber, wood, carpet or other similar
substances that may accumulate as a result of remodeling or construction
projects.
   (d)   “Householder” means the head of family or one maintaining separate
living quarters and includes owners, tenants and occupants of all premises
where garbage or other refuse or both are created. Nothing in this definition
shall be construed to apply to commercial operators as defined in subsection
(f) hereof.
   (e)   “Premises” means land or building or both, or parts of either or both,
occupied by a householder or a commercial operator.
   (f)   “Commercial operator” means all persons, firms, or corporations who
own or operates stores, restaurants, industries, institutions and other similar
places, public or private, charitable or non-charitable, and includes all
responsible persons other than householders, upon the premises of which garbage
or other refuse or both are created.
   (g)   “Nonresident” means person or persons living outside of City limits.
      (Ord. 2017-2. Passed 4-11-17.)
955.02 REGULAR PICK-UP.
   (a)   No householder or commercial operator shall permit to accumulate upon
the premises any garbage or other refuse except in covered containers. When
plastic containers are used, the City shall not be responsible for the cost if
the containers are split, torn or damaged.
   (b)   All garbage and other refuse shall be kept in rust-resistant,
watertight, nonabsorbent and easily washable containers which are covered with
close-fitting lids except as provided in subsection (c) hereof. Where
practicable, all garbage shall be drained of liquid and wrapped in paper. These
containers shall be of adequate capacity, not exceeding 33 gallons, and
provided in sufficient number to hold all garbage and refuse that accumulates
between collections. All containers shall be washed and treated with a
disinfectant as often as necessary to prevent nuisance.
   (c)   Garbage and other refuse can also be stored in other reasonably tight
and substantial containers that are easy to handle. Such containers can be
plastic bags of adequate capacity and thickness, tied at the top and provided
in sufficient number to hold all other refuse that accumulates between
collections.
   (d)   Garbage and other refuse shall not be placed on the curb strip before
5:00 a.m. on the day prior to the designated pickup.
   (e)   Garbage and other refuse containers shall not remain on the curb strip
after 12:00 midnight on the day after the day of designated pickup.
   (f)   Bulk waste shall not be placed on the curb strip more than three days
before the designated day of pickup.
   (g)   Nonresidents are prohibited from disposing of any garbage, other
refuse or bulk waste anywhere in the City limits.
(Ord. 2017-2. Passed 4-11-17.)
955.03 ACCUMULATION OF UNCOLLECTED GARBAGE PROHIBITED.
   No person shall permit fermenting, putrefying or odoriferous garbage or
other refuse in containers or dumped in the open to accumulate or remain in any
place.
(Ord. 2017-2. Passed 4-11-17.)
955.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2017-2. Passed 4-11-17.)

CHAPTER 1101
Title, Purpose and Application
1101.01   Title.
1101.02   Authority and scope.
1101.03   Purpose.
1101.04   Applicability.
1101.05   Interpretation and application.
1101.06   Conflicting laws.
1101.07   Effective date.
1101.08   Repeal of existing code.
1101.09   Severability.
1101.01 TITLE.
   These rules, regulations, procedures and accompanying maps shall be known,
cited and referred to as the Mingo Junction Planning and Zoning Code. This
Planning and Zoning Code includes standards for planning, subdividing and
developing land within the Village. This Planning and Zoning Code combines the
rules, regulations and standards contained in the Subdivision Regulations and
Zoning Code into one unified land use ordinance.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.02 AUTHORITY AND SCOPE.
   (a)   This Planning and Zoning Code is adopted by the Village pursuant to
its authority  under the Ohio Revised Code. Nothing in this Planning and Zoning
Code shall be construed to limit Village Council in the exercise of all of the
powers to zone or redistrict now or hereafter as authorized by the Ohio Revised
Code.
 
   (b)   The regulations contained in this Planning and Zoning Code shall apply
to the use of private property in the Village of Mingo Junction and do not
apply to the use of public property, including Village rights-of-way.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.03 PURPOSE.
   This Planning and Zoning Code establishes certain districts in the Village
and regulates and restricts the ways in which land can be used and subdivided
in order to promote the public health, safety, convenience, prosperity and
general welfare. More specific purposes are to:
   (a)    Promote the orderly and beneficial development of the Village of
Mingo Junction in accordance with the Village's land use policies.
   (b)    Establish districts of such classification and number to encourage
the most appropriate uses of the land and guide the future development of the
Village and to carry out the purposes of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (c)   Encourage compatibility between different land uses and protect the
scale and character of existing development from the encroachment of
incompatible uses.
   (d)   Regulate and restrict the location, bulk, height and land coverage of
buildings to protect the character and value of the Village's residential,
business and industrial areas.
   (e)    Regulate the area and dimension of lots, yards and other open spaces
to provide adequate open spaces for light and air.
   (f)   Ensure efficient traffic circulation, manage congestion on the streets
and improve public safety by locating buildings and uses adjacent to streets in
such a manner that they will cause the least interference with, and be damaged
least by, traffic movements.
   (g)    Facilitate adequate provisions for public utilities and facilities
such as schools, recreation facilities, sewer, water, transportation and other
public necessities.
   (h)    Provide regulations, standards and procedures for the administration,
amendment and enforcement of this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.04 APPLICABILITY.
   After the effective date of this Planning and Zoning Code, no use of a
structure or land shall be changed, and no structure or part thereof shall be
erected, moved or altered, unless for a use expressly permitted by and in
conformity with, the regulations specified in this Planning and Zoning Code.
Existing buildings, structures and uses of land that do not comply with the
regulations of this Planning and Zoning Code are subject to the regulations set
forth in Chapter
1163, Nonconforming Uses. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.05  INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION.
   Unless specifically noted otherwise, in interpreting and applying the
provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code, these provisions shall be
considered the minimum requirements necessary for the promotion of the public
health, safety and general welfare. They shall be liberally construed to
further the purposes and objectives set forth herein and the purposes and
intent of each district as set forth in each district chapter.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.06 CONFLICTING LAWS.
   (a)   Except as specifically provided herein, the provisions of this
Planning and Zoning Code shall not repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair
or interfere with any existing deed or plat restrictions, ordinances, laws,
rules, or permits previously adopted or issued, and shall not be construed as
removing or rendering inoperative any deed or land restriction formerly
established by restrictive covenants running with the land, easements or other
agreements between parties.
   (b)   In cases where this Planning and Zoning Code imposes a greater
restriction upon the use of buildings or land or upon the height and/or bulk of
buildings, or requires larger lot area, yards or other open spaces than are
imposed or required by such other laws or ordinances, or by such rules and
regulations, the provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code shall govern.
Conversely, other regulations shall govern where they are more restrictive in
nature than this
Planning and Zoning Code.
   (c)   These regulations shall in no way affect any approved final
development plan or subdivision that has received preliminary approval prior to
the effective date of these regulations or any amendments thereto.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.07 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This Planning and Zoning Code, and amendments thereto, shall take effect and
be in full force and effect from and after the earliest period allowed by law.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.08 REPEAL OF EXISTING CODE.
   The Planning and Zoning Code of the Village of Mingo Junction, Ohio, adopted
effective January 24, 2002 and as subsequently amended together with the Zoning
Map, is hereby repealed and amended to read as set forth in this Planning and
Zoning Code update, dated January 24, 2002. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1101.09 SEVERABILITY.
   Sections and subsections of this Planning and Zoning Code and the several
parts or provisions thereof are hereby declared to be independent sections,
subsections, parts and provisions. If any section, subsection or provision of
this Planning and Zoning Code, or amendment thereto, is held to be invalid or
unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall
not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Planning and Zoning
Code or amendments thereto.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1103
Definitions
1103.01    Interpretation of terms and words.
1103.02   Definitions.
1103.01 INTERPRETATION OF TERMS AND WORDS.
   For the purpose of this Planning and Zoning Code, certain terms and words
used herein shall be interpreted as follows:
   (a)   The word "shall" is a mandatory requirement, the word "may" is a
permissive requirement, and the word “should" is a preferred requirement.
   (b)   The word "lot" includes the words “plot" or “parcel”.
   (c)   The words "used" and “occupied" include the words “intended,"
"designed" or "arranged" to be used or occupied.
   (d)   The word "person" includes a firm, association, organization,
partnership, trust, company or corporation, as well as an individual.
   (e)   The present tense includes the future tense, the singular number
includes the plural, and the plural number includes the singular.
   (f)   Whenever a number of days are specified, days shall mean calendar days
unless specifically noted otherwise.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1103.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Words used in this Planning and Zoning Code are used in their ordinary
English usage.
   (b)   However, for the purpose of this Planning and Zoning Code, certain
words herein
are defined and whenever used in this Planning and Zoning Code, shall have the
meaning indicated in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a
different meaning.
      (1)   ABANDONED VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle or accessory to the same,
licensed or unlicensed, without regard to its age or value, and which is
apparently inoperable, or in such condition that it could not be legally
operated, or is in an extensively damaged, dilapidated, or disassembled
condition. For the purposes of this definition, vehicle includes but is not
limited to automobile, truck, jeep, van, trailer, farm equipment, boat,
aircraft and off-road vehicles.
      (2)    ACCESS DRIVE. A paved strip which provides a vehicular connection
between off-street parking spaces and a public street.
      (3)    ALTERATION. A change or rearrangement in the structural parts or
in the exit facilities of a building or structure, or an enlargement, whether
by extending on a side or by increasing height or by moving from one location
to another.
      (4)    APPROPRIATE. Belonging peculiarly, or specially suitable.
      (5)    APPROVED. Sanctioned by the appropriate official as required by
law so long as all provisions of these zoning regulations are met.
      (6)    AUTO REPAIR GARAGE. A building or part of a building that is used
for the major repair, rebuilding or reconstruction of motor vehicles or parts
thereof including collision service, painting, washing and steam cleaning of
vehicles.
      (7)    AUTO SERVICE STATION. A building or part of a building, structure
or space which is used for the retail sale of lubricants and motor vehicle
accessories and where the routine maintenance and service of vehicles and the
making of repairs to motor vehicles are conducted, except that repairs
described as major repairs in "Auto Repair Garage" shall not be permitted.
      (8)    BASEMENT. A story having not more than one-half (½) of its height
above the finished grade. A basement is counted as a story for the purpose of
height regulations if it is subdivided and used for dwelling purposes other
than by a janitor employed on the premises.
      (9)    BLOCK. A distinct portion or plot of land in a platted subdivision
described and numbered as a block on the recorded plat of the subdivision, or a
distinct portion or plot of land bounded on all sides by public streets.
      (10)    BOARD. The Village of Mingo Junction, Ohio Zoning Board of
Appeals.
      (11)    BOARDING HOUSE. A building occupied for, or arranged, intended or
designed to be occupied for rooming or rooming and boarding for compensation by
not less than four (4) persons by prearrangement for definite periods of not
less than one (1) week in contrast to a hotel which is open for occupancy for
shorter periods. The term "boarding house" includes "lodging house" and
"rooming house."
      (12)    BUFFER YARD. A strip of ground running along the property line
between adjacent districts designed to improve the quality of the district and
to protect any adjacent neighbors from offensive, unsafe or unhealthy
conditions.
      (13)    BUILDING. A roofed structure for support, shelter or enclosure of
persons, animals, chattels or property. The term “building” does not include
any vehicle, trailer (with or without wheels), or any removable device, such as
furniture, machinery, or equipment.
         A.    BUILDING, ACCESSORY. A subordinate building detached from, but
located on the same lot as, the principal building, the use of which is
incidental and accessory to that of the principal building.
         B.   BUILDING ATTACHED. A building attached to another building by a
common wall (such wall being a solid wall with or without windows and doors)
and/or a common roof with a common horizontal dimension of eight (8) feet or
more.
         C.    BUILDING, HEIGHT OF. The vertical distance from the grade to the
highest point of the roof surface if it is a flat roof: to the deck line for a
mansard roof; and to the mean height level between eaves and ridge for gambrel,
gable or hip roofs, each of which is measured to the average finished grade
across the front of the building.
          Figure I - Building Height for Gambrel, Gable or Hip Roofs
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/37720bd21ee1d45ff75e71d0803f8117e8de59b7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2189_4603x2629.jpg]
         D.    BUILDING, NONCONFORMING. A building or portion thereof, lawfully
existing at the time this Planning and Zoning Code or any amendment hereto
became effective, that does not conform to all regulations applicable in the
zone district in which it is located.
         E.    BUILDING, PRINCIPAL AND/OR MAIN. A building in which is
conducted the main or principal use of the lot or parcel on which such building
is situated, including areas such as garages, carports, storage sheds, etc.,
which are attached to and architecturally integrated with the principal
building.
      (14)    CARPORT. A roofed structure providing space for the parking of
motor vehicles and enclosed on not more than two (2) sides.
      (15)    CAR WASH. A building or enclosed area that provides facilities
for washing and cleaning motor vehicles, which may use production line methods
with a conveyor, blower, or other mechanical devices and/or which may employ
hand labor.
      (16)    CEMETERY. Land used or intended to be used for the burial of the
human dead and dedicated for cemetery purposes, including columbariums and
mausoleums, when operated in conjunction with and within the boundaries of such
cemetery.
      (17)    COMMERCIAL VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle licensed by the state as a
commercial vehicle.
      (18)    COMMISSION. The Village of Mingo Junction Municipal Planning and
Zoning Commission.
      (19)   COMMON DRIVE. A private way that provides access to two (2) or
more dwelling units.
      (20)    COMPREHENSIVE PLAN. A document or documents which contain the sum
of the policies, proposals, programs, maps and reports adopted by the Planning
and Zoning Commission to serve as a guide for community growth.
      (21)    CONGREGATE CARE FACILITY. A residential facility to provide for
the needs of individuals who are elderly or handicapped. The facility shall
consist of residential dwelling units designed specifically for the elderly or
handicapped, and have common social, recreational, dining and food preparation
facilities, and may provided skilled nursing care.
      (22)    COUNCIL. The Village Council of the Village of Mingo Junction,
Ohio.
      (23)    COUNTY. Jefferson County, Ohio.
      (24)    COVENANT. A written promise or pledge.
      (25)    COVERED. Roofed, trellised or otherwise shielded from the sky
except for ground cover material.
      (26)    DAY CARE FACILITY. DAY CARE, ADULT OR CHILD. Ministering to the
needs of persons other than by their children, parents, guardians, custodians,
or relatives for any part of the twenty-four (24) hour day, in a place other
than the persons own home.
      (27)    DAY CARE, FAMILY HOME, TYPE B. A permanent residence of the
provider in which child day-care or child day-care services are provided for
one (1) to six (6) children at one time and in which no more than three (3)
children may be under two (2) years of age at one time. In counting children
for the purposes of this division. any children under six (6) years of age who
are related to the provider and who are on the premises of the type B home
shall be counted "Type B family day-care home" does not include a residence in
which the needs of children are administered to, if all of the children whose
needs are being administered to are siblings of the same immediate family and
the residence is the home of the siblings.
      (28)    DENSITY. The number of dwelling units per acres of land.
      (29)    DEVELOPER. Any person. partnership or corporation or duly
authorized agent who constructs or contracts to construct improvements on
property.
      (30)    DEVELOPMENT PLAN. A plan prepared to scale, showing accurately
and with complete dimensioning the boundaries of the site, the location of
buildings, landscaping, parking areas, access drives, signs, outdoor storage
areas and any other features that comprise a proposed development.
      (31)    DISTRICT ZONE. A land area or land areas as defined by the Zoning
Map, within which the zoning regulations are uniform.
      (32)    DRIVE-THRU FACILITY. Any portion of a building or structure from
which business is transacted, or is capable of being transacted, directly with
customers located in a motor vehicle during such business transactions. The
term "drive through" shall also include "drive-up" and "drive-in".
      (33)    DWELLING MULTIPLE. A building designed for or occupied by three
(3) or more families, living independently of each other.
      (34)    DWELLING, SINGLE-FAMILY. A detached building designed for or
occupied exclusively by one-family.
      (35)   DWELLING, TWO-FAMILY. A dwelling consisting of two (2) dwelling
units which may be either attached side by side, or one above the other, and
each unit having a separate or combined entrance and entrances.
      (36)    DWELLING UNIT. A building or portion thereof providing complete
housekeeping facilities including kitchen and toilet facilities for only one
(1) family, which has a permanent foundation and has never been titled as a
motor vehicle.
      (37)    EASEMENT. A grant by the property owner of a portion of their
property rights to another person or entity for a specific use or uses.
      (38)    ENCLOSED. Surrounded by walls and/or fences on all sides and a
roof.
      (39)    ENGINEER. A registered engineer as defined in the Ohio Revised
Code.
      (40)    ENGINEER, VILLAGE. The individual employed by the Village of
Mingo Junction permanently employed to oversee projects and matters of an
engineering nature on behalf of the Village.
      (41)    FACILITIES AND APPURTENANCES. Means and includes water system
wells, pump stations, water storage and treatment facilities and appurtenances,
valves, hydrants and curb connections, storm sewer manholes, curb inlets, catch
basins, culverts, headwalls, and open drainage channels; street lighting
fixtures, pole supports, controls and wiring; and such other construction as
may be deemed necessary to effect a completed system of any of the major items
listed in this subsection.
      (42)    FAMILY. A group of persons related by blood, marriage, adoption,
friendship or economic circumstance, living together on the premises in a
single dwelling unit.
      (43)    FAMILY DAY CARE HOME, TYPE B. A permanent residence of the
provider in which child day-care or child day-care services are provided for
one (1) to six (6) children at one time and in which no more than three (3)
children may be under two (2) years of age at one time. In counting children
for the purposes of this division, any children under six (6) years of age who
are related to the provider and who are on the premises of the type B home
shall be counted. "Type B family day-care home" does not include a residence in
which the needs of children are administered to, if all of the children whose
needs are being administered to are siblings of the same immediate family and
the residence is the home of the siblings, nor does it include any child day
camp.
      (44)    FENCE. Any structure composed of wood, iron, steel, masonry,
stone or other material and erected in such a manner and in such a location as
to enclose, secure, partially enclose or secure, provide privacy, decorate,
define or enhance all or any part of any premises.
      (45)    FENCE, HEIGHT OF. The vertical distance between the grade of the
ground upon which located and the top of the fence.
      (46)    FLOOR AREA, GROSS. The sum of the gross horizontal areas measured
between the exterior faces of exterior walls of the several floors of a
building and accessory buildings, including interior walls, mezzanines,
hallways, basements and cellars, but not including such space unless such space
is used for business purposes.
      (47)    FRONTAGE. That portion of a lot abutting upon a street.
      (48)    FUNERAL HOME. A building or part thereof used for human funeral
services. Such building may contain space and facilities for: (a) embalming and
the performance of other services used in preparation of the dead for burial;
(b) the performance of autopsies and other surgical procedures: (c) the storage
of caskets, funeral urns, and other related funeral supplies; and (d) the
storage of funeral vehicles. but shall not include facilities for cremation.
Where a funeral home is permitted, a funeral chapel shall also be permitted.
      (49)    GARAGE. A building, designed, built or used for the parking and
storage of automobiles.
      (50)    GASOLINE STATION. An establishment where liquids used as motor
fuels are stored and dispensed into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles by an
attendant or by persons other than the station attendant and may include
facilities available for the sale of other retail products.
      (51)    GRADE, FINISHED. The average level of the finished surface of
ground adjacent to the exterior walls of the building after final grading and
normal settlement.
      (52)    GRADE, NATURAL. The elevation of the undisturbed natural surface
of the ground prior to any recent excavation or fill.
      (53)    HANDICAPPED. A physical or mental impairment, as defined in 42
U.S.C. 3602 (h), that substantially limits one or more of such person's major
life activities so that such person is incapable of living independently.
However, "handicapped" shall not include current illegal use of or addiction to
a controlled substance, nor shall it include any person whose residency in a
home would constitute a direct threat to the health and safety of other
individuals.
      (54)    HIGHWAY PLAN. The plan of the Village of Mingo Junction streets
and highways.
      (55)    HOME FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS, FAMILY. A residential facility that
provides room and board, personal care. rehabilitative or habilitative
services, and supervision in a family setting for five (5) to eight (8)
handicapped persons. (See HANDICAPPED.) One (1) to four (4) persons, including
resident staff, living in such a residential facility constitute a family for
the purposes of this Planning and Zoning Code (see FAMILY), and are not subject
to the conditional use regulations for family homes. The term "family home for
handicapped persons" does not include "halfway house" or other housing
facilities serving as an alternative to incarceration, "nursing home", "rest
home", "boarding house", "rooming house", "lodging house", "residential
treatment home/center", "special care home" or any other such similar building
or use of a building.
      (56)    HOME FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS, GROUP.  A residential facility that
provides room and board, personal care, rehabilitative and habilitative
services, and supervision in a family setting for at least nine (9) handicapped
persons. (See HANDICAPPED.) The term "group home for handicapped persons" does
not include "halfway house" or other housing facilities serving as an
alternative to incarceration, "nursing home", "rest home", "boarding house",
"rooming house", "lodging house", "residential treatment home/center", "special
care home" or any other such similar building or use of a building.
      (57)    HOME OCCUPATION. A business enterprise or profession entirely
within a dwelling and carried on by the inhabitants there, and no others, which
use is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling for dwelling
purposes and does not change the character thereof.
      (58)    HOTEL. A building in which lodging is provided and offered to the
public for compensation and which is designed primarily for use by transient
guests.
      (59)    IMPROVEMENTS. Street and right-of-way pavements, curbs and
gutters, pedestrian walks, street signs, sanitary and storm sewers or water
mains and other appropriate items.
      (60)    INDOOR RECREATION. An indoor facility for any number of uses such
as game courts, exercise equipment, exercise and/or dance floor area, pools,
locker rooms, spa, whirlpool or hot tub, and which may include an accessory
retail shop for the sale of related equipment.
      (61)    JUNK YARD. Any land used for abandonment, storage, keeping,
collecting or bailing paper, rags, scrap metals, other scrap or discarded
materials, or for abandonment, demolition, dismantling storage, or salvaging of
automobiles or vehicles not in running condition, machinery or parts thereof
shall be deemed a junk yard.
      (62)    LAND DEVELOPMENT. The improvement of any land, whether or not
platted or subdivided, by the addition of roadways, utilities, commercial or
industrial buildings or dwellings, whether or not individual dwelling units are
privately owned.
      (63)    LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS. A business that
provides home-type washing, drying, and/or ironing machines for use by
customers on the premises, or serves as a drop-off for dry cleaning or laundry
and where dry cleaning may occur on the premises.
      (64)    LOADING AND UNLOADING SPACE. A space within the main building or
on the same lot, parcel or tract providing for the standing, loading or
unloading of trucks and/or semi-trailers.
      (65)    LOCATION MAP. A drawing located on the plan which sets forth, by
dimensions, the relationship of the proposed subdivision or use to other nearby
developments, landmarks and community facilities and services in the County and
adjacent communities, in order to better locate and orient the area in
question.
      (66)    LOT. A parcel of land of sufficient size to meet minimum zoning
requirements for use, coverage and area and to provide such yards and other
open spaces as are required by this Planning and Zoning Code. A lot shall have
frontage on an improved public or private street and may consist of the
following: See also Parcel.
         A.    A single lot of record;
         B.    A portion of a lot of record;
         C.    A combination of complete lots of record, of complete lots of
record and portions of lots of record, or portions of lots of record.
      (67)    LOT AREA. The computed area contained within the lot lines. Where
the lot has been conveyed to the center of the street, the area of the lot
between such centerline and the established street right-of-way shall not be
included as part of the area for the purpose of these regulations.
      (68)    LOT, COVERAGE. The ratio of enclosed ground floor area of all
buildings on a lot to the horizontally projected area of the lot, expressed as
a percentage.
      (69)    LOT, DEPTH. The distance between mid-points of straight lines
connecting the foremost points of the side lot lines in the front and the
rearmost points of the side lot lines in the rear.
      (70)    LOT, FRONTAGE. The lot line which adjoins the street right-of-
way. For the purpose of determining yard requirements on corner lots and
through lots, all sides of a lot adjacent to streets shall be considered
frontage.
      (71)    LOT LINE. The property lines defining the limits of the lot.
         A.    FRONT LOT LINE. The line separating an interior lot from the
street right-of-way on which the lot fronts; or, on a corner lot, the shorter
of the two (2) lot lines abutting streets, except that when the lot lines
abutting streets are of equal lengths, the front lot line shall be the lot line
abutting the street having the longest frontage within the same block.
         B.    REAR LOT LINE. The line which is opposite and most distant from
the front line, or, on an irregular or triangular lot, a line at least ten (10)
feet long entirely within the lot, parallel to and furthest distance from the
front lot line.
         C.    SIDE LOT LINE. A line connecting a front lot line with a rear
lot line.
      (72)    LOT, NONCONFORMING. A parcel which lawfully existed at the time
this Planning and Zoning Code or an amendment hereto became effective but which
does not now conform to the regulations applicable in the zone district in
which it is located.
      (73)    LOT TYPES.
         A.    CORNER LOT. A lot situated at the junction of and abutting upon
two (2) intersecting streets.
         B.    LOT, INTERIOR. A lot other than a corner lot with only one
frontage on a street.
         C.    THROUGH LOT. An interior lot having frontage upon two (2)
parallel or nearly parallel streets.
Figure 2 - Lot Types
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/37720bd21ee1d45ff75e71d0803f8117e8de59b7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2192_6316x3536.jpg]
      
      (74)    LOT WIDTH. The distance between the side lot lines measured at
the required front building setback line, or in the case of an irregularly
shaped lot, the front building line.
      (75)    MOTEL. See Hotel.
      (76)    MONUMENTS. Permanent concrete or iron markers used to establish
definitely all lines of the plat of a subdivision, including all lot corners,
boundary line corners and points of change in street alignment.
      (77)    NONCONFORMING SITE CONDITION. Any structure lawfully existing on
the effective date of this Planning and Zoning Code or any amendment thereto,
which on such effective date, does not conform to the yard regulations, parking
requirements, sign regulations, landscaping and screening requirements or other
development standards of the district in which it is situated.
      (78)    OPEN SPACE. Any parcel or areas of land essentially unimproved
and set aside, dedicated, designated or reserved for public or private use and
enjoyment, or for the use and enjoyment of owners and occupants of land
adjoining or neighboring such open space.
      (79)    OUTDOOR DISPLAY. An outside area devoted to the viewing from the
street a representative sample or retail goods and merchandise for sale, rent,
or lease from the premises.
      (80)    OUTDOOR RECREATION FACILITY. A facility for recreational uses
that are conducted primarily outdoors as opposed to an indoor recreational
facility.
      (81)    OUTDOOR STORAGE. The keeping, in an area outside of a building,
of any goods, material, merchandise, or vehicles in the same place for more
than twenty-four (24) hours, except for merchandise placed in an area for
outdoor display.
      (82)    OWNER. Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others,
has legal title to any land or structure, with or without accompanying actual
possession thereof; or has charge, care or control of any land or structure as
owner or agent of the owner; or is executor, administrator, conservator,
trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. Any such person thus
representing the actual owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of
this Planning and Zoning Code and of rules and regulations adopted pursuant
thereof, to the same extent as if he were the owner.
      (83)    PARCEL. A lot or tract, or contiguous groups or portions of such
lots and/or tracts shown on the assessor's roll of Jefferson County, or a
contiguous area of land under legal control of any one person, partnership,
firm, corporation, syndicate, agency or institution. See also Lot.
      (84)    PARKING. Parking of motor vehicles off the public rights of way.
      (85)    PARKING LOT. A lot, parcel or tract designed, built or used for
the parking of motor vehicles.
      (86)    PARKING, OFF-STREET. Parking of motor vehicles off the public
rights of way.
      (87)    PARKING SPACE. An off-street space available for the parking of
one motor vehicle with room for opening the doors on both sides together with
properly related access to a public street or alley and maneuvering room.
      (88)    PATIO. An outdoor living area usually hard surfaced and
frequently fenced or covered.
      (89)    PERMANENT. Continuing or enduring in the same state, place or the
like, without marked change.
      (90)    PLACE OF WORSHIP. A building, structure, or other indoor or
outdoor facility used for public worship. The word "place of worship" includes
the words "church," "chapel," "synagogue" and "temple" and their uses and
activities that are customarily related.
      (91)    PLAN. A drawing of a proposed design or a proposed work to be
performed on land.
      (92)    PLAT. A map of a lot, tract or subdivision on which the lines of
each element are shown by accurate distances and bearings.
      (93)    PORCH. A roofed or unroofed unenclosed portion of a building
projecting from the front, side or rear wall of the building.
      (94)    PREMISES. A general term meaning part of or all of any lot,
parcel or tract or part of all of any building or structure or group of
buildings or structures located thereon.
      (95)    PROJECT BOUNDARY. The boundary defining the tract of land which
are included in a proposed development to meet the minimum required project
area for a planned residential development or multifamily development. The term
"project boundary" shall also mean "development boundary".
      (96)    PROPERTY LINE. The boundary of any lot, parcel or tract as the
same is described in the conveyance to the owner, and shall not include the
streets or alleys upon which the lot, parcel or tract may abut.
      (97)    PUBLIC HEARING. A meeting called by a public body for which
public notice has been given and which is held in a place in which the general
public may attend to hear issues and express their opinions.
      (98)    PUBLIC SAFETY FACILITY. Police, fire, emergency medical, and
similar essential safety services owned and operated by the Village, County, or
other public agency and which are needed and thus located to provide adequate
distribution of such facilities to primarily meet the emergency and safety
needs of the residents of the Village of Mingo Junction.
      (99)    PUBLIC SERVICE MAINTENANCE FACILITY. Any structure owned and
operated by a governmental entity that is related to the erection,
construction, alteration, operation or maintenance of buildings, power plants
or substations, water treatment plants or pumping stations, sewage disposal or
pumping plants and other similar public service structures utilized in the
finishing or maintenance of the following public services, roads and streets,
electricity, gas, rail transport, communication, public water and public sewer.
      (100)    PUBLIC UTILITY STRUCTURE. A structure providing for public
services such as power plants or substations, water treatment plants or pumping
stations, sewage disposal or pumping plants, and other similar public service
structures operated by a public utility, by a public or private railroad, or by
a municipal or other governmental agency.
      (101)    RETAIL ESTABLISHMENT. An establishment engaged in the selling of
goods or merchandise to the general public for personal or household
consumption, which is open to the general public during regular business hours
and which has display areas that are designed and laid out to attract the
general public. In determining a use to be a retail use, the Zoning Inspector
or Planning and Zoning Commission may consider the proportion of display area
vs. storage area and the proportion of the building facade devoted to display
windows.
      (102)    RIGHT OF WAY, PUBLIC. A strip of land taken, dedicated, or
otherwise recorded as an irrevocable right-of-passage for uses as a public way.
In addition to the roadway, it normally incorporates the curbs, lawn strips,
sidewalks, water and sewer lines, lighting and drainage facilities, and may
include special features (required by the topography or treatment) such as
grade separation, landscaped areas, viaducts and bridges.
      (103)    SETBACK. The minimum distance from the right of way line to the
building line measured along a line perpendicular to the right of way line or
property line or, in the case of an arc street measured along the radius of
such an arc.
      (104)    SIDEWALK. That portion of the road right-of-way outside the
roadway that is improved exclusively for pedestrian use.
      (105)    SIGN. Any identification, description, illustration or device
which is affixed to or integrated into a building, structure or land, or
otherwise situated on a lot and which is intended to direct or attract
attention to, or announce or promote a product, place, activity, person,
institution or business by means of letters, words, designs, colors, symbols,
flags, banners, fixtures, images or illuminations.
      (106)    SIMILAR USE. A use not specifically listed in any of the
schedules of permitted uses of any district, but which may be found similar and
added to a schedule for a particular district.
      (107)    STREET. A way for vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic, whether
designated as a street highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, road,
avenue, boulevard, mall or otherwise.
         A.    ALLEY. A minor street used primarily for vehicular service
access to the back or side of properties abutting on another street.
         B.    COLLECTOR STREET. A thoroughfare, whether in a residential,
industrial, commercial or other type of development, which primarily carries
traffic from local streets to major streets, including the principal entrance
and circulation routes in residential subdivisions.
         C.    CUL-DE-SAC. A local street of relatively short length with one
end open to traffic and the other end permanently terminated in a vehicular
turn around.
         D.    DEAD-END STREET. A street temporarily having one end closed to
traffic and intended to be extended or continued in the future.
         E.    FREEWAY. A divided high-volume traffic way for through traffic
and for the connection of the major districts of the City and having limited
access and grade-separated intersections.
         F.    HALF STREET. A public street having only one-half (½) of the
right-of-way width legally required by this Planning and Zoning Code.
         G.    LOCAL STREET OR MINOR STREET. A street used primarily for access
to abutting lots.
         H.    MAJOR STREET. A thoroughfare or highway, which is primarily for
moving fast or heavy traffic between large or intensively developed areas and/
or is included in the highway plan.
         I.    PRIVATE STREET. A street that is owned and maintained by a
person, corporation, association, or other legal entity other than the Village
of Mingo Junction.
         J.    SERVICE STREET. A driveway or privately owned street, which
services a commercial or industrial development.
      (108)    STREET, CENTER LINE OF. The true center line of a dedicated
public right of way as determined by the County Commissioner of Roads or the
Village Engineer. Where such public right of way is curved, offset, angular or
any other questions arise, the Commissioner of Roads and/or the Village
Engineer shall determine the alignment of the center line.
      (109)    STREET RIGHT OF WAY, LINE. The dividing line between a lot and
the right-of-way of a street.
      (110)    STRUCTURAL ALTERATION. Any change in the supporting members of a
building, such as bearing walls, columns, beams or girders.
      (111)    STRUCTURE. Anything constructed or erected, and having a
permanent location on the ground, including but not limited to fences, decks,
pools, gazebos and sheds.
         A.    STRUCTURE, NONCONFORMING. A structure, or portion thereof
lawfully existing at the time this Planning and Zoning Code or any amendment
hereto became effective, that does not conform to all regulations applicable in
the zone district in which it is located.
         B.    STRUCTURE, PERMITTED. A structure meeting all the requirements
established by these zoning regulations for the district in which structure is
located.
      (112)   SUBDIVISION. A division of any parcel of land (shown as a unit or
as contiguous units in the current records of the County Recorder) into two (2)
or more lots, parcels, sites, or other divisions of land, any one of which is
five (5) acres or less, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of
transfer of ownership. Subdivision also includes the improvement of one or more
parcels of land for residential or nonresidential purposes, involving the
division or allocation of land for the opening, widening or extension of any
street, for open space, or for easement for the extension and maintenance of
sewers, drainage, water supply, or other public facilities.
      (113)    SUBDIVIDER. Any landowner who undertakes the subdivision of
land.
      (114)    SURVEYOR. A person registered to practice surveying as defined
in O.R.C. 4733.01.
      (115)    SWIMMING POOL. An outdoor structure capable of containing an
excess of one and one half (1 ½) feet of water at its deepest point and having
more than 100 square feet of water surface.
      (116)    USE. The purpose for which land, a building or structure is
arranged, designed intended, maintained or occupied, or any occupation,
activity or operation carried on in a building or structure or on land.
         A.    USE, ACCESSORY. A subordinate use which is located on the same
lot as the principal use and is customarily incidental to the principal
building or to the principal use of the parcel.
         B.    USE, CONDITIONAL. A use permitted in a district, other than a
principal use permitted by right, which is allowed only under certain
conditions as set forth in Chapter
1161, and which requires a conditional use permit and approval of the Planning
and Zoning Commission in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth
in Chapter
1111.
         C.    USE, NONCONFORMING. A use which lawfully existed at the time
this Planning and Zoning Code or an amendment hereto became effective and which
does not now conform with the use regulations applicable in the zone district
in which it is located.
         D.    USE, PERMITTED. Any use allowed in a zoning district and subject
to the restrictions applicable to that zoning district.
         E.    USE, PRINCIPAL. The primary or main use or activity of a
building or lot.
      (117)    VARIANCE. A modification of the strict terms of this Planning
and Zoning Code where such modification will not be contrary to the public
interest or the intent and purpose of this Planning and Zoning Code, and where,
owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of the actions
of the applicant, a literal enforcement of this Planning and Zoning Code would
result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship.
      (118)    WAITING SPACE. An unenclosed area outside the public right of
way that accommodates customers in vehicles being served or waiting served at a
drive-thru facility, car wash, gasoline station, or other similar use. Also
known as a stacking space.
      (119)    WAREHOUSE. A building used primarily for the storage of goods
and materials which are intended for future sale or use but specifically
excluding commercial multi-unit storage facilities.
      (120)    WHOLESALE. Establishments that sell commodities in large
quantities or by the piece to retailers, jobbers, other wholesale
establishments, or manufacturing establishments. These commodities are for
further resale, for use in the fabrication of a product, or for use by a
business service.
      (121)    WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATION FACILITY. See Chapter
1169.
      (122)    YARD. An open space on the same lot with a principal building
that lies between the principal building and the nearest lot line, unoccupied
and unobstructed by any portion of the structure from the ground upward, except
for accessory uses, structures or buildings as expressly permitted in this
Planning and Zoning Code.
         A.    YARD, FRONT. A yard extending the full width of the lot and
situated between the street line and the front line of a building.
         B.    YARD, REAR. A yard extending the full width of the lot and
situated between the rear line of the lot and the rear wall of the building.
         C.    YARD, SIDE. A yard between the principal building and the side
lot line and extending from the front yard to the rear yard on an interior lot.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/37720bd21ee1d45ff75e71d0803f8117e8de59b7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2195_5284x4708.jpg]
      (123)    YARD, REQUIRED. The space between a lot line and a setback line
for a building, parking area or use that is the minimum area required to comply
with the regulations of the district in which the lot is located except as
expressly permitted in this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (124)    ZONING MAP. An accurate map depicting the Village of Mingo
Junction, Ohio, and indicating the boundaries of the zoning districts
established by this Planning and Zoning Code.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1105
Administrative Powers and Duties
1105.01   Purpose.
1105.02   Zoning Inspector.
1105.03   Planning and Zoning Commission. (Repealed)
1105.04   Board of Zoning Appeals.
1105.05   Village Council.
1105.06   Planning and Zoning Commission.
1105.01 PURPOSE.
   This Chapter sets forth the powers and duties of the Zoning Inspector,
Planning and Zoning Commission, Board of Zoning Appeals and Village Council,
with respect to the administration of the provisions of this Planning and
Zoning Code.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1105.02 ZONING INSPECTOR.
   (a)   Establishment and Qualifications. The Zoning Inspector, together with
such assistants as deemed necessary, shall act as the administrative officer
for the purpose of effecting the proper administration of this Planning and
Zoning Code.
      (1)   Appointment. The Zoning Inspector shall be appointed by the Mayor
and approved by Council.
      (2)   Compensation. Suitable compensation as directed by Council shall be
made for his or her services.
      (3)   Dismissal. Dismissal of the Zoning Inspector shall be at the
discretion of Council and only for reasons of dereliction of duty, dishonesty
or malfeasance.
   (b)   Powers and Duties. The Zoning Inspector shall have the following
powers and
duties:
      (1)   Enforce the provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code and
interpret the meaning and application of its provisions.
      (2)    Accept, review for completeness, and respond to questions
regarding those applications which the Zoning Inspector is authorized to review
by the provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code, including amendments to
this Planning and Zoning Code, development plans, conditional uses, variances,
appeals, preliminary plats, and final plats.
      (3)    Review and act on development plans.
      (4)   Issue zoning permits and certificates of zoning occupancy as
provided by this Planning and Zoning Code and keep a record of same with a
notation of any special conditions involved.
      (5)    Coordinate the Village's administrative review of rezoning,
conditional use and subdivision plat applications.
      (6)    To permit, in collaboration with the Village Mayor and Solicitor,
the remodeling or expansion of a nonconforming use or the substitution of one
nonconforming use with another nonconforming use in conformance with the
provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (7)    Maintain any records required by this Planning and Zoning Code
including inspection documents, and records of all variances, amendments,
conditional uses, and similar use determinations.
      (8)    Make such records available for the use of Council, the Planning
and Zoning Commission, the Board of Zoning Appeals and the public.
      (9)    Conduct or cause the inspection of buildings and uses of land to
determine compliance with this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (10)   Determine the existence of any violations of this Planning and
Zoning Code and cause such notifications, revocation notices, stop orders or
tickets to be issued, or initiate such other administrative or legal action as
needed, to address such violations.
      (11)   Maintain in current status the "Official Zoning District Map" of
the Village of Mingo Junction. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1105.03 PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
1105.03 was repealed by implication by Ordinance 2024-2. See Section
1105.06 for relevant provisions.)
1105.04 BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   (a)   Establishment. A Board of Zoning Appeals is hereby created to act as a
board of judicial appeal as provided in Ohio R.C. 713.11.
   (b)   Organization. The Board shall consist of five (5) members appointed by
the Mayor and approved by Council. In no case shall a member of the Planning
and Zoning Commission or Council concurrently serve on the Board. Each member
shall be appointed for a period of four (4) years.
   (c)   Replacement of Member. In the event of the death or resignation of a
member, the Mayor, with the approval of Council, shall make the appointment for
the duration of the unexpired portion of the term of the member. The term of
the Council member shall expire on December 31 of the year in which such member
is appointed. Each member shall serve until his or her successor is appointed
and qualified.
   (d)    Appointment of Chairperson and Clerk. The Board of Zoning Appeals
shall elect a chairperson from its membership and shall appoint a clerk.
   (e)    Meetings. Meetings shall be at the call of the chairperson or any
other two (2) members, and at such other regular times as it may determine.
   (f)    Quorum. A quorum shall consist of three (3) members at all its
meetings, and a concurring vote of a majority of those present shall be
necessary to effect an order.
   (g)    Powers and Duties. For the purposes of this Planning and Zoning Code,
the Board of Zoning Appeals shall have the following powers and duties:
      (1)   To authorize such variances from the terms of this Planning and
Zoning Code where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of this
Planning and Zoning Code will result in extreme practical difficulty, provided
that such variances will serve the public interest, observe the spirit of this
Planning and Zoning Code and secure substantial justice to all parties
concerned.
      (2)    To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is an error
in any decision made by the Zoning Inspector or his or her designee regarding a
numerical requirement in this Planning and Zoning Code, in the carrying out or
enforcement of any provision of this Planning and Zoning Code, or in the
interpretation of the Official Zoning District Map.
      (3)    To hear and decide upon applications regarding the alteration,
remodeling or reconstruction of a nonconforming use or the substitution of a
nonconforming use with another nonconforming use when such application has been
forwarded to the Board from the Zoning Inspector, Village Solicitor and Mayor.
      (4)    To attach such requirements, conditions, and/or reviews to actions
on applications presented to it as it feels necessary to carry out the intent
and purposes of this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (5)    To present to the Planning and Zoning Commission such suggestions
for amendments to this Planning and Zoning Code as it deems necessary to
clarify the intent and purpose or improve any Section on which the Board of
Zoning Appeals has occasion to rule.
      (6)    To resolve any disputes with respect to the precise location of a
