zoning district boundary, using, where applicable, the standards and criteria
of Section
1131.04.
      (7)    To request information or opinions from any administrative officer
of the Municipality or any other person or persons considered expert on the
matter before the Board and to make such studies and surveys as are required to
carry out the duties herein outlined.
      (8)    The chairperson or acting chairperson may administer oaths and
compel the attendance of witnesses in all matters within the purview of this
Planning and Zoning Code.
      (9)    To adopt rules or bylaws for the holding of regular and special
meetings, for the transaction and disposition of its business and the exercise
of its powers. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1105.05 VILLAGE COUNCIL.
   For the purposes of this Planning and Zoning Code, the powers and duties of
Village Council shall be limited to the following:
   (a)    Holding public hearings and voting upon proposed amendments to this
Planning and Zoning Code.
   (b)    Investigating and proposing on its own initiative such amendments to
the Planning and Zoning Code as it may deem consistent with the purposes of
this Planning and Zoning Code and which further the public health, safety, and
general welfare of the Village of Mingo Junction.
   (c)    Review and act on all preliminary plats for major subdivisions,
including the financial guarantees for required improvements.
   (d)   To attach such requirements, conditions, and/or reviews to actions on
applications presented to it as it feels necessary to carry out the intent and
purposes of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (e)    To request information or opinions from any administrative officer of
the Municipality or any other person or persons considered expert on the matter
before the Board and to make such studies and surveys as are required to carry
out the duties herein outlined.
   (f)    Appropriate sufficient funds for the uses of the Planning and Zoning
Commission and the Board of Zoning Appeals to carry out the provisions of this
Planning and Zoning Code.
   (g)    Establish by Ordinance a schedule of fees.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1105.06 PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   (a)   The Village Planning and Zoning Commission is hereby eliminated.
   (b)   The Village Zoning Commission is hereby eliminated.
   (c)   The Village of Mingo Junction Planning and Zoning Commission (PZ
Commission) is hereby established.
   (d)   The PZ Commission shall consist of five (5) members consisting of the
Mayor, one (1) member of the legislative authority to be elected thereby for
the remainder of the individual’s terms as such members of the legislative
authority, two (2) citizens of the Village and one (1) public member to be
appointed by the Mayor.
   (e)   Members of the PZ Commission shall be appointed by the Mayor for terms
of six (6) years each, except that the term of one (1) of the members of the
first commission shall be for four (4) years and one (1) for two (2) years. All
PZ Commission members shall serve without compensation.
   (f)   The public members appointed under this section need not be residents
of the municipal corporation but shall be a resident of Jefferson County.
   (g)   The PZ Commission shall have all the powers conferred by the Ohio
Revised Code upon planning commission and upon a zoning commission, including
but not limited to Section 735.15 of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (h)   The PZ Commission shall have all the powers conferred upon the former
Planning and Zoning Commission and the former Zoning Commission by the codified
ordinances as well as uncodified ordinances and resolutions previously enacted
by Council and as amended by Council in the future.
(Ord. 2024-2. Passed 2-27-24.)
CHAPTER 1107
Procedures for Zoning Permits and Certificates of Zoning Occupancy
1107.01   Purpose.
1107.02   Zoning permit required.
1107.03   Filing an application.
1107.04   Application submission requirements.
1107.05   Review by Zoning Inspector.
1107.06   Action by the Planning and Zoning Commission.
1107.07   Simultaneous plat approval.
1107.08   Equivalency provision.
1107.09   Significance of an approved development plans; plan revisions.
1107.10   Expiration of zoning permit.
1107.11   Certificate of zoning occupancy.
1107.12   Records.
1107.13   Schedule of fees.
1107.01 PURPOSE.
   The administrative provisions of this Chapter establish the procedures for
reviewing and acting upon applications for zoning permits, including
development plans, and certificates of zoning occupancy, in order to accomplish
the purposes for which this Planning and Zoning Code is adopted. (Ord. 2002-2.
Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.02 ZONING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall commence any excavation, or the construction of any building
or other structure, including accessory structures: store building materials on
the building site; construct parking lots; commence the moving, structural
alterations, conversions, extension, enlargements, alterations or repairs,
except usual repairs not requiring permits under this Planning and Zoning Code
or any other County resolution or Municipal ordinance, of any structure
including accessory structures, fences or walls, until the Zoning Inspector has
issued a zoning permit for such work. A zoning permit shall be issued only when
the plans for the proposed use, building or structure comply with the
regulations set forth in this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (a)    A zoning permit shall be issued for the following when the required
steps are accomplished:
      (1)   Development Plans. When a development plan has been reviewed and
approved by the Zoning Inspector according to the procedures set forth in this
Chapter.
      (2)   Conditional Uses. When an application for a conditional use has
been reviewed and approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission according to
the procedures set forth in Chapter
1111.
      (3)   Appeal Requests. When an application for an appeal has been
reviewed and approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission or Board of Zoning
Appeals, according to the procedures set forth in Chapter
1113.
      (4)   Variance Requests. When an application for which a variance from a
requirement of this Planning and Zoning Code has been reviewed and approved by
the Board of Zoning Appeals, according to the procedures set forth in Chapter
1115.
      (5)   Similar Uses. When an application for any building or use not
specifically listed in this Planning and Zoning Code as a permitted or
conditional use has been reviewed and approved by the Planning and Zoning
Commission according to the procedures set forth in Section
1111.10.
   (b)   Zoning Permit Not Required. A zoning permit shall not be required for
the reoccupancy of an existing structure when a development plan has been
previously approved and there is no change in the bulk of the structure and in
the number of parking spaces required. However, a certificate of zoning
occupancy shall be required prior to re-occupancy of such structure.
   (c)   Application Forms. Applications for zoning permits shall be available
in the office of the Zoning Inspector. A completed application form accompanied
by all other applicable submission requirements shall be submitted to the
Zoning Inspector.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.03 FILING AN APPLICATION.
   Applications for a zoning permit shall be filed with the Zoning Inspector by
the property owner, a designated agent or a lessee with written consent of the
property owner.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.04 APPLICATION SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS.
   An application for a zoning permit shall include a plan for the entire area
of the proposed project, including information about any future phases of the
project, which may be planned. A sufficient number of copies of the application
and any supplementary documents as determined by the Zoning Inspector, along
with the application fee, shall be submitted to the Zoning Inspector. The
application shall include the maps, plans, designs and supplementary documents
itemized below, unless specific items are determined by the Zoning Inspector to
be inapplicable or unnecessary and are waived in writing by the Zoning
Inspector.
   (a)    Zoning permits for single-family and two-family dwellings or use
accessory thereto. An application for the construction or alteration of a
single-family dwelling, two-family dwelling or use accessory thereto shall be
prepared by a qualified professional and shall be drawn to an appropriate
scale. Such applications shall include the items set forth below and may be
submitted simultaneously with an application for a building permit.
      (1)   An accurate, legal description prepared or certified by a
registered surveyor of the state.
      (2)    An area map showing the relationship of the site to existing
development and including existing property lines, buildings, parking areas,
access drives, easements, utilities and street rights-of-way of the subject
property and property within 300 feet of the site, and zoning district
boundaries.
      (3)    Site plan of the proposed development including:
         A.    The actual shape, proportion and dimensions of the parcel to be
built upon.
         B.    Location of all public rights-of-way and private streets.
         C.    Use and location of existing and proposed buildings and
structures, including fences, walls, signs, and lighting.
         D.    Dimensions of all buildings, setbacks, parking areas, drives and
walkways.
         E.    Height of existing and proposed buildings and structures.
   (b)    Other Applications for Zoning Permits. In addition to the submission
requirements set forth in subsection (a) above, all other applications for
zoning permits shall also include the following additional information:
      (1)   Additional information on the site plan including:
         A.    Location and configuration of vehicular circulation including
off-street parking and loading areas: the arrangement of internal and in-out
traffic movement including access roads and drives; lane and other pavement
markings to direct and control parking and circulation: the location of signs
related to parking and traffic control and proposed pedestrian circulation.
         B.    Location and layout of all proposed and existing outdoor storage
areas including storage of waste materials and location of trash receptacles.
         C.    In addition to the items identified in this Section, the
following items shall also be required for planned residential developments:
            1.    Location, size and character of any open space.
            2.    Location of lot lines for single-family dwellings and
building envelopes for two-family and multifamily dwellings.
      (2)    Topographic maps showing existing and proposed grading contours
and major vegetation features including existing trees with a caliper of four
(4) or more inches, wooded areas, wetlands and other environmental features.
      (3)    Sanitary sewers, water and other utilities including fire
hydrants, as required and proposed drainage and storm water management.
      (4)    Proposed landscaping and screening plans indicating the location
and nature of existing and proposed vegetation, landscaping and screening
elements.
      (5)    Summary table showing total acres of the proposed development, the
number of acres devoted to each type of use including streets and open space,
and the number of proposed dwelling units by type, building coverage, pavement
coverage and acreage devoted to open space.
      (6)    Subdivision plat, if appropriate.
      (7)    The substance of covenants, grants of easements, or other
restrictions which will be imposed upon the use of the land, buildings, and
structures, including proposed easements or grants for public utilities.
      (8)    Other information necessary for the evaluation of the application
as deemed necessary by the Zoning Inspector.
   (c)    An application shall be required for each phase of development and
shall include:
      (1)   Proposed phases if the project is to be developed in stages
indicating the phases during which any common facilities are anticipated to be
constructed.
      (2)    If a phased development includes improvements that are designed to
relate to, benefit, or be used by the entire development, then for the first
phase the applicant shall submit a proposed schedule for completion of such
improvements. The schedule shall relate completion of such improvements to
completion of one or more phases of the entire development.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.05 REVIEW BY ZONING INSPECTOR.
   Applications for a zoning permit shall be reviewed and distributed according
to the following procedures.
   (a)    Review for Completeness. The Zoning Inspector shall review the
submitted application for completeness and compliance with the applicable
submission requirements within five (5) working days of receipt of such
application. If the application is deemed insufficient, the Zoning Inspector
shall notify the applicant of the deficiencies and place the application on
hold until complete. When the application is determined complete and the
application fee has been paid, the Zoning Inspector shall officially accept the
application for consideration.
   (b)    Review Criteria. The Zoning Inspector shall review an application to
determine if such application complies with the review criteria set forth
below. In order to approve an application the Zoning Inspector shall determine
that such application:
      (1)    Complies with the requirements of this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (2)    For planned residential developments, multifamily and
nonresidential developments:
         A.    The appropriate use and value of property within and adjacent to
the area will be safeguarded.
         B.    The development will preserve and be sensitive to the natural
characteristics of the site in a manner that complies with the applicable
regulations set forth in this Planning and Zoning Code.
         C.    The plan is consistent with any plan for the orderly development
of the Village.
         D.    Adequate provision is made for safe and efficient pedestrian and
vehicular circulation within the site and to adjacent property.
         E.    The development will have adequate public service and open
spaces.
         F.    The development will provide adequate lighting for safe and
convenient use of the streets. walkways, driveways, and parking areas.
         G.    The proposed signs:
            1.   Adequately identify the use; and
            2.   Are located so as to maintain safe and orderly pedestrian and
vehicular circulation.
         H.    Adequate provision is made for storm drainage within and through
the site so as to maintain, as far as practicable, usual and normal swells,
water courses and drainage areas, and shall comply with the applicable
regulations in this Planning and Zoning Code and any other design criteria
established by the Village or any other governmental entity which may have
jurisdiction over such matters.
         I.    If the project is to be carried out in progressive stages, each
stage shall be so planned that the foregoing conditions are complied with at
the completion of each stage.
   (c)    Action by the Zoning Inspector. The Zoning Inspector shall within
thirty (30) days of the application being deemed complete:
      (1)   Approve the development plan as submitted; or
      (2)    Approve the plan subject to specific conditions not included in
the plan as submitted, such as, but not limited to, improvements to the yard
layout, open space arrangement, on-site control of access to streets or such
features as fences, walls and plantings to further protect and improve the
proposed and surrounding developments; or
      (3)    Deny the development plan when the application does not
demonstrate that the required standards have been met; or
      (4)    Forward all applications for planned residential developments and
conditional uses to the Planning and Zoning Commission for review; or
      (5)   Forward applications for permitted uses in business and industrial
districts to the Planning and Zoning Commission when the Zoning Inspector
determines that because of the nature of the proposed application or its size
and complexity the proposal may not comply with the provisions of Section
1107.05.
   (d)   If the Zoning Inspector fails to act on the application within thirty
(30) days from the date the application was determined complete, or an extended
period as may be agreed upon, then the applicant may deem the application
denied.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.06 ACTION BY THE PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   If the Zoning Inspector forwards the application to the Planning and Zoning
Commission, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall review the application in
accordance with the review criteria set forth in subsection
1107.05(b).
   (a)    The Planning and Zoning Commission shall either:
      (1)   Approve the application as submitted; or
      (2)    Approve the application subject to specific conditions not
included in the plan as submitted, such as, but not limited to, improvements to
the yard layout, open space arrangement, on-site control of access to streets
or such features as fences, walls and plantings to further protect and improve
the proposed and surrounding developments; or
      (3)    Table the application for the next scheduled Planning and Zoning
Commission meeting, demonstrating to the applicant an acceptable alternative
plan: or
      (4)    Deny the application when the application does not demonstrate
that the required standards have been met.
   (b)   If the Planning and Zoning Commission fails to act on the application
within ninety (90) days from the date the application was determined complete,
or an extended period as may be agreed upon, then the applicant may deem the
development plan denied.
   (c)   In their review of an application, the Planning and Zoning Commission
may request that the applicant supply additional information deemed necessary
to adequately review and evaluate the proposed development.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.07 SIMULTANEOUS PLAT APPROVAL.
   If the proposed development includes the subdivision of land, the
development shall be subject to the requirements of the plat approval process
in accordance with Chapter
1121. An application for a zoning permit and subdivision plat approval may
proceed simultaneously at the discretion of the Zoning Inspector. (Ord. 2002-2.
Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.08 EQUIVALENCY PROVISION.
   In reviewing the application, the Zoning Inspector and/or Planning and
Zoning Commission may find that a development plan either adheres or is
equivalent to the requirements of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (a)    Elements of a development plan may be determined to be equivalent to
a requirement if:
      (1)   The proposed development plan substantially complies with all
specific requirements and with the purposes, intent and basic objectives of the
zoning district;
      (2)    Through imaginative and skillful design in the arrangement of
buildings, open space, streets, access drives and other features, as disclosed
by the application, the proposal results in a development of equivalent or
higher quality than that which could be achieved through strict application of
such standards and requirements: and
      (3)    The development, as proposed, shall have no adverse impact upon
the surrounding properties or upon the health, safety or general welfare of the
community.
   (b)   It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to demonstrate that
the provisions of this Section have been satisfied. When evaluating the
application with respect to this Section, the Zoning Inspector and/or Planning
and Zoning Commission may make a finding of equivalency in writing which shall
explain how and why the proposal has satisfied the above criteria. When making
such finding, the Zoning Inspector and/or Planning and Zoning Commission may
approve the proposed application, including waivers from the numerical
standards herein, as if the application were in strict compliance with the
standards and requirements in this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.09 SIGNIFICANCE OF AN APPROVED DEVELOPMENT PLANS; PLAN REVISIONS.
   An approved development plan shall become for the proposed development a
binding commitment of the specific elements approved for development.
   (a)    The approved development plan may be transferred to another person,
corporation, or group of individuals or corporations prior to the issuance of a
zoning permit. A transfer shall be granted only if the new ownership entity
satisfies the administrative, financial, legal and all other performance
guarantees approved with the original development plan.
   (b)   After the approval of the development plan, the applicant shall obtain
a zoning permit prior to construction.
   (c)   All construction and development under any zoning permit shall be in
accordance with the approved plan. Any departure from such plan shall be cause
for revocation of the zoning permit.
   (d)   No certificate of zoning occupancy shall be issued unless all
facilities and improvements that are included on the approved plans are
provided.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.10 EXPIRATION OF ZONING PERMIT.
   A zoning permit shall become void at the expiration of one (1) year after
the date of issuance unless, prior thereto, construction is begun, or an
extension has been granted by the Zoning Inspector. If no construction is begun
within one (1) year of the date of the zoning permit and an extension has not
been granted, a new application and zoning permit shall be required.
Construction is deemed to have begun when all necessary excavation and piers or
footings of the structure included in the application have been completed. The
date of expiration shall be noted on the zoning permit.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.11 CERTIFICATE OF ZONING OCCUPANCY.
   (a)   Certificate of Zoning Occupancy Required. A certificate of zoning
occupancy shall be applied for and issued as follows:
      (1)   Occupancy of a Building. A certificate of zoning occupancy shall be
required before a building that has been constructed, or an existing building
that has been altered, moved, changed in use, or changed as to off-street
parking or loading requirements may be occupied. A certificate of zoning
occupancy shall only be issued after the completion of the erection or
alteration of the building or structure, or part thereof, and the proposed use
are found upon inspection to be in conformity with the provisions of this
Planning and Zoning Code and any approved development plan for the project.
      (2)    Occupancy of Land. A certificate of zoning occupancy shall be
required before occupancy of the land or where use of the land has been changed
to a use different from the prior use. A certificate of zoning occupancy shall
be issued when it is determined, upon inspection, that the use conforms to the
provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (3)    Change in Use of Nonconforming Building or Use. A certificate of
zoning occupancy shall be required whenever a nonconforming use of a building
or land is changed, and shall not be issued until the change has been approved
according to the procedures set forth in Chapter
1111.
   (b)   Applications. Applications for a certificate of zoning occupancy shall
be available in the office of the Zoning Inspector.
      (1)   Applications shall include accurate information provided by the
owner, or authorized representative, regarding the size and location of the
lot, dimensions of all yards and open space, the use of land or building
operations or processes and other pertinent infonnation as may be requested by
the Village.
      (2)   Within three (3) days after notification that a building, structure
or premises or part thereof is ready for occupancy or use, the Zoning Inspector
shall make a final inspection thereof and issue a certificate of zoning
occupancy if the land, building, structure or part thereof and the proposed use
thereof are found to conform with this Planning Zoning Code.
      (3)   If such certification is refused. the Zoning Inspector shall state
such refusal in writing, with the cause thereof and immediately mail notice of
such refusal to the applicant at the address indicated on the application.
   (c)   Certification. The certificate of zoning occupancy shall document that
the building, structure or proposed use of land, conforms to the provisions of
this Planning and Zoning Code.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.12 RECORDS.
   A permanent record of all applications submitted and permits and
certificates issued shall be kept on file in the office of the Zoning
Inspector, and copies shall be furnished on request to and at the expense of
any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in land or a building
affected by such application, permit or certificate.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1107.13 SCHEDULE OF FEES.
   Council shall by ordinance establish a schedule of fees for review of and
action on applications for zoning permits, development plans, conditional use
permits, appeals, variances, certificates of zoning occupancy, amendments,
subdivision plats and other procedures and services pertaining to the
administration and enforcement of this Planning and Zoning Code. Council shall
consider the recommendation of the Zoning Inspector with respect to actual
administrative costs, both direct and indirect. The schedule of fees shall be
available at Village Hall, and may be altered or amended only by Council. Until
all such appropriate fees, charges, and expenses have been paid in full, no
action shall be taken on any application, appeal, or administrative procedure.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1111
Conditional Use Permits and Similar Uses
1111.01   Purpose.
1111.02   Pre-application meeting encouraged.
1111.03   Submission of application.
1111.04   Conditional use permit procedures.
1111.05   Review of conditional use permit application.
1111.06   Public hearing and notice by Planning and Zoning Commission.
1111.07   Action by Planning and Zoning Commission.
1111.08   Terms and duration of conditional use permit.
1111.09   Reapplication.
1111.10   Similar uses.
1111.01 PURPOSE.
   When a proposed use is permitted in a zoning district as a conditional use,
as set forth in the district regulations, a conditional use permit is required.
An application for such permits shall be submitted and reviewed according to
the guidelines outlined in this chapter.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.02 PRE-APPLICATION MEETING ENCOURAGED.
   The applicant is encouraged to meet with the Zoning Inspector, or his or her
designee, prior to submitting an application for a conditional use permit. The
purpose of this meeting is to discuss early and informally with the applicant
the purpose and effect of these zoning regulations and the criteria and
standards contained within. However, no action shall be taken at such a meeting
and no discussions, opinion, suggestions, or recommendations of the Zoning
Inspector shall be relied upon by the applicant to indicate subsequent approval
or disapproval of the application.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.03 SUBMISSION OF APPLICATION.
   The owner, or agent thereof, of property for which such conditional use is
proposed shall file with the Zoning Inspector an application for a conditional
use permit on the form provided for such purposes, which shall be accompanied
by payment of the required fee established by Council. The application for a
conditional usc permit shall disclose all uses proposed for the development,
their location, extent and characteristics and shall include the following:
   (a)    A development plan and associated documentation when required in
Section
1107.04.
   (b)    A list of all record title holders of property immediately adjacent
to, adjoining and abutting the property on which the conditional use is
proposed, including their addresses and permanent parcel number, as shown on
the current tax duplicate in the Office of the Jefferson County Treasurer.
   (c)   A statement indicating how the negative effects of the proposed use
will be mitigated and how all the conditions for approval set forth in Chapter
1161 for the proposed use will be met.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.04 CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT PROCEDURES.
   Applications for conditional use permits shall be distributed according to
the following procedures.
   (a)   Review for Completeness. The Zoning Inspector shall review the
submitted application for completeness and compliance with the applicable
submission requirements within five (5) working days of receipt of such
application. If the application is deemed insufficient, the Zoning Inspector
shall notify the applicant of the deficiencies and place the application on
hold until complete. When the application is determined complete and the
application fee has been paid, the Zoning Inspector shall officially accept the
application for consideration.
   (b)   Transmission to the Planning and Zoning Commission. Once the
application has been deemed complete, the Zoning Inspector shall transmit the
application to the Planning and Zoning Commission for review at its next
regularly scheduled meeting which in no case shall be more than thirty (30)
days from the date the application was determined to be complete. The Planning
and Zoning Commission may distribute the application to the appropriate
administrative departments or other experts for review and comment.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.05 REVIEW OF CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT APPLICATION.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall review the proposed conditional
use, as presented on the submitted plans and specifications, to determine
whether or not the proposed use is appropriate and in keeping with the purpose
and intent of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (a)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall review the development plan
for the proposed conditional use according to the review procedures and
criteria set forth in Sections
1107.06, as applicable;
   (b)    The Planning and Zoning Commission shall review the application to
determine if the establishment and operation of the proposed conditional use
complies with the general criteria established for all conditional uses and the
specific requirements established for that particular use, as set forth in
Chapter
1161 of this Planning and Zoning Code; and
   (c)   The Planning and Zoning Commission may require the applicant to submit
such additional information as deemed necessary including the carrying out of
additional studies and the provisions of expert advice. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-
24-02.)
1111.06  PUBLIC HEARING AND NOTICE BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall hold a public hearing on the
proposed conditional use. Notice of such public hearing shall be given by first
class mail to the applicant and to the record title holders of property which
are immediately adjacent to adjoining and abutting the property on which the
use is proposed. Further notice shall be given in one (1) or more newspapers of
general circulation in the Village. All notices shall be made at least fifteen
(15) days before the date of said public hearing. All notices shall set forth
the time and place of the public hearing and the nature of the proposed
conditional use. Failure of delivery of such notice shall not invalidate action
taken on such application.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.07 ACTION BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall take one of the following actions:
   (a)   If the proposed conditional use is determined by the Planning and
Zoning Commission to be appropriate and in conformance with the review criteria
outlined in Chapter 1161, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall approve the
conditional use. As part of the approval, the Planning and Zoning Commission
may prescribe appropriate conditions, stipulations, safeguards and limitations
on the use as it may deem necessary and in conformance with the intent and
purposes of this Chapter.
   (b)    If the proposed use is found not to comply with the specifications of
this Planning and Zoning Code, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall deny
the application. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall indicate in its
minutes the reason(s) for its action.
   If the Planning and Zoning Commission fails to act within ninety (90) days
from the date the application was deemed complete, or an extended period as may
be agreed upon, then the applicant may deem the application denied.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.08 TERMS AND DURATION OF CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT.
   Following the Planning and Zoning Commission's approval of an application
for a conditional use permit, the Zoning Inspector shall issue a conditional
use permit.
   (a)    The permit shall authorize a particular conditional use on a specific
parcel for which it was approved. The permit shall be valid only for the use
and the operation of such use as specified on the permit. The breach of any
condition, safeguard or requirement shall constitute a violation of this
Planning and Zoning Code.
   (b)    An approved conditional use permit shall remain valid for a period of
twelve (12) months following the date of its approval, unless the Zoning
Inspector authorizes a longer period at the time of approval. If at the end of
that time, construction of the development has not begun then approval of such
conditional use permit shall expire and shall be of no effect unless
resubmitted and reapproved in accordance with the procedures set forth in this
Chapter. Construction is deemed to have begun when all necessary excavation and
piers or footings of one or more principal buildings included in the plan have
been completed or substantial renovation has begun.
   (c)   Any expansion, enlargement, or change in the operation of the
conditional use that involves enlarging buildings or structures, expanding
impervious surfaces including parking areas, or changing the use shall require
approval of a separate conditional use permit.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.09 REAPPLICATION.
   No re-application for a conditional use permit shall be accepted by the
Zoning Inspector until the expiration of one (1) year after the denial or
revocation, unless the re-application is revised in response to the findings
given by the Planning and Zoning Commission in its denial of the initial
application. A re-application shall comply with all the requirements of this
Chapter, including payment of the required fee.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1111.10 SIMILAR USES.
   Within each zoning district established by the Planning and Zoning Code and
any amendments thereto, uses of land or structures which are compatible with
each other are permitted in the district. To the extent that new types of uses
are created and are not addressed by this Planning and Zoning Code, this
section provides the procedure by which the Planning and Zoning Commission may
make a determination that a new use is similar to a use permitted by right or
conditionally permitted in a district.
   (a)    Determination. A proposed use may be permitted as a similar use when
the Planning and Zoning Commission determines that such proposed use is in
compliance with the following provisions:
      (1)   The proposed use is not prohibited in any other district;
      (2)    The proposed use is not listed as a permitted or conditionally
permitted building or use in any other district;
      (3)    The proposed use conforms to and is consistent with the purpose
statement of the proposed district more appropriately than in any other
district; and
      (4)   The proposed use is of the same general character as the permitted
or conditionally permitted uses in the district to which it is proposed or is
similar to a specific use permitted or conditionally permitted in that
district.
   (b)    Procedure. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall review the
proposed use according to the conditional use procedures set forth in Sections
1111.05 through
1111.06, including the requirement for a public hearing.
   (c)   Action by Planning and Zoning Commission. The Planning and Zoning
Commission shall either approve or disapprove the proposed similar use. If the
Planning and Zoning Commission approves the proposed similar use, then the
similar use shall be added to those districts that allow the principal or
conditional use that is most like the similar use.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1113
Appeals
1113.01   Appeal to the Board of Appeals or Planning and Zoning Commission.
1113.02   Initiation of appeal.
1113.03   Public hearing required.
1113.04   Notice of public hearing.
1113.05   Stay of proceedings.
1113.06   Review of appeal.
1113.07   Criteria for determining an appeal.
1113.08   Decision on application.
1113.09   Reapplication.
1113.01 APPEAL TO THE BOARD OF APPEALS OR PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   Any person deeming himself or herself to be adversely affected by a decision
of the Zoning Inspector or his or her designee or by any administrative
committee may appeal such action in accordance with the provisions set forth in
this Chapter to the Planning and Zoning Commission or the Board of Zoning
Appeals within thirty (30) days from the date of such action.
   (a)    Appeals shall be made to the Planning and Zoning Commission whenever
the decision being appealed is related to the following:
      (1)   Development plan review criteria set forth in Section
1107.05.
      (2)    Landscaping and screening requirements set forth in Sections
1137.10 and
1139.10.
      (3)   Sign regulations as set forth in Chapter
1165.
   (b)   Appeals regarding all other decisions related to this Planning and
Zoning Code shall be made to the Board of Appeals.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.02 INITIATION OF APPEAL.
   An appeal shall be submitted within thirty (30) days from the date of such
action by the Zoning Inspector, his or her designee or any administrative
committee.
   (a)   An application for an appeal shall be filed with the Zoning Inspector
on forms provided and shall contain the following:
      (1)   The applicant's name and address and the names and addresses of any
persons, firms or corporations represented by such applicant in the
application;
      (2)    The interest of the applicant and interest of the person or
persons, firm or corporation represented by the applicant, be it ownership,
legal, sales, development, operation, or other interest;
      (3)    The nature of the appeal;
      (4)   A legal description of the property for which such application is
made;
      (5)    A plat showing the dimensions of the property for which the appeal
is requested and the location of improvements with respect to property lines;
      (6)   A statement of the facts which the applicant believes justify the
appeal;
      (7)    The names and addresses of property owners within 300 feet of the
property for which the appeal is requested;
      (8)    Any other documents deemed necessary by the Zoning Inspector; and
      (9)    Payment of the application fee as established by Council.
   (b)    The Zoning Inspector shall transmit the appeal to the appropriate
body within fifteen (15) days including all papers constituting the record upon
which the action appealed from was taken and a written statement indicating the
findings of fact and the applicant's reasons for the action for which the
appeal is made.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.03 PUBLIC HEARING REQUIRED.
   A public hearing shall be required before action is taken on an appeal. When
an application for appeal has been filed in proper form and the application fee
has been paid, the Zoning Inspector shall immediately place the request upon
the calendar for public hearing before the Board of Zoning Appeals or Planning
and Zoning Commission.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.04 NOTICE OF PUBLIC HEARING.
   (a)   A notice of the public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of
general circulation in the Municipality at least fifteen (15) days before the
date of the public hearing.
   (b)   A copy of such notice shall be sent at least fifteen (15) days prior
to the public hearing by first class mail to the owners of real property lying
within 300 feet of the exterior boundaries of the property for which the appeal
is requested. The word "owner" as used in this section shall mean the title
holder of such property as disclosed by the records of the County Auditor
thirty (30) days immediately prior to the date of such hearing.
   (c)   All notices shall be made at least fifteen (15) days before the date
of said public hearing. Such notices shall give the time, date and place of the
hearing, a brief description of the appeal, and the legal description and
street address of such property. Failure of delivery of such notices shall not
invalidate action taken on such application.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.05 STAY OF PROCEEDINGS.
   An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed
from, unless the Zoning Inspector legally certifies after the notice of the
appeal has been filed, that by reason of facts stated in the permit, a stay
would, in his or her opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such
case, proceedings shall not be stayed, other than by a restraining order, which
may be granted by a court having lawful jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.06 REVIEW OF APPEAL.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals or Planning and Zoning Commission shall review
the appeal. To aid in their review, the Board or Commission may transmit the
application to the appropriate administrative departments and professional
consultants for review and comment. Any reports, comments or experts opinions
shall be compiled by the Zoning Inspector and transmitted to the
appropriate body prior to the time of review. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.07 CRITERIA FOR DETERMINING AN APPEAL.
   Before granting an appeal from actions of the Zoning Inspector, the Board of
Zoning Appeals or Planning and Zoning Commission shall find, in writing, based
upon a written record of appropriate evidence and testimony, that all of the
following conditions do in fact exist:
   (a)   The granting of the appeal will permit only those uses listed in the
zone district in which the parcel is located; and
   (b)   The action of the Zoning Inspector was arbitrary, capricious or not in
harmony with the provisions, purposes, intent and spirit of this Planning and
Zoning Code.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.08 DECISION ON APPLICATION.
   (a)   The Board of Zoning Appeals or Planning and Zoning Commission shall
take one of the following actions:
      (1)   Within its powers, the Board of Zoning Appeals or Planning and
Zoning Commission may reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, the decision being
appealed, and to that end shall have all the powers of the officers from whom
the appeal is taken, and it may direct the issuance of a permit or certificate.
      (2)    Decisions regarding an appeal shall be rendered within sixty (60)
days from receipt of the appeal. Failure of the appropriate body to render a
decision within the allotted time shall constitute denial of such appeal. Upon
mutual agreement of the Board of Zoning Appeals or the Planning and Zoning
Commission and the applicant, the time period within which the appropriate body
shall act may be extended.
   (b)    All actions of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Planning and Zoning
Commission shall be in writing and shall contain the required findings of fact
and shall include a statement setting forth those factors which the Board or
Commission considered controlling factors in reaching its decision.
   (c)    The Board or Commission shall notify the appellant in writing of its
decision.
   (d)    Any appeal granted by the Board or Commission shall not be personal
to the applicant, but shall be transferable.
   (e)    Any appeal granted shall be exercised in full within no more than one
(1) year from the date of granting such appeal after which the appeal granted
shall be null and void and the parcel shall thereafter be subject to all the
applicable regulations of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (f)    Once the appellant has received the Board or Commission's decision,
he or she may submit an application for the zoning permit that complies with
such decision. A copy of said decision shall be attached to the application.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1113.09 REAPPLICATION.
   No re-application for an appeal shall be accepted by the Zoning Inspector
until the expiration of one (1) year after the denial or revocation, unless the
re-application is revised in response to the findings given by the Planning and
Zoning Commission or Board of Zoning Appeals in its denial of the initial
application. A re-application shall comply with all the requirements of this
Chapter, including payment of the required fee.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1115
Variances
1115.01   Review by the Board of Zoning Appeals.
1115.02   Submission requirements.
1115.03   Procedures for review.
1115.04   Area variance.
1115.05   Use variance.
1115.06   Action by the Board.
1115.07   Reapplication.
1115.01 REVIEW BY THE BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals may authorize upon appeal a variance from the
terms of this Planning and Zoning Code and its Subdivision Regulations or any
amendment thereto as will not be contrary to the public interest according to
the following criteria set forth in this Chapter.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1115.02 SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS.
   An application for a variance shall be filed with the Zoning Inspector for
review by the Board of Zoning Appeals upon the forms provided, and shall be
accompanied by the following requirements necessary to convey the reason(s) for
the requested variance:
   (a)   Name, address and phone number of applicant(s):
   (b)   Proof of ownership, legal interest or written authority;
   (c)   Description of property or portion thereof;
   (d)   Description or nature of variance requested;
   (e)   Narrative statements establishing and substantiating the justification
for the variance pursuant to Sections
1115.04 and
1115.05;
   (f)   Payment of the application fee as established by Council: and
   (g)   Any other documents deemed necessary by the Zoning Inspector.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1115.03 PROCEDURES FOR REVIEW.
   (a)   Review for Completeness. Upon receipt of a written request for a
variance, the Zoning Inspector shall make a preliminary determination whether
such application provides the information necessary for review and evaluation.
If it is determined that such application does not provide the information
necessary for such review and evaluation, the Zoning Inspector shall within
five (5) working days so advise the applicant of the deficiencies and shall not
further process the application until the deficiencies are corrected.
   (b)   Review by the Board. According to the procedures established for
appeals in Sections
1113.03 and
1113.04, the Board shall hold a public hearing and give notice of the same. The
Board shall review each application for a variance to determine if it complies
with the purpose and intent of this Planning and Zoning Code and evidence
demonstrates that the literal enforcement of this Planning and Zoning Code will
result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship.
   (c)   Requests for Additional Information. The Board of Zoning Appeals may
request that the applicant supply additional information that the Board deems
necessary to review and evaluate the request for a variance. (Ord. 2002-2.
Passed 1-24-02.)
1115.04 AREA VARIANCE.
   The following factors shall be considered and weighed by the Board to
determine practical
difficulty:
   (a)   Whether special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar
to the land or structure involved and which are not applicable generally to
other lands or structures in the same zoning district. Examples of such special
conditions or circumstances are exceptional irregularity, narrowness,
shallowness or steepness of the lot, or adjacency to non-conforming and
inharmonious uses, structures or conditions;
   (b)    Whether the property in question will yield a reasonable return or
whether there can be any beneficial use of the property without the variance;
   (c)    Whether the variance is substantial and is the minimum necessary to
make possible the reasonable use of the land or structures;
   (d)    Whether the essential character of the neighborhood would be
substantially altered or whether adjoining properties would suffer substantial
detriment as a result of the variance;
   (e)   Whether the variance would adversely affect the delivery of
governmental services such as water, sewer and trash pickup;
   (f)   Whether the property owner purchased the property with knowledge of
the zoning restrictions;
   (g)    Whether special conditions or circumstances exist as a result of
actions of the owner;
   (h)    Whether the property owner's predicament feasibly can be obviated
through some method other than a variance;
   (i)    Whether the spirit and intent behind the zoning requirement would be
observed and substantial justice done by granting a variance; and
   (j)   Whether the granting of the variance requested will confer on the
applicant any special privilege that is denied by this regulation to other
lands, structures, or buildings in the same district. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-
24-02.)
1115.05 USE VARIANCE.
   ln order to grant a use variance, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
determine that strict
compliance with the tenns of this Code will result in unnecessary hardship to
the applicant. The applicant must demonstrate such difficulty by clear and
convincing evidence that all of the following criteria are satisfied:
   (a)   The property cannot be put to any economically viable use under any of
the permitted uses in the zoning district in which the property is located:
   (b)   The variance requested stems from a condition which is unique to the
property at issue and not ordinarily found in the same zone or district:
   (c)   The hardship is not created by actions of the applicant:
   (d)   The granting of the variance will not adversely affect the rights of
adjacent property owners or residents:
   (e)   The granting of the variance will not adversely affect the public
health, safety or general welfare:
   (f)   The variance will be consistent with the general spirit and intent of
this Planning and Zoning Code: and
   (g)   The variance sought is the minimum that will afford relief to the
applicant.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1115.06 ACTION BY THE BOARD.
   (a)   Action by the Board. The Board shall either approve, approve with
supplementary conditions as specified in subsection (b) below, or disapprove
the request for variance according to the procedures set forth in Section
1113.08.
   (b)   Additional Conditions and Safeguards. The Board may further prescribe
any conditions and safeguards that it deems necessary to ensure that the
objectives of the regulation(s) or provision(s) to which the variance applies
will be met.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1115.07 REAPPLICATION.
   No re-application for a variance shall be accepted by the Zoning Inspector
until the expiration of one (1) year after the denial or revocation, unless the
re-application is revised in response to the findings given by the Board of
Zoning Appeals in its denial of the initial application. A reapplication shall
comply with all the requirements of this Chapter, including payment of the
required fee.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1117
Amendments
1117.01   Authority for amendments.
1117.02   Initiation of zoning amendments.
1117.03   Amendments initiated by property owner(s).
1117.04   Amendments initiated by Planning and Zoning Commission or Council.
1117.05   Review and public notice by Planning and Zoning Commission.
1117.06   Recommendation by the Planning and Zoning Commission.
1117.07   Public hearing and notice by Council
1117.08   Action by Council.
1117.01 AUTHORITY FOR AMENDMENTS.
   Any portion of this Planning and Zoning Code and the Mingo Junction Zoning
Map may be changed whenever the public necessity, health, safety, general
welfare and good zoning practice justifies such action. Any such change shall
be made only by Council in the form of an amending ordinance. (Ord. 2002-2.
Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.02 INITIATION OF ZONING AMENDMENTS.
   Amendment to the Planning and Zoning Code, either text or map, may be
initiated in one of the following ways:
   (a)    By the adoption of a motion by Village Council;
   (b)    By the adoption of a motion by the Planning and Zoning Commission; or
   (c)    By the filing of an application to the Planning and Zoning Commission
by the majority of owner(s) or lessee(s) of property or a developer with an
option on such property within the area proposed to be changed or affected by
said amendment.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.03 AMENDMENTS INITIATED BY PROPERTY OWNER(S).
   An amendment initiated by at least one (1) owner or lessee of property or
developer with an option on such property within the area proposed to be
changed or affected by said amendment shall be submitted and reviewed according
to the following:
   (a)    Discussion with Planning and Zoning Commission. Prior to submitting
an application for an amendment to this Planning and Zoning Code, the applicant
shall appear before the Planning and Zoning Commission to informally discuss
the proposed amendment. However, no action shall be taken at such a meeting and
no discussions, opinions, suggestions, or recommendations of the Planning and
Zoning Commission shall be relied upon by the applicant to indicate subsequent
approval or disapproval of the proposed amendment.
   (b)   Submission Requirements. The request for such changes shall be
submitted in writing to the Zoning Inspector and shall contain the following:
      (1)   The name, address and phone number of the applicant and the
property owner if other than the applicant;
      (2)   The nature of the amendment and the section of this Planning and
Zoning Code for which the amendment is proposed;
      (3)   A description of the type of regulations, uses, structures or
parcels that would be affected by the amendment;
      (4)   A statement of the reason(s) for the proposed amendment;
      (5)   The payment of the application fee as established by Council;
      (6)   Amendments to the Mingo Junction Zoning Map adopted as part of this
Planning and Zoning Code shall contain the following additional information:
         A.   Legal description of the parcel(s) to be rezoned, drawn by a
registered surveyor;
         B.   Present use and zoning district;
         C.   Proposed use and zoning district;
         D.   A vicinity map at a scale approved by the Zoning Inspector
showing property lines, thoroughfares, existing and proposed zoning, and such
other items as the Zoning Inspector may require;
         E.   Existing topography of the property to be rezoned and extending
at least 100 feet outside the proposed site, and including property lines,
easements, street rights-of-ways, existing structures, trees and landscaping
features existing thereon;
   (c)   Referral to Planning and Zoning Commission. After the filing of a
completed application by an owner, lessee of property or developer with an
option on such property, the Zoning Inspector shall transmit the application to
the Planning and Zoning Commission to begin the adoption process set forth in
Sections
1117.05 through
1117.08.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.04 AMENDMENTS INITIATED BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION OR COUNCIL.
   After the passage of a motion by the Planning and Zoning Commission or the
adoption of a resolution by Council to consider an amendment, the motion or
resolution shall be reviewed and considered by the Planning and Zoning
Commission and Council according to the process set fotih in Sections
1117.05 and
1117.08.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.05 REVIEW AND PUBLIC NOTICE BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   (a)   Upon receipt of a resolution by Council or passage of a motion by the
Planning and Zoning Commission regarding an amendment or receipt of an
application for an amendment and all supporting documentation as transmitted by
the Zoning Inspector, the secretary of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall
cause the application to be placed on the agenda of the regular meeting in the
next month of the Planning and Zoning Commission.
   (b)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall hold a public hearing on such
proposed amendment and notice of the public hearing shall be given according to
the following:
      (1)    Notice of such public hearing shall be published at least once in
a newspaper of general circulation in the Village at least thirty (30) days
prior to the public hearing.
      (2)   Whenever a proposed map amendment proposes to rezone ten (10) or
fewer parcels of land as listed on the tax duplicate, written notice of the
public hearing shall be sent via first class mail to the owners of real
property lying within 300 feet of the property on which the change is proposed,
such notice shall be given no less than twenty (20) days prior to the date set
for the hearing.
      (3)    Notices shall include the time and place of the meeting, a summary
of the proposed amendment and a statement that opportunity to be heard will be
afforded to any person interested.
      (4)   Failure of delivery of such notice shall not invalidate any
recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission or any subsequently
enacted ordinance.
   (c)   During such thirty (30) days, the proposed amendment, along with any
necessary maps, plans or supplementary reports shall be on file for public
examination in the office of the Zoning Inspector.
   (d)    The Planning and Zoning Commission may continue the public hearing or
defer its consideration and no further written notice shall be required.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.06 RECOMMENDATION BY THE PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   (a)   Before making its recommendation, the Planning and Zoning Commission
shall make the following findings:
      (1)   The change requested promotes the public necessity, health, safety
and general welfare and is consistent with good land use and zoning practice.
      (2)    If the proposed change involves property bounded on one or more
sides by the corporate limits of another city or village or a boundary street
of another city or village, the matter has been referred to the Planning and
Zoning Commission of the city or village for its review and recommendation. If
the proposed change involves matters of regional significance, or property
bounded on one or more sides by the corporate limits of the Village or a
boundary street, the matter has been referred to the Jefferson County Regional
Planning and Zoning Commission for its review and recommendation.
   
   (b)    After the conclusion of the public hearing required in Section
1117.05, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall recommend one of the
following to Village Council:
      (1)   That the amendment be granted as requested;
      (2)    That the amendment be granted as modified by the Planning and
Zoning Commission; or
      (3)    That the amendment be denied.
   (c)   If the Planning and Zoning Commission does not make a recommendation
on the proposed amendment within sixty (60) days, or an extended period as may
be agreed upon by the applicant or Village Council it shall be deemed that the
recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission is that the amendment be
denied. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.07 PUBLIC HEARING AND NOTICE BY COUNCIL.
   The recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be forwarded
to the Council. Within ninety (90) days of receipt thereof, the Council shall
act upon such recommendation.
   (a)   Council may, by a majority vote, decide to hold a public hearing on
the proposed amendment. If Council votes to hold a public hearing, notice of
such shall be given according to the following:
      (1)    Notice of the public hearing shall be published once a week for
two (2) consecutive weeks on the same day of the week, the first of which shall
be published at least thirty (30) days prior to the date of the required
hearing, in one or more newspapers of general circulation in the Village.
      (2)   Whenever a proposed map amendment proposes to rezone ten (10) or
fewer parcels of land as listed on the tax duplicate, written notice of the
public hearing shall be mailed via first class mail to the owner(s) of real
property lying within 300 feet of the property on which the change is proposed,
and to such other persons in the general vicinity as in the judgment of the
secretary should be notified, such notice shall be given no less than twenty
(20) days prior to the date set for the hearing.
      (3)    Notices shall include the time and place of the public hearing, a
summary of the proposed amendment and a statement that opportunity to be heard
will be afforded to any person interested.
      (4)   Failure of delivery of such notice shall not invalidate any such
amendment.
   (b)    During the thirty (30) days prior to the public hearing, the text of
the proposed amendment, maps or plans, if applicable, and the maps, plan and
reports that constitute the recommendation of the Planning and Zoning
Commission shall be on file for public examination in the office of the Zoning
Inspector.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1117.08 ACTION BY COUNCIL.
   After the conclusion of the public hearing required in Section
1117.07, Council shall act on the proposed amendment according to the
following:
   (a)    Council's action shall either:
      (1)   Adopt the recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission;
      (2)    Deny the recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission; or
      (3)   Adopt some modification thereof.
   (b)    Required Vote for Adoption.
      (1)   In order to enact an amendment that confirms the Planning and
Zoning Commission’s recommendation a favorable vote of a majority of the
members of Council shall be necessary.
      (2)    In order to enact an amending ordinance which does not carry out
the entire recommendation of the Planning and Zoning Commission, a favorable
vote of not less than three-fourths (3/4) of the members of Council shall be
necessary.
   (c)    Council shall take final action upon such proposed amendment within
ninety (90) days after receipt of the Planning and Zoning Commission's
recommendation. If Council fails to act upon such petition within such time,
the proposed amendment shall be rejected.
   (d)   Reapplication. In the event the proposed amendment is denied by
Council, no new request for the same or a substantially similar amendment shall
be heard by Council within one (1) year of such denial.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1119
Enforcement and Penalty
1119.01   Enforcement by Zoning Inspector.
1119.02   Zoning permit and certificate of zoning occupancy required.
1119.03   Violations.
1119.04   Complaints.
1119.05   Inspection of property.
1119.06   Notice of violation.
1119.07   Stop orders.
1119.08   Permit revocation.
1119.09   Legal remedies.
1119.99   Penalties.
1119.01 ENFORCEMENT BY ZONING INSPECTOR.
   The provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code shall be administered and
enforced by the Zoning Inspector. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.02 ZONING PERMIT AND CERTIFICATE OF ZONING OCCUPANCY REQUIRED.
   No person shall commence any excavation, or the construction of any building
or other structure, including accessory structures; store building materials on
the building site; construct parking lots; commence moving, structural
alterations, conversions, extensions, enlargements, alterations or repairs,
except usual repairs not requiring permits under this Planning and Zoning Code
or any other County resolution or Municipal ordinance, of any structure
including accessory structures, fences or walls; or change the use of any
building or structure, including accessory buildings and structures, until the
Zoning Inspector has issued a zoning permit for such work or change of use and
a certificate for such occupancy.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.03 VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   No person shall erect, construct, alter, maintain or use any building
or structure or use any land in violation of any provision of this Planning and
Zoning Code or any amendment thereto. Any person, firm or corporation, either
as owner, lessee, occupant or otherwise, violating any provision of this
Planning and Zoning Code or any amendment thereto or who interferes in any
manner with any person in the performance of a right or duty granted or imposed
upon him or her by the provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code shall be
guilty of a violation of this Section and such violation may be declared to be
a nuisance.
   (b)   No oversight or dereliction on the part of the Zoning Inspector or his
or her authorized assistants or on the part of any official or employee of the
Municipality shall legalize, authorize or excuse the violation of any provision
of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (c)   Any permit issued in violation of any provision of this Planning and
Zoning Code shall be null and void and may not be construed as waiving any
provision of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (d)   Any building or land use activity considered to be a possible
violation of any provision of this Planning and Zoning Code that is observed by
any Village official shall be reported to the Zoning Inspector.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.04 COMPLAINTS.
   Whenever a violation of this Planning and Zoning Code occurs, or is alleged
to have occurred, any person may file a complaint. Such written complaints
shall fully state the causes and basis of the complaint and shall be filed with
the Zoning Inspector.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.05 INSPECTION OF PROPERTY.
   The Zoning Inspector or any duly authorized deputy inspector shall have the
right to enter upon any premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of
making inspections necessary to the
conduct of his or her duties in the administration and enforcement of this
Planning and Zoning Code. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.06 NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
   Upon finding a violation, the Zoning Inspector shall order, in writing, the
owner, agent, occupant or operator of such building or premises to correct,
within a stated reasonable time, all conditions that are found to be in
violation of this Planning and Zoning Code. After such a notice is served, no
work, except to correct the violation or comply with the notice shall proceed
on any building or premises included in the violation.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.07 STOP ORDERS.
   Whenever any work is being done contrary to the provisions of this Planning
and Zoning Code, the Zoning Inspector or his or her designee shall order the
work or use stopped by notice in writing served on any person engaged in doing
or causing such work to be done or such use to be continued, and any such
person and all others engaged in doing or causing such work to be done or such
use to be continued shall forthwith stop such work or use being done contrary
to this Planning and Zoning Code until authorized by the Zoning Inspector to
proceed with the work or continue the use. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.08 PERMIT REVOCATION.
   The Zoning Inspector may issue a revocation notice to revoke a permit or
administrative approval that was issued contrary to this Planning and Zoning
Code or based upon false information or misrepresentation in the application.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.09 LEGAL REMEDIES.
   If proper notice of a violation has been given as set forth in this Chapter
and if such violation has not ceased within such reasonable time as may be
specified, the Zoning Inspector shall present the facts in the case to the
Village Solicitor. The Village Solicitor shall immediately upon a violation of
this Planning and Zoning, having been called to his or her attention, institute
injunction, mandamus, abatement or any other appropriate action to prevent,
enjoin abate or remove any such unlawful construction, reconstruction,
alteration, conversion, maintenance or use.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1119.99 PENALTIES.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to:
      (1)   Use or occupy any land or place; build, erect, alter, remodel,
restore or rebuild thereon any building or structure; permit any building or
structure to remain on such land; or use, occupy or operate such building or
structure, in any way or for any use or purpose which is not permitted by the
provisions of this Planning and Zoning Code;
      (2)    Use or occupy any parcel of land or new building, or enlarge,
substitute, or otherwise change the use, occupancy or configuration of any land
or building, without having received a zoning permit conditional use permit or
certificate of zoning occupancy indicating compliance with the provisions of
this Planning and Zoning Code from the Zoning Inspector;
      (3)   Aid, assist or participate with any person in placing, building,
erecting, altering, remodeling, restoring or rebuilding any building or
structure which is not permitted by the provisions of this Planning and Zoning
Code;
      (4)   Violate or fail to perform any condition, stipulation or safeguard
set forth in any permit issued pursuant to this Planning and Zoning Code, or
continue to use or occupy the premises or building as previously authorized by
such permit beyond the duration limit therein stated;
      (5)    Continue construction, renovation or improvements contrary to a
Stop Work Order or Notice of Violation;
      (6)    Refuse to permit the Zoning Inspector to enter any premises in the
Municipality to investigate a reported violation of the provisions of this
Planning and Zoning Code or refuse or fail to furnish to the Zoning Inspector a
statement as to the number of persons occupying such premises:
      (7)   Knowingly make any materially false statement of fact in an
application to the Zoning Inspector for a zoning permit, conditional use permit
or certificate of zoning occupancy or in the plans or specifications submitted
to Zoning Inspector in relation to such application; or
      (8)    Make changes to the Official Zoning District Map, or matter shown
thereon, except in conformity with the procedures set forth in this Planning
and Zoning Code.
   (b)    Failure to correct the conditions in violation with the provisions of
this Planning and Zoning Code, as ordered by the Zoning Inspector, shall
constitute a misdemeanor. The responsible person or party shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned for not more than thirty
(30) days, or both. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a
separate offense. Any other person who commits, participates in or assists in
the continuation of said violation may each be found guilty of a separate
offense and suffer the penalties provided.
   (c)    No plat or plan of subdivision of land in Mingo Junction shall be
admitted to the records of the County or received or recorded by the County
Recorder until such plat has received final approval, in writing by the
Planning and Zoning Commission and Council, except as provided in Section
1121.06. Admission to the records shall not be construed as approval.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any County Recorder to receive, file or
record a plat in violation of the Subdivision Regulations contained within this
Planning and Zoning Code. The responsible person shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) as
provided in ORC §711.12.
      (2)    Any individual or party who transfers or negotiates to transfer
any lot in a subdivision before the final plat of such subdivision is approved
by Council and recorded in the office of the County Recorder, or attempts the
description of land by metes and bounds in violation of the Subdivision
Regulations contained within this Planning and Zoning Code, shall be fined not
less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
TITLE THREE - Subdivision Regulations
         Chap.   
1121.   Subdivision Approval Procedures.
         Chap.   
1123.   Submission Requirements.
         Chap.   
1125.   Design Standards.
         Chap.   
1127.   Improvements.
CHAPTER 1121
Subdivision Approval Procedures
1121.01    Purpose.
1121.02   Approval required.
1121.03   Review by Ohio Department of Transportation.
1121.04   General procedures.
1121.05   Sketch plan review.
1121.06   Minor subdivision review.
1121.07   Preliminary plat review for major subdivisions.
1121.08   Grading of site prior to final approval.
1121.09   Required documents, construction drawings, specifications.
1121.10   Public improvements.
1121.11   Final plat review for major subdivisions.
1121.12   Recordation of final plat.
1121.13   Revision of plat after approval.
1121.14   Annexed subdivisions.
1121.01 PURPOSE.
   These regulations are adopted as minimum requirements for the regulation and
control of land subdivision within the Village of Mingo Junction. These
regulations are intended to:
   (a)   Define the steps by which an applicant may design, make application,
record plats and construct improvements in the development of land.
   (b)   Ensure appropriate surveying of land, preparing and recording of plats
and the equitable handling of all subdivisions by providing uniform procedures
and standards for observance by all applicants.
   (c)   Provide for the proper arrangement of streets and highways in relation
to those existing or planned and to provide the most beneficial relationship
between use of land, buildings, traffic and pedestrian movements.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.02 APPROVAL REQUIRED.
   No owner, agent or person having control of any land within the Village
shall subdivide or lay out such land unless in accordance with the Subdivision
Regulations contained herein.
   (a)   Approval Required Prior to Recording. No subdivision of any land shall
be recorded or have any validity unless and until approved as herein required.
If an unapproved subdivision is recorded, it shall be considered invalid and
Council may institute proceeding to have the subdivision stricken from the
records of the County.
   (b)   Approval Required Prior to Selling Lots. No owner or agent of the
owner of any land located in a subdivision shall transfer, sell, agree to sell,
or negotiate to sell any land by reference to, exhibition of, or use of a
subdivision before such subdivision is approved and recorded according to the
procedures set forth in these subdivision regulations.
   (c)   Approval Required for Zoning Permit. A zoning permit shall not be
issued for any structure on a subdivided lot until such subdivision has been
approved and recorded according to the procedures set forth in these
subdivision regulations, and in compliance with the following:
      (1)   The Zoning Inspector states, in writing, that the improvements
required by these Subdivision Regulations have been completed and accepted by
the Village by ordinance, or the completion of such improvements has been
guaranteed according to the provisions set forth in these subdivision
regulations.
      (2)    No permit shall be issued under these subdivision regulations
until the developer or subdivider pays the required fees established by
Council.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.03 REVIEW BY OHIO DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION.
   Any plan within 300 feet of the centerline of a state highway for which
changes are proposed, or any land within a radius of 500 feet from the point of
intersection of said centerline with any public road or highway requires the
Planning and Zoning Commission give notice by registered or certified mail to
the Ohio Department of Transportation. If the Ohio Department of Transportation
notifies the Planning and Zoning Commission that it plans to acquire the land
needed, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall refuse to approve the plan.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.04 GENERAL PROCEDURES.
   (a)   Classification of Subdivisions. Before any land is subdivided the
owner of the property proposed to be subdivided, or his authorized agent, shall
apply for and secure approval of the proposed subdivision in accordance with
the following procedures, which include two (2) principal steps for a minor
subdivision and three (3) principal steps for a major subdivision.
      (1)   Minor Subdivision:
         A.    Sketch Plan Review.
         B.    Minor Subdivision Review.
      (2)    Major Subdivision:
         A.    Sketch Plan Review.
         B.    Preliminary Plat Review.
         C.    Final Plat Review.
   (b)    Filing an Application. Applications for minor and major subdivisions
shall be filed with the Zoning Inspector by the property owner or a designated
agent.
   (c)    Review for Completeness. The Zoning Inspector shall review the
submitted application for completeness and compliance with the applicable
submission requirements set forth in Chapter
1123 within five (5) working days of receipt of such application. If the
application is deemed insufficient, the Zoning Inspector shall notify the
applicant of the deficiencies and place the application on hold until complete.
When the application is determined complete and the application fee has been
paid, the Zoning Inspector shall officially accept the application for
consideration. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.05 SKETCH PLAN REVIEW.
   (a)    Prior to subdividing land, the owner of the land, or his or her
authorized agent,
shall submit a sketch plan to the Zoning Inspector. The application shall be
made on forms available in the Office of the Zoning Inspector and shall comply
with the submission requirements set forth in Section
1123.01.
   (b)    The subdivider shall meet with the Zoning Inspector to:
      (1)   Review the overall layout of the proposed subdivision;
      (2)    Discuss requirements for the general location of streets, drainage
and sewage requirements, fire protection and the availability of existing
utility services; and
      (3)    Discuss the location of any proposed major streets, parks,
playgrounds, school sites and any other planned projects that may affect the
property being considered for subdivision.
   (c)    The Zoning inspector shall review the sketch plan to determine if the
application is a major or minor subdivision and shall advise the applicant of
the appropriate procedures.
   (d)    No opinions, suggestions, or recommendations discussed shall be
construed to constitute automatic approval of a subsequently submitted
application for a minor subdivision or preliminary plat for a major
subdivision.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.06 MINOR SUBDIVISION REVIEW.
   (a)   Applications for minor subdivisions shall comply with the submission
requirements set forth in Section
