1123.02.
   (b)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, a proposed lot division may
be approved by the Zoning Inspector if the proposed subdivision of the parcel
of land meets the following conditions.
      (1)   The proposed division of a parcel as shown on the last proceeding
tax duplicate involves no more than five (5) lots, after the original parcel
has been completely subdivided, any one of which is under five (5) acres,
inclusive of the remainder of the parcel.
      (2)    The proposed subdivision is located along an existing public
street and involves no opening, widening or extension of any street or road or
extension of any public utility.
      (3)    The proposed subdivision is not contrary to any applicable
subdivision or zoning regulation.
      (4)    The proposed subdivision is approved by the local health
department, the Village Engineer and others as may be applicable.
      (5)    The proposed minor subdivision is based on a professional survey
for both the existing parcel(s) and new parcels to be created.
   (c)   The Zoning Inspector shall, within seven (7) business days after the
submission is determined complete, approve or disapprove the application.
      (1)   If the application meets the criteria for minor subdivisions set
forth in this Section, the Zoning Inspector shall sign and stamp the survey
drawing "approved-no plat required".
      (2)    If the application is denied the subdivider shall be notified of
the issue(s) and reason(s) for the denial.
   (d)   Upon approval the applicant shall file the deed with the County
Auditor for the transfer of property and with the County Recorder where it will
become a legal lot of record. If such conveyance is not recorded within 180
days from the date of approval, such approval shall expire.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.07 PRELIMINARY PLAT REVIEW FOR MAJOR SUBDIVISIONS.
   Any person applying for a major subdivision shall submit a preliminary plat
to be reviewed in accordance with the following procedures.
   (a)   Purpose. The preliminary plat of a major subdivision is not intended
to serve as a record plat. Its purpose is to show on a map all facts needed to
enable the Planning and Zoning Commission and Council to determine whether the
proposed layout of the land in question is satisfactory from the standpoint of
the public interest. It enable the applicant the Planning and Zoning Commission
and Council to explore the best relationship to adjoining land and outline a
program of improvements.
   (b)   Submission Requirements. The preliminary plat shall comply with the
submission requirements set forth in Section
1123.04.
   (c)   Distribution of Plans. Once the application has been determined
complete, the Zoning Inspector shall forward copies of the complete application
to the appropriate agencies, departments, individuals or consultants for review
and report. Any reports comments or expert opinions shall be returned to the
Zoning Inspector within ten (10) business days from the date the application is
deemed complete.
   (d)   Transmission to the Planning and Zoning Commission. The Zoning
Inspector shall distribute the application and the recommendations from the
appropriate individuals set forth in subsection (c) above to the Planning and
Zoning Commission.
   (e)   Criteria for Approval. Prior to granting approval of a preliminary
plat the Planning and Zoning Commission shall determine that such application
complies with the following:
      (1)   The design and layout of the subdivision conforms to the design
standards set forth in Chapter
1125.
      (2)    The application complies with the improvements standards set forth
in Chapter
1127.
      (3)    The application complies with all zoning regulations governing the
area and dimensions of lots set forth in this Planning and Zoning Code.
      (4)    The application complies with any development criteria promulgated
by any agency that has jurisdiction of the subdivision.
   (f)   Action By Planning and Zoning Commission. The Planning and Zoning
Commission shall take one of the following actions:
      (1)   Approve. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall approve the
application if it meets the regulations set forth in these subdivision
regulations.
      (2)   Disapprove. If a preliminary plat is disapproved, the reasons for
such disapproval shall be stated in writing.
      (3)    Approve with modifications. The Planning and Zoning Commission may
require such changes or revisions as are deemed necessary to the welfare and
needs of the community. If the preliminary plat is approved with modifications,
the nature of the modifications shall be indicated in writing.
      (4)   If the Planning and Zoning Commission fails to act within sixty
(60) days from the date the application was deemed complete, or an extended
period as may be agreed upon, then the applicant may deem that the application
has been denied.
   (g)   Confirmation By Village Council. The Planning and Zoning Commission
shall forthwith forward the application to Council for review:
      (1)    The purpose of Council's review shall be to confirm or deny the
action of the Planning and Zoning Commission. In doing so, Council shall rely
on the record of the Planning and Zoning Commission. A public hearing shall not
be required.
      (2)    Council shall act on the application according to the following:
         A.    Council may confirm the action of the Planning and Zoning
Commission or modification thereof; or
         B.    Council may refer the preliminary plat back to the Planning and
Zoning Commission for further study and review; or
         C.    Council may reject the action of the Planning and Zoning
Commission.
      (3)    Failure of Council to act within sixty (60) days from the date the
Planning and Zoning Commission acts shall be deemed a confirmation of the
Planning and Zoning Commission's action.
   (h)    Resubmission of Disapproved Preliminary Plat. If a preliminary plat
is disapproved subject to modification, such modified preliminary plat may be
resubmitted for review by the Commission within ninety (90) days at no
additional fee.
   (i)    Record of Action. The actions of the Planning and Zoning Commission
and Council shall be noted on two (2) copies of the preliminary plat. Any
specific changes required by the Planning and Zoning Commission and Council at
the time of approval or disapproval of the plat shall be noted on the plat.
      (1)   One copy shall be returned to the subdivider, and
      (2)   One copy shall be retained by the Planning and Zoning Commission.
   (j)   Approval Period. The approval of the preliminary plat shall be
effective for a maximum period of twelve (12) months unless the Commission, on
application of the subdivider grants an extension. If the final plat has not
been submitted for review within this time limit, the preliminary plat approval
shall expire and become void. Approval of the preliminary plat shall not
constitute acceptance of the final plat. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.08 GRADING OF SITE PRIOR TO FINAL APPROVAL.
   The preliminary plat shall be approved prior to the completion of final
surveys of roads and lots and before the start of any grading or construction
work.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.09 REQUIRED DOCUMENTS, CONSTRUCTION DRAWINGS, SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   General. After receiving notice of approval of the preliminary plat
and prior to filing the final plat the subdivider shall submit the following
information:
      (1)    Three (3) copies of the covenants and restrictions governing the
maintenance and insurance of any common area any proposed easements or grants
for public utilities shall be submitted to the Zoning Inspector who shall
forward such documentation to the Village Solicitor for review and approval.
      (2)    Three (3) sets of the detailed construction drawings and
specifications, and supporting documentation as applicable and as required in
Section 1123.08 shall be submitted to the Zoning Inspector who shall forward
such documentation to the Village Engineer for review and approval.
   (b)   Review. The subdivider shall be notified of any recommended changes so
that the subdivider may revise the documents as needed. Subsequent to final
approval of the covenants, grants of easements, or the restrictions and/or the
detailed engineering drawings and specifications, the subdivider may submit the
final plat for approval.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.10 PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS.
   All public improvements shall be installed and dedicated prior to the
signing of the final subdivision plat by the Zoning Inspector unless the
subdivider guarantees construction of the improvements and such guarantees as
required in Section
1123.09 are approved by Council prior
to approval of the final plat. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.11 FINAL PLAT REVIEW FOR MAJOR SUBDIVISIONS.
   The subdivider, having received approval of the preliminary plat of the
proposed subdivision shall submit a final plat of the subdivision and drawings
and specifications of the improvements required therein to the Zoning
Inspector. The final plat may constitute only a portion of the approved
preliminary plat that the subdivider proposes to record and develop at that
time.
   (a)    Submission Requirements. The application shall comply with the
required submission requirements set forth in Section
1123.05.
   (b)    Criteria for Approval. The Zoning Inspector shall approve a final
plat when such plat complies with the following:
      (1)   The final plat conforms to the approved preliminary plat, including
the layout of streets, number of lots, amount and percentage of open space,
etc. and incorporates all changes required in the preliminary plat approval.
      (2)    The Village Engineer has approved the construction drawings for
the proposed roads, sewer and water systems and other proposed public
facilities and either the improvements are installed or a construction
performance guarantee has been approved by Council.
      (3)    The Village Solicitor has approved the covenants and restrictions
regarding maintenance and insurance of common areas and any proposed easements
or grants for public utilities.
      (4)   The application complies with the provisions set forth in these
subdivision regulations and this Planning and Zoning Code. If a zoning change
is involved such change shall be approved prior to approval of a final plat.
      (5)    All computations, certifications, and monuments are accurately
noted on the plat, including all required certifications for water and sewer
improvements.
      (6)    The subdivider has furnished the appropriate certifications and
statements as required in Sections
1123.06 to
1123.07.
   (c)   Action by Zoning Inspector. The Zoning Inspector shall approve or deny
a final plat within thirty (30) days after the filing, unless such time is
extended by agreement with the subdivider. the final plat is withdrawn or a
delay-of-action is requested and granted.
      (1)   Upon review of the final plat if the Zoning Inspector determines
that the final plat meets the criteria set forth in subsection
1121.11(b) the Zoning the final plat that such plat has been reviewed, found to
comply with subsection
1121.11(b) and approved. The Zoning Inspector shall return the signed final
plat to the subdivider.
      (2)    If the application is denied the subdivider shall be notified of
the issue(s) and reason(s) for the denial.
   (d)   Approval of the final plat by the Zoning Inspector shall not
constitute acceptance by the Village of the dedication of any street, public
way or public site.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.12 RECORDATION OF FINAL PLAT.
   After the Zoning Inspector has approved the final plat and the necessary
approvals are endorsed thereon in writing. the subdivider shall submit a copy
of the approved plat for processing by the County Tax Department, County
Auditor and filing with the County Recorder. It shall be the responsibility of
the subdivider to gain all necessary certifications before filing the plat with
the County Recorder. The subdivider shall provide the Zoning Inspector with a
paper copy of the approved plat. After the plat is recorded, the original plat
or an archival quality reproducible reproduction shall be filed with the County
Recorder.
   (a)   The subdivider shall record the final plat within 180 days of final
approval; otherwise the final plat approval shall expire and become void.
   (b)   Where the developer has entered into an agreement with the Village to
install the improvements prior to the filing of the plat for record, the 180
day period shall commence after the time set for completion of the improvements
lapses.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.13 REVISION OF PLAT AFTER APPROVAL.
   No change, modification, revision shall be made in any final plat of a
subdivision after approval has been given by the Zoning Inspector. Any change,
modification, or revision shall constitute a new subdivision application.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1121.14 ANNEXED SUBDIVISIONS.
   The property owners within the annexed subdivision shall be responsible for
the total cost of bringing the subdivision up to the standards set forth in
these subdivision regulations unless the requirement for compliance has been
waived by the Village Council prior to annexation and specific waivers are
spelled out in terms of annexation. Such costs may include but not be limited
to those incurred for upgrading or installing storm and sanitary sewers,
waterlines, curbs and gutters, streets and related improvements. The
assessments of the property owners within the annexed subdivision for such
improvements shall be based on the procedures specified within the Ohio Revised
Code.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1123
Submission Requirements
1123.01   Sketch plan submission requirements.
1123.02   Minor subdivision submission requirements.
1123.03   Certifications required for minor subdivisions.
1123.04   Preliminary plat submission requirements.
1123.05   Final plat submission requirements.
1123.06   Required certifications.
1123.07   Required statements.
1123.08   Construction drawings and specifications.
1123.09   Subdivider’s agreement and guarantees.
1123.10   As-built documents.
1123.01 SKETCH PLAN SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS.
   A Sketch Plan shall be drawn at a scale of not less than l "=100' and shall
contain the following information:
   (a)   The name, address and phone number of the applicant or his or her
agent who is authorized to receive all notices required by these subdivision
regulations;
   (b)    Required fees as established by Council;
   (c)    A vicinity map at a scale of not less than 1"=1000' showing the
relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings within one-half (½) mile;
   (d)    Ownership of the subject property and adjacent properties,
identifying all contiguous holdings of the subject property owner including
land in "common ownership";
   (e)   Proposed layout of area(s) to be subdivided, illustrating lots,
streets, and open space areas;
   (f)   Existing streets. easements. and structures:
   (g)    Existing zoning;
   (h)    Important natural features and drainage ways:
   (i)    A written statement about storm drainage, sewage disposal, water
supply and other facilities that exist in the area and the likely impacts of
the development on those systems.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.02 MINOR SUBDIVISION SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS.
   The applicant shall submit the following information to the Zoning
Inspector:
   (a)    Required fees as established by Council.
   (b)    A deed with a legal description of the property.
   (c)    A survey drawing that complies with the minimum standards for
boundary surveys in the State of Ohio (OAC 4733-37). Such survey shall indicate
the location of boundaries and lot lines at a scale between 1" = 10' and 1" =
100'. All dimensions shall be shown in feet and hundredths of feet.
   (d)    Location of monuments and their descriptions.
   (e)    Location and size of all existing buildings.
   (f)   Areas within the 100 year flood plain and within floodways shall be
delineated.
   (g)    The Zoning Inspector may require the applicant to submit any
additional information he or she deems relevant to the proposal.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.03 CERTIFICATIONS REQUIRED FOR MINOR SUBDIVISIONS.
   A minor subdivision shall contain the following certifications.
   (a)    Certificate of Ownership.
      I hereby certify that I am the owner of the property described hereon,
which property is within the subdivision regulation jurisdiction of the Village
of Mingo Junction, Ohio and that"I freely adopt this plan of subdivision.
                                                                                                        
      Date:                Owner:
   (b)    Certification of Approval.
      I hereby certify that the minor subdivision shown on this survey does not
involve the creation of new public streets or any change in existing public
streets, that the subdivision shown is in all respects in compliance with these
subdivision regulations, and that therefore this plat has been approved by the
Zoning Inspector subject to its being recorded in the office of the County
Recorder within 180 days of the date below.
                                                                                                        
      Date:                Zoning Inspector:
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.04 PRELIMINARY PLAT SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS.
   The preliminary plat shall include the maps, plans, designs and
supplementary information itemized below, unless specific items are determined
by the Zoning Inspector to be inapplicable or unnecessary and are waived in
writing by the Zoning Inspector.
   (a)    Entire Holding to be Shown. Where the preliminary plat covers only
part of the subdivider's entire holding, a sketch plan of the entire holding
shall be submitted in order to consider the proposed subdivision's connections
with the road system of the part not submitted.
   (b)    Form. The preliminary plat shall be drawn at a scale of not less than
l "= l 00' and shall be on one or more sheets, with dimensions which are
multiples of six (6) inches in either direction. Construction plans shall be
prepared by an Ohio registered engineer.
   (c)    Submission. Eight (8) copies of the preliminary plat shall be
submitted to the Zoning Inspector with a written application and payment of the
fee.
   (d)    Contents. The information required for the preliminary plat and
accompanying information shall include:
      (1)   Vicinity Map. A vicinity map at a scale of not less than 1"= l 000'
showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings within one-half
(½) mile.
      (2)    Existing Conditions. A map(s) indicating the following existing
conditions on the subject tract and within 200 feet of the tract.
         A.    Boundaries, dimensions and acreage of the tract to be
subdivided;
         B.    Identification of adjacent subdivisions and adjacent parcels
with boundary lines shown by dashed lines and including the names of adjacent
subdivisions and owners of the adjacent parcels:
         C.    Topographic features:
         D.    Location, widths, types and names of all existing streets,
railroad rights-of-way, easements, parks and other public rights-of-way:
         E.    The location, type and name and dimension of any buildings,
structures, parking areas, driveways, corporation lines, wooded areas, water
courses, drainage patterns and water bodies:
         F.    Zoning classification of the proposed subdivision and adjoining
properties and a description of proposed zoning changes if any.
         G.    The existing use(s) on the subject property and adjacent land.
         H.    Existing sanitary and storm sewers, water mains, culverts, gas
lines, fire hydrants, electric and telephone poles, street lights, cable
television lines or other underground items within the tract or immediately
adjacent thereto, with pipe sizes, grades, elevations, and locations indicated.
If water mains and sewers are not on or adjacent to the tract, the direction,
distance and size of those nearest shall be indicated.
         I.    Contours at two-foot intervals of the tract and adjacent
properties.
         J.    Streams, drainage ditches, ponds, swamps, marshes, wetlands and
other boundaries of floodways and flood plains, the tree line of wooded areas,
rock outcroppings and individual preservable trees one foot or more in diameter
and other significant features.
      (3)    Proposed Conditions. A map(s) illustrating the following
pertaining to the proposed subdivision.
         A.    Boundaries of the proposed subdivision indicated by a heavy,
solid line and the approximate acreage comprised therein and the bearing and
distances of the boundary lines.
         B.    Layout approximate dimensions of each lot. Lots shall be
identified by number.
         C.    Front, side and rear building setback lines with dimensions and
notation of minimum lot size.
         D.    Preliminary layout and typical cross sections of streets,
including names and widths of existing and proposed streets, and widths of any
alleys or crosswalks, and the location width and purpose of any easements.
         E.    Location and size of proposed utility mains, showing their
connections with the existing systems.
         F.    General phasing of the development, indicating construction and
development of any common open space and recreation facilities. The preliminary
plat shall include the proposed general layout for the entire area.
         G.    Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved
for public use or reserved by covenant for residents of the subdivision, the
acreage of each parcel and the conditions of such dedication or reservation.
         H.    For multi-family and nonresidential uses, the location,
dimensions and approximate grade of the proposed parking and loading areas,
alleys, sidewalks, and points of vehicular ingress to and egress from the
development and the tentative lot arrangement.
      (4)    General Information. The following additional information shall be
provided.
         A.    Name, address and telephone number of the owner, subdivider,
Ohio professional surveyor and Ohio professional engineer with appropriate
numbers and seals.
         B.    Date of survey, scale of plat and north arrow.
         C.    Location by section, township or by other legal description or
tract designation and other description according to the real estate records of
the tax-map office.
         D.    A statement of the proposed use of lots, giving the type and
number of dwelling units and the type of business or industry.
         E.    Highways or other major improvements planned by public
authorities for future construction on or near the tract.
         F.    A general description of any proposed covenants and
restrictions.
         G.    Any site or federal wetland development permits that have been
obtained for development of wetlands on the site.
         H.    Location of any known gas or oil wells.
         I.    Any other information, studies, items or provisions deemed
necessary or prudent to promote the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord.
2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.05 FINAL PLAT SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS.
   The subdivider shall prepare the final plat for record purposes. The final
plat shall include the maps, plans, designs and supplementary documents
itemized below, unless specific items are
determined by the Zoning Inspector to be inapplicable or unnecessary and are
waived in writing by the Zoning Inspector.
   (a)   Application. Three (3) copies of an application for approval of a
final plat shall be submitted to the Zoning Inspector, on forms provided by the
Zoning Inspector. The application shall be accompanied by the final plat and
related documentation as required in this Section and payment of the fee.
   (b)   Final Plat Form. The final plat shall be drawn or printed on mylar or
other material of equal permanence and shall be drawn in india ink, Auto Cad or
other method approved by the Zoning Inspector.
      (1)    It shall be drawn at a scale of not less than 1"=100' and shall be
on one or more sheets. If more than one sheet is needed, each sheet shall be
numbered, the relation of one sheet to another clearly shown, and the number of
sheets used shall be set forth in the title of the plat.
      (2)    The plat shall comply with the Minimum Standards for Boundary
Surveys in the State of Ohio and the measurement specifications as contained in
Chapter 4733-37 of the Ohio Administrative Code.
      (3)    The final plat shall be prepared by a professional surveyor, and
the design for construction of improvements prepared by a professional engineer
both licensed to practice in the State of Ohio.
      (4)   All linear dimensions shall be given to the nearest hundredth of a
foot.
   (c)   Contents of Final Plat. The final plat shall contain the following
information. All dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data on the plat
shall be tied to primary control points, and the locations and description of
such control points shall be given.
      (1)   Existing Conditions.
         A.    Municipal, township, county or lot lines accurately tied to the
lines of the subdivision by distance and angles.
         B.    The lines, name and right-of-way width of all existing streets
and alleys.
         C.    The location of all adjoining properties, the names and
addresses of the owners of adjoining properties and the lines of adjoining
streets and alleys with their widths and the name of all streets.
         D.    The location of all survey monuments and/or iron pins.
         E.    The location of all easements provided for public use, services
or utilities.
         F.    Location of all streams, rivers, canals, lakes, flood hazard
boundary areas and other similar significant natural features.
      (2)   Proposed Conditions. A map(s) illustrating the following details
pertaining to the subdivision.
         A.    A statement table showing total acreage in the subdivision and
total acreage of lots, roads, open space, easements and other types of uses.
         B.    Boundaries of the proposed subdivision indicated by a solid
line.
         C.    Layout and dimensions of each lot and setback lines. Lots shall
be identified by number.
         D.    Bearings and distances to the nearest established street lines
and accurate location and description of all monuments.
         E.    All dimensions, both linear and angular, necessary for locating
the boundaries of the subdivision and lots and other areas for public or
private use with the purpose indicated thereon.
         F.    Names, locations, dimensions and rights-of-way of all existing
and proposed streets, railroads and easements within and adjoining the plat.
Radii, internal angles, points of curvature, tangent bearings. length or arcs,
and lengths and bearing of chords of all streets.
         G.    Front, side and rear building setback lines accurately shown
with dimensions.
         H.    Previous lots or blocks and their numbers indicated by a
contrasting line style in the case of a replat.
         I.    A legend of all symbols and abbreviations used.
      (3)    General Information.
         A.    The name of the subdivision, its location by section or by other
survey number and the graphic scale, points of compass, date and true north
arrow.
         B.    The purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are
dedicated or reserved.
         C.    Name, address and telephone number of the owner, subdivider,
professional surveyor and professional engineer with appropriate numbers and
seals.
         D.    Names and addresses of the owner of any easements on or
immediately adjacent to the property to be subdivided.
         E.    Descriptions and specifications of the storm drainage system and
a clear title by deed to the Village for any retention or detention basin site
as well as a statement indicating the entity or person responsible for
maintenance of storm water facilities.
         F.    The part, which is to be subdivided shall be clearly
superimposed upon the overall plan in order to illustrate clearly the
progression of development. Each subsequent plat shall follow the same
procedure until the entire area controlled by the subdivider is subdivided.
            (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.06 REQUIRED CERTIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Notarized certification on the plat of title showing that the
applicant is the owner and acknowledgment of any restrictions including
dedication to public use of all streets, alleys, parks or other open spaces
shown thereon and the granting of easements required.
   (b)   Certification from the Zoning Inspector that the plat is in accordance
with the requirements of the Planning and Zoning Code. No plat may be approved
contingent upon the subsequent approval of a zoning change.
   (c)   Certification by the County Health Officer and/or Ohio Environmental
Protection Agency, as required.
   (d)   Certification by the County Auditor that there are no unpaid taxes or
assessments upon any part of the area within the subdivision.
   (e)   Certification by an Ohio registered surveyor attesting to the accuracy
of the survey and the correct location of all monuments shown.
   (f)   Certification of approval by the Village Engineer where new street
construction
is involved.
   (g)   Certification by the Village Engineer that the subdivider has
installed the required improvements including monuments or that a financial
guarantee has been posted to insure the completion of improvements.
   (h)   Spaces of the signatures of the owners of the property, the Zoning
Inspector, Village Engineer, County Auditor, County Recorder and a Notary
Public.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)

   The following statements shall be affixed on the subdivision plat:
   (a)    Title (Subdivision Name).
      Being part of Original Mingo Junction Township Lot No.         Village of

1123.08 CONSTRUCTION DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   The Zoning Inspector shall not consider for approval any final development
plan or final plat unless such development plan or plat is accompanied by
construction drawings, specifications
and computations bearing the approval of the Village Engineer.
   (a)    The subdivider shall submit a complete set of construction drawings
and specifications of the improvements authorized in the approval of the
preliminary plat. A registered engineer shall prepare the drawings. The
construction drawings and specifications shall include typical sections, plans
and profile views, construction details, and estimates of quantities.
   (b)   If new roads are to be constructed in the allotment, a plan and
profile of each road, drawn on Standards Federal Aid Sheets, shall follow the
final plat approval and precede any initial construction. Scale to be used:
horizontal, 1" = 50'; vertical, 1" = 50'. Mylar FAS sheets and india ink, Auto
Cad or another legible source shall be used. Such street profiles shall be
approved by the Village Engineer prior to the commencement of street
improvements.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.09 SUBDIVIDER’S AGREEMENT AND GUARANTEES.
   To ensure the construction and installation of storm and sanitary sewers,
water systems, streets, sidewalks and street lighting systems for dedication
and to indemnify and save harmless the Village from any and all liability
arising from such construction, the subdivider shall, prior to final plat
approval, enter into a subdivider's agreement with the Village. This Section
shall not
be applicable if such improvements are in place and the Village has previously
accepted such improvements for dedication.
   (a)    Forms and Contents. The subdividers' agreement shall be prepared in
accordance with the Village's legal requirements and shall be approved as to
form, manner of execution and surety by the Village Solicitor, in the amount
determined by the Village Engineer, and shall post title and liability
insurance as approved by the Village Solicitor, all of which shall run to the
Village.
   (b)    Construction Performance Guarantee. The financial guarantee of
construction performance shall include:
      (1)   An amount equal to one hundred ten percent (110%) of the Village
Engineer's estimate of the cost of construction of the storm and sanitary
sewers, water systems, streets, sidewalks, street lighting systems and
facilities and appurtenances thereto; plus
      (2)    An amount, as determined by the Village Engineer, to cover the
engineering fee commensurate with the work performed; plus
      (3)    An amount, as determined by the Village Engineer, to cover the
inspection fee.
   (c)    Maintenance Bond. The maintenance bond shall be ten percent (10%) of
the construction costs of the improvements, as determined by the Engineer, for
one (1) year from the date of acceptance by the Village. Improvements shall
include streets, sidewalks, pavements and facilities appurtenant thereto, and
storm and sanitary sewers, water systems, street lighting systems and
facilities appurtenant thereto. If the subdivider does not comply with the
minimum improvement requirements, he or she shall reinstall the improvements to
conform to these subdivision regulations.
   (d)   Title Insurance. The subdivider shall furnish title insurance in the
amount determined by the Village Solicitor, covering the lands to be dedicated
as indicated on the final plat and showing the title to such dedicated lands
good in the name of the Village when the final plat is filed for record.
   (e)   Liability Insurance. The subdivider shall furnish such insurance as is
deemed necessary by the Council which shall indemnify and save harmless the
Village from any and all liability arising from or related to the construction
or installation of any improvements in the subdivision. The insurance shall be
of such duration as determined by the Council, but shall in no case be allowed
to expire earlier than the effective period of any maintenance bond. A copy of
the insurance policy shall remain, at all times. with the Village Clerk.
   (f)   Monuments. Before the construction guarantee performance is released,
all monuments shall be set by the developer and checked as required by the
Village Engineer. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1123.10 AS-BUILT DOCUMENTS.
   (a)   As part of the dedication of any street utility, easement or any other
improved real property, the subdivider shall submit to the Village as-built
documents indicating all improvements as put in place, with field notes and
dimensions needed to record any variance from the design drawings.
   (b)   Such as-built documents shall be submitted in hard copy or electronic
form if generated by such means.
      (1)    Hard copy shall be on reproducible mylar.
      (2)    Electronic copy shall be on three and one-half (3.5) inch
diskettes, in DXF format.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1125
Design Standards
1125.01    Purpose.
1125.02   Suitability of land.
1125.03   Streets.
1125.04   Sidewalks.
1125.05   Blocks.
1125.06   Lots.
1125.07   Wetlands and flood-prone areas.
1125.01 PURPOSE.
   This Chapter shall control the manner in which streets, lots and other
elements of a subdivision are arranged, or a development is arranged, on the
land. The design controls set forth in this Chapter shall help ensure
convenient and safe streets, the creation of usable lots, the provision of
space for public utilities and the reservation of land for recreational uses.
The standards and details of design prescribed in this Chapter are intended
only as minimum requirements so that the general arrangements and layout of a
subdivision may be adjusted to a wide variety of circumstances. However, in the
design and development of the plat, the subdivider should use standards
consistent with the site conditions to promote attractive and functional
neighborhoods so as to assure an economical, pleasant, and stable neighborhood.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1125.02 SUITABILITY OF LAND.
   If the Planning and Zoning Commission finds land proposed for development or
to be subdivided is unsuitable for development or subdivision, the Commission
shall not approve such land for development or subdivision unless adequate
methods are formulated by the developer or subdivider for meeting the obstacles
created by such development or subdivision of land.
   (a)   Land may be considered unsuitable for development due to flooding,
improper drainage, steep slopes, rock formations, utility easements or any
other such condition that may increase the danger to health, life or property
or aggravate erosion or flood hazards.
   (b)   In order to determine that land is unsuitable for development, the
Planning and Zoning Commission shall consider adequate investigations conducted
by all the public agencies having jurisdiction, and shall determine that it is
in the best interest of the public that the land should not be platted or
developed for the proposed purpose.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1125.03 STREETS.
   (a)   General Layout of Streets. The arrangement, character, extent, width,
grade and location of all streets shall be considered in their relation to
other existing and planned streets, topographical conditions and public
convenience and safety and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses
of land to be served and or abutted by such streets.
      (1)   Continuation of Existing Streets. Proposed streets shall provide
for the continuation or completion of any existing streets, constructed or
recorded, in adjoining property, at equal or greater width, and in similar
alignment unless variations are recommended by the Planning and Zoning
Commission.
      (2)   Circulation. The street pattern shall provide ease of circulation
within the subdivision as well as convenient access to adjoining streets or
thoroughfares and shall not be such as to cause hardship to owners of adjoining
property in platting their own land and providing convenient access to it.
         A.    In general, streets shall be platted with appropriate regard for
topography, creeks, wooded area and other natural features which would lend
themselves to attractive treatment.
         B.    Local streets shall be laid out so that their use by through
traffic will be discouraged.
         C.    Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall
be avoided. Where streets intersect major and collector streets, their
alignment shall be continuous.
         D.    Where a street terminates at the property line of a proposed
development or subdivision for the specific purpose of serving the adjacent
undeveloped or unplatted lands, the developer or subdivider shall construct a
suitable turn-around.
         E.    Alleys shall not be provided in a residential block, except
where justified by extreme conditions, but may be required in business and
industrial districts for adequate access to block interior and for off-street
loading and parking purposes. Dead-end alleys are prohibited.
   (b)    Right-of-Way Requirements.
      (1)    The right-of-way shall be measured from lot line to lot line.
      (2)    The right-of-way of a new street that is a continuation of an
existing street shall in no case be continued at a width less than that of the
existing street.
      (3)    The right-of-way for a new street shall meet the minimum standards
set forth below in Schedule
1125.03(6):
Schedule
1125.03(b)
Minimum Width of Right of Way
 
                             Minimum Width of Right-of-Way (1)
Alley                        30 feet
Minor Street or Local Street 50 feet
Collector Street             50 feet
Cul-de-sac                   50 feet
Notes to Schedule
1125.03(b)
(1) Where the topography or special conditions make streets of less width more
suitable, the Planning and Zoning Commission may modify this requirement
   (c)    Pavement Width. The width of pavement will vary, depending upon the
character of the development served and the amount of traffic expected to
utilize the street. The street pavement width shall meet the minimum standards
set forth below in Schedule
1125.03(c) and shall include two and one-half (2½) feet concrete curb and
gutter. See the Village of Mingo Junction typical street sections.
Schedule
1125.03(c)
Minimum Pavement Width
 
Type                         Minimum Pavement Width (ft.)(1)
Alley                        18 feet
Minor Street or Local Street 24 feet
Cul-de-sac                   24 feet
Collector Street             28 feet
Notes to Schedule
1125.03(c):
(1) Where the topography or special conditions make streets of less width more
suitable, the Planning and Zoning Commission may modify this requirement.
   (d)    Cul-de-sacs. Cul-de-sacs shall not exceed a length of 1,000 feet
measured to the center of the radius of the turnaround, unless topography
necessitates a greater length. The terminal shall be a circular area with a
minimum radius of fifty (50) feet measured from a point on the street
centerline within which the pavement area shall be a minimum radius of thirty-
five (35) feet to the face of the curb except in Industrial districts where the
minimum radius of a turnaround shall be seventy-five (75) feet. Cul-de-sacs are
required whenever a street is intended to be permanently dead-ended.
   (e)    Half Streets. Dedication of a half-street is discouraged. Where there
exists a dedicated or platted half-street or alley adjacent to the tract to be
subdivided, the other half shall be platted if deemed necessary by the Planning
and Zoning Commission.
   (f)   One-Way Streets. One-way streets are permitted in new subdivisions if
the Planning and Zoning Commission determines that such streets are properly
integrated with the existing and proposed street system in the area.
   (g)    Easements. A utility easement of ten (10) feet in width may be
required along each side of the street right-of-way.
   (h)    Street Intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at
right angles as topography and other limiting factors will permit. The angle of
intersection between minor streets and major streets shall not vary by more
than ten (10) degrees from a right angle.
      (1)   Street curb intersections shall be rounded by a radii of at least
twenty (20) feet.
      (2)    Not more than two (2) streets shall intersect at one (1) point,
unless approved by the Commission.
   (i)   Interference with Traffic. Streets serving nonresidential developments
and accessory parking areas shall be planned to connect with major and
collector streets so as not to generate traffic on local streets. The
intersections of driveways with major or collector streets shall be located so
as to cause the least possible interference with traffic movement.
   (j)   Street Vacation. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall not
recommend the vacation of any street dedicated to and accepted by the public if
such vacation will adversely affect the proper functioning of the existing
street system or any future street plan prepared by, or approved, by the
Planning and Zoning Commission. The procedure to vacate a street or alley shall
comply with Ohio Revised Code Section 5553.01.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1125.04 SIDEWALKS.
   (a)   Sidewalks where required shall not be less than four (4) feet in width
and shall be constructed in accordance with applicable standard specifications
of the Village. The location of all sidewalks shall be shown on the final plat.
Where the existing width of sidewalks is greater than four (4) feet, all newly
constructed sidewalks must be of the same width as existing sidewalks.
   (b)   Sidewalks shall be required as provided by the Planning and Zoning
Commission for major subdivisions and the Zoning Inspector for minor
subdivision.
   (c)    Sidewalks are to be constructed at the time of completion of the
residential, or commercial structure on the premises and prior to the issuance
of an occupancy permit. If inclement weather or other conditions makes it
impossible or impractical to construct sidewalks at the time of completion of
the major improvements, the Zoning Inspector may issue an occupancy permit upon
the developer depositing with the Village a cash deposit or an irrevocable
letter of credit from a financial institution in an amount determined by the
Village Engineer to be sufficient to construct sidewalks.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1125.05 BLOCKS.
   The following regulations shall govern the design and layout of blocks:
   (a)   The arrangement of blocks shall conform to the street planning
criteria set forth in Section
1125.03.
   (b)   Blocks shall be arranged to accommodate lots and building sites of the
size and character required for the particular zoning district, as set forth in
these Subdivision Regulations and this Planning and Zoning Code, to provide for
required community facilities, and with regard to the limitations and
opportunities of the topography.
   (c)   Irregularly shaped blocks, those intended for cul-de-sacs or loop
streets, and those containing interior parks or playgrounds, may be approved by
the Commission if properly designed and located and if the property
arrangements are made for the maintenance of interior public spaces.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1125.06 LOTS.
   The following regulations shall govern the design and layout of lots:
   (a)    Every lot shall abut on a public or private street except as
otherwise permitted by the Planning and Zoning Commission as part of a planned
residential development or unified commercial development.
   (b)    Lots shall be numbered.
   (c)    Lot arrangement and design shall be properly related to the
topography and to the character of surrounding development to provide desirable
and appropriate building sites.
   (d)    All side lines of lots shall be at right angles to straight street
lines and radial to curved street lines except where the Planning and Zoning
Commission determines that a variation of this rule will provide a better
street and lot layout.
   (e)   All lots shall conform to or exceed the requirements of these
Subdivisions Regulations and the zoning district requirements for the district
in which they are located and the use for which they are intended.
   (f)   Lots with double frontage shall be avoided except where the Commission
determines that it is essential to provide for the separation of a residential
development from major streets to overcome a specific disadvantage due to
orientation or topography.
   (g)   Lots shall follow the Village boundary lines, whenever practical,
rather than cross them. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1125.07 WETLANDS AND FLOOD-PRONE AREAS.
   Each lot in a subdivision shall have sufficient buildable area to
accommodate a building and its requisite parking without locating either the
building or parking area within a flood plain or existing natural watercourse.
The applicant shall certify that the parcel in question is not subject
to flooding within a 100-year period.
   (a)   If a development or subdivision is located in an area having poor
drainage or other adverse physical characteristics, the Commission may approve
the development or subdivision, provided that the developer agrees to perform
improvements that will render the area safe for the intended use.
   (b)   Wetlands. In order to achieve the goals of wetland protection, the
Planning and Zoning Commission shall not approve any request that involves
dredging, filling, or construction in a delineated wetland area without proof
of acquisition of valid state and federal wetland development permits.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1127
Improvements
1127.01   Purpose.
1127.02   Compliance to specifications; inspection.
1127.03   Monuments.
1127.04   Street and sidewalk construction.
1127.05   Curbs and gutters.
1127.06   Street grading.
1127.07   Street lighting.
1127.08   Sanitary sewerage system.
1127.09   Stormwater drainage and storm sewers.
1127.10   Water system.
1127.11   Fire hydrants.
1127.12   Electric, gas, telephone and cable TV facilities.
1127.13   Street names and signs.
1127.14   Dedication of improvements.
1127.01 PURPOSE.
   This Chapter sets forth the minimum standards for improvements. The planning
principles and construction standards herein shall be applied with professional
skill and shall take advantage of the natural features of the site in order to
utilize the natural surface drainage, to economize the construction of sewers,
to reduce the amount of grading and to minimize destruction of trees and
topsoil. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.02 COMPLIANCE TO SPECIFICATIONS; INSPECTION.
   (a)   In addition to the requirements established by these regulations, all
subdivision plats shall comply with the design and specifications of pavement
base, wearing surfaces, curbs and gutters, materials and procedures, and
grading and drainage facilities established by the State of Ohio Department of
Transportation and approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission.
   (b)   All work shall be done under Village supervision and inspection and
shall be completed within the time set by the Village Engineer. All inspection
costs shall be paid by the developer or subdivider. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-
02.)
1127.03 MONUMENTS.
   The applicant shall place permanent reference monuments in the subdivision
as required below:
   (a)   Concrete posts measuring six (6) inches by six (6) inches by forty-
eight (48) inches with one-half (1½) inch iron rod cast in the center. Such
monuments shall be located as follows along the boundary of the subdivision:
      (1)   Along the right-of-way line at all street intersections.
      (2)    Along all street right-of-way lines and along straight lines not
more than 1,400 feet apart.
      (3)    At each end of all curves and at points where a curve changes its
radius.
      (4)    At all angle points in any line.
      (5)   Other points as are necessary to establish definitely all lines of
the plat.
   (b)   Permanent iron pins, at least thirty (30) inches long and three
quarters (3/4) of an inch in diameter, or similar suitable marker shall be
placed at all corners of each lot. Any contractor or person doing preliminary
or final grading, or ground work of any kind, shall be responsible for the
preservation of all such markers.
   (c)   Street monuments shall be set in suitable monument boxes.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.04 STREET AND SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Streets and sidewalks shall be constructed so as to serve the entire
development or subdivision, and such construction shall conform to the
provisions of these Subdivision Regulations.
   (b)   Where the widening, improving or abandoning of existing streets is
deemed necessary by the Village, the developer or subdivider shall perform such
work as is necessary at his or her expense.
   (c)   Sidewalk Construction.
      (1)   Sidewalks shall be constructed on four (4) inches of No. 57
Limestone Aggregate and consist of four (4) inches of Class "C" concrete or six
(6) inches of Class "C" concrete through driveways, and shall be four (4) feet
in width. Curb ramps shall be provided at all intersections and shall comply
with ODOT Standard Drawing BP-7.1.
      (2)    Sidewalks shall be placed a minimum of eighteen (18) inches from
the curb and shall have a transverse slope of one-fourth (1/4) inch per foot
with the low side adjacent to the roadway.
   (d)   Street Construction. All materials and construction procedures shall
be in accordance with the current "Construction and Materials Specifications"
of the State of Ohio Department of Transportation.
      (1)   Minor or local streets shall be constructed with flexible pavement:
six (6) inches of Type 404/301 asphaltic concrete on six (6) inches of No. 2
Aggregate all in strict accordance with the Typical Section and the State Ohio
Department of Transportation Construction and Material Specification, latest
Edition.
      (2)    Collector streets shall be constructed with flexible pavement; six
(6) inches of Type 404/301 asphaltic concrete on ten (10) inches of No. 57 No.
l and 2 Aggregate all in strict accordance with the Typical Section and the
State of Ohio Department of Transportation Construction and Material
Specifications, latest edition.
   
   (e)   Minimum street pavement widths shall conform to the standards set
forth in Section
1125.03(c). (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.05 CURBS AND GUTTERS.
   The requirements for curbs and gutters will vary according to the character
of the area and the density of the development. In areas of notable flash
flooding or heavy rain run-off, curbs may be required by the Planning and
Zoning Commission to channel the flow of water. Curbs shall be required in
commercial developments, or where other similar intensive urban uses exist.
Where curbs exist on abutting properties, their extension may be required by
the Planning and Zoning Commission throughout the subdivision. Curbs shall be
Type 6 or Type 3-B; Curb/Gutter shall be Type 2 and both shall comply with ODOT
Standard Drawing BP-5.1. Paved Gutters shall comply with Standard Drawing MC-
5 as required to meet field conditions. Curbs, curb/gutter and paved gutters
shall also comply with the following standards:
   (a)   Combination curb and gutter shall be constructed with flexible
pavement (type 3 or type 5).
   (b)   Any alternate type of curb must be approved as per typical section on
project plans.
   (c)   The crown shall be standard three-sixteenths (3/16) inch per foot.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.06 STREET GRADING.
   (a)   Streets shall be graded the width of the pavement plus six (6) feet on
each side. No street shall exceed a fifteen percent (15%) grade.
   (b)   Streets shall be graded in accordance with the current standards and
specifications on file in the office of the Village Engineer. Deviation from
this standard, due to special topographical conditions, will be allowed only
with the special approval of the Village Engineer and Planning and Zoning
Commission.
   (c)   All changes of grade shall be connected by vertical curves of
appropriate lengths.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.07 STREET LIGHTING.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission may require the developer or subdivider
to provide suitable conduits under pavements, including crosswalks,
intersections and cul-de-sacs, for the future installation of underground
wiring through those conduits necessary to serve street lighting fixtures at
places designated by the local power company and the Planning and Zoning
Commission. Appurtenances thereto shall be provided by the developer or
subdivider, and shall be post-type lights at intersections, cul-de-sacs and
crosswalks only, but shall be located no more than a maximum of 500 feet apart.
Such lights shall be located at each street intersection within the subdivision
and at other locations deemed necessary by the Village Engineer. Street lights
shall be designed, with appropriate lamps and reflectors, to minimize light
pollution.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.08 SANITARY SEWERAGE SYSTEM.
   The applicant shall install sanitary sewer facilities as required below:
   (a)    A sanitary sewerage system shall be constructed so as to serve the
entire development or subdivision.
   (b)    Sewer connections shall be extended to the property line of each lot
at the time sewer is laid and prior to paving.
   (c)    If, because of topography, a pumping station is necessary, this
facility shall be provided by the developer. This facility shall be included in
the plans and specifications submitted as part of the preliminary plat.
   (d)    Where a subdivision is located within the Village limits and
accessible to the Village system, public sanitary sewers shall be installed to
adequately serve all lots, including lateral connections to the public system.
Public sewer system extensions shall meet the requirements of the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency (OEPA) and applicable Village standards. When a
sewer system is not accessible the requirements of subsection (i) hereof shall
prevail.
   (e)   Bell and spigot polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe shall be used.
   (f)   All construction and materials shall be approved by the Village
Engineer and conform to the specifications of the Ohio Department of Health.
   (g)    Manholes shall be precast concrete and constructed in accordance with
the specifications of the State of Ohio Department of Transportation.
   (h)    No surface water or storm sewers shall be introduced into the
sanitary system. All downspouts shall be directed into the surface drainage
system.
   (i)    Where a public sanitary sewer system is not reasonably accessible,
the subdivider shall provide one of the following:
      (1)   A central treatment plant for the subdivision provided that such
central treatment plant is installed in accordance with State and Village
Health requirements.
      (2)   Lots may be served by individual disposal systems only with
approval of the appropriate state and local health officials.
         A.    Where the installation of individual disposal systems is
considered. the suitability of the soil for individual systems, the absorptive
ability of the soil, surface drainage, ground water level and topography shall
be the criteria for determining whether or not the installation of individual
systems is permissible. Criteria shall be in accordance with the requirements
of the Ohio Department of Health.
         B.    Each lot so served shall be of a size and shape to accommodate
the necessary length of tile field at a safe distance from and at a lower
elevation than the proposed building. Such lot size and shape shall conform to
the requirements of the zoning district in which it is located and these
subdivision regulations.
         C.    At least one percolation test shall be made for each lot area
being platted, and each test shall be located in close proximity to the
proposed individual sewage disposal unit, be numbered and its location shown on
the preliminary plat. All percolation tests shall be performed in accordance
with requirements of the appropriate State and local health officials.
         D.    Where the installation of individual disposal units is
considered and where the average natural ground slope exceeds ten percent
(10%), the installation of a step-up system may be required subject to the
specification of the local health official.
            (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.09 STORM WATER DRAINAGE AND STORM SEWERS.
   It is the intent of this section to provide surface drainage to all areas
and to prevent property damage, inconvenience and deterioration caused by
ponding water and flooding. The subdivider shall construct all necessary
facilities as determined by the Village Engineer and Planning and Zoning
Commission and the requirements set forth in this section.
   (a)   Stormwater management shall follow the standards established in
"Rainwater and Land Development: Ohio's Standards for Stormwater Management,
Land Development and Urban Stream Protection". Second Edition. 1996 (Department
of Natural Resources, Division of Soil and Water Conservation) or any later
version that is published as an update.
   (b)    Provision shall be made for adequate drainage of surface water,
either as a natural drainage course or a storm sewer system as approved by the
Village Engineer. All construction shall be carried out under Village
supervision. Storm water facilities shall include the following:
      (1)   Surface drainage systems.
      (2)    Storm sewers and tile systems.
      (3)    Storm water runoff control structures.
      (4)    Open ditches and diversion channels.
      (5)    Stormwater retention.
   (c)    All surface drainage facilities shall be connected to an adequate
drainage course.
   (d)    Catch basins shail comply to the standards of the State of Ohio
Department of Transportation designated 3-A catch basin or a modified type
approved by the Village Engineer.
   (e)    Adequate provision shall be made to provide a drainage outlet a
minimum of three (3) feet below the mean ground level for each lot.
   (f)    Grading.
      (1)    A grading plan shall be required of the entire subdivision for the
purpose of providing proper drainage. Such plan shall be approved by the
Village Engineer.
      (2)    The area around a residence shall be graded away from the
residence in such a manner as to allow surface runoff to escape from the
immediate area around a residence.
   (g)    When an adequate public storm sewer is available at the plat
boundary, the subdivider shall construct a storm sewer to connect with such
storm sewer line. If such a storm sewer is not accessible, natural drainage
channels with easements of adequate width shall be provided as determined by
the Village or County Engineer and approved by the Planning and Zoning
Commission and shall connect to an adequate drainage outlet.
   (h)    Easements For Drainage. Storm sewers shall be located within the
right-of-way or within an easement. Whenever any stream or important surface
drainage course is located in an area being subdivided, the subdivider shall
provide an adequate easement along each side of the stream or ditch for the
purpose of widening, deepening, sloping, improving and maintaining the drainage
course and such easement shall be dedicated to the Village or other appropriate
public agency. Such easements shall not be less than thirty (30) feet.
   (i)    When, in the opinion of the Village Engineer, the natural watercourse
receiving storm sewer discharge is not adequate, the developer or subdivider
shall, at his or her expense, undertake to give such natural watercourse the
directional and capacity control as may be deemed necessary, even though such
work lies outside the boundaries of his or her development or subdivision. The
developer or subdivider shall acquire such permission as is necessary to
construct drainage structures, ditches, etc., outside the boundaries of his or
her development or subdivision.
   (j)    Whenever the construction of streets and the required storm water
drainage is such that the direction of storm water flow is diverted to affect
surrounding property, the subdivider shall obtain adequate drainage easements
to provide for efficient disposal of surface water.
   (k)    Bridge and Culverts. Where natural drainage channels intersect any
street right-of- way, it shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to have
satisfactory bridges and/or culverts constructed. Where culverts are required,
minimum requirements shall be observed as follows:
      (1)   All bridges and culverts shall be designed according to Ohio
Department of Transportation design standards.
      (2)    All culverts shall extend for an adequate distance to accommodate
the required roadway embankment slopes. The cover over the culvert and its
capacity shall be determined by the developer's professional engineer and
approved by the County or Village Engineer. The minimum diameter of the culvert
pipe shall be twelve (12) inches.
      (3)    Depending on existing conditions headwalls may be required.
      (4)    Driveway culverts shall have a minimum length of twenty (20) feet
and a minimum diameter of twelve (12) inches. The driveway culverts shall be
laid so as to maintain the flow lines of the ditch or gutter.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.10 WATER SYSTEM.
   (a)   The water system shall be constructed so as to serve the entire
development or subdivision.
   (b)   Where the public water supply is reasonably accessible in the
determination of the Village Engineer and Planning and Zoning Commission, the
subdivision shall be provided with a complete water distribution system,
including a connection for each lot and fire hydrants where permitted or
required. Public water distribution and public well systems shall meet the
requirements of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency (OEPA) as cited in the
Ohio Revised Code and the Village's "Rules and Regulations for Water Service",
latest revision.
   (c)    All taps shall be made and extended to the property line at the time
the pipe is laid and prior to paving.
   (d)    Materials and construction methods shall conform to the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency (OEPA) specifications and Village regulations,
and be approved by the Village Engineer.
   
   (e)    Where public water supply is not available, the subdivider shall
provide acceptable evidence of the availability of water. If such evidence is
deemed not acceptable, the subdivider may be required to make one or more test
wells in the area to be platted. Chemical analysis may be required. Copies of
well logs to be submitted as evidence of the availability of water in the area
to be platted shall include the name and address of the well driller and shall
be submitted to the
Planning and Zoning Commission.
   (f)   Individual private wells shall be located at least fifteen (15) feet
from property lines, fifty (50) feet from all septic tanks; fifty (50) feet
from all tile fields and other sewage facilities; fifteen (15) feet from all
sewer line; and shall not be located within any areas of flooding. As a
precaution to seepage, a watertight seal shall be provided around the well
casing. Minimum lot sizes shall be accordance with this Planning and Zoning
Code. In all cases where it has been determined that individual water supplies
from private wells are not feasible, a public water distribution system shall
be required. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.11 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (a)   Fire hydrants with two and one-half (2½) inch outlets and one large
pumping connection shall be provided by the subdivider in all subdivisions with
public water supplies.
   (b)   Hydrants shall be located between property lines and curbs with all
outlets facing or parallel to the street. Hydrants shall be placed at the
corners of all blocks and at mid-block for blocks exceeding 800 feet in length.
Hydrants shall also be required at the entrance and end of all cul-de-sacs
exceeding 400 feet in length.
   (c)   Hydrants shall be located at all low points and at all high points
with adequate means of drainage provided.
   (d)   Hydrants shall be spaced to provide necessary fire flow. Hydrants
shall be spaced so that each residence shall be within 250 feet of a hydrant.
   (e)   The type of hydrant, size of the water lines serving the hydrant,
control valves and the location of the hydrant in all subdivisions within the
corporate limits shall be in strict accordance with the "Rules and Regulations
for Water Service”, latest addition.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.12 ELECTRIC, GAS, TELEPHONE AND CABLE TV FACILITIES.
   (a)   Electric service and telephone service shall be provided within each
subdivision. Gas service may be required where reasonably accessible. Whenever
such facilities are reasonably accessible and available, they may be required
to be installed within the area prior to the approval of the final plat. In all
cases, electric, telephone, street lighting wires, conduits and cables shall be
installed underground except in cases where the Village Engineer determines
that topographic, bedrock, or underground water conditions would result in
excessive costs to the subdivider. When a development is on an existing street
with aboveground service lines, such utilities shall be underground from the
street to the house.
   (b)   All utilities, including gas, electric, water, storm and sanitary
sewers, telephone and cable T.V. may be placed on any right-of-way and such
shall be done before any curb and gutter or paving is placed.
   (c)   Utility Easements. Easements for the establishment of electric gas,
sewer, telephone, cable and water lines shall be provided in all subdivisions.
      (1)   The location of utility line easements within the road right-of-way
shall be located outside of the improved portion of the roadway. Utility
easements may also be located along the front lot line or center of the rear or
side lot line as necessary for utility lines. Easements shall give access to
every lot, park or public grounds.
      (2)   Easements shall have a width of ten (10) feet measured on each side
of the lot line, or such additional widths as may be required for necessary
access to the utility involved. Five (5) foot easements shall be required on
each side of an alley to accommodate pole lines.
      (3)    Whenever a sanitary sewer line and electric and/or telephone line
are each placed underground in the same utility easement, the total easement
width shall not be less than twenty (20) feet.
   (d)    Whenever a major gas transmission line is on or adjacent to property
proposed to be subdivided, adequate measures shall be taken to insure that all
buildable sites are at a minimum safe distance from the transmission line
easement, as recommended by the gas transmission company and the Public
Utilities Commission of Ohio.
   (e)   Overhead utility lines, where permitted, shall be located at the rear
of all lots. The width of the easement per lot shall not be less than ten (10)
feet and the total easement width shall not be less than twenty (20) feet.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.13 STREET NAMES AND SIGNS.
   (a)    Signs shall be erected by the subdivider at all road intersections.
House numbers will be assigned by the Zoning Inspector.
   (b)    Street name signs shall be furnished and installed by the developer
in accordance with the following standards:
      (1)   The letters and numerals shall be of uniform height and shall be
set on a reflecting material.
      (2)    Signs shall be mounted at a height of approximately seven (7) feet
above the top of the curb.
      (3)    Placement of signs shall be in accordance with the "Ohio Manual of
Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways" and shall be placed
on diagonally opposite corners, on the far right-hand side of the intersection
for traffic on the more heavily traveled street, and as close to the corner as
possible.
   (c)   Whenever a new street is constructed along the approximate alignment
or extension of an existing street, its name shall be the same as that of the
existing street.
   (d)    Whenever a cul-de-sac street serves not more than three (3) lots, the
name of the intersecting street shall apply to the cul-de-sac.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1127.14 DEDICATION OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   The developer or subdivider shall offer for dedication to public use,
without compensation, all storm and sanitary sewers, water systems, streets,
sidewalks, street lighting and facilities and appurtenances thereto, unless the
improvement is otherwise permitted by the Planning and Zoning Commission to
remain under private ownership.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
TITLE FIVE - District Regulations
      Chap.
