CHAPTER 1131
Districts Established; Annexation
1131.01   Purpose.
1131.02   Districts established.
1131.03   Zoning district map.
1131.04   Interpretation of district boundaries.
1131.05   Annexation.
1131.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Chapter is to establish zoning districts in order to
realize the general purpose set forth in this Planning and Zoning Code, to
provide for orderly growth and development, and to protect the property rights
of all individuals by assuring the compatibility of uses and practices within
districts.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
   
1131.02 DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED.
   The following zoning districts are hereby established for the Village of
Mingo Junction, Jefferson County, Ohio:
   (a)    Residential Districts.
      R-1A Single Family Residential District
      R-1 Single Family Residential District
      R-2 Single and Two Family Residential District
      R-3 Multi-Family Residential District.
   (b)    Business Districts.
      B-1 Downtown Business District
      B-2 Limited Business District
      B-3 General Business District
   (c)   Industrial Districts.
      I-1 Light Industrial District
      I-2 Heavy Industrial District
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1131.03 ZONING DISTRICT MAP.
   The districts established in Section
1131.02 are bounded and defined as shown on the map entitled "Village of Mingo
Junction Zoning Map", which, together with all accompanying notations,
references, rules and designations, is hereby adopted and made a part of this
Planning and Zoning Code, thereby having the same force and effect as if herein
fully described in writing. The Village of Mingo Junction Zoning Map and all
its future additions, amendments, changes and supplements, designates the area
assigned to the respective use districts and their boundaries.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1131.04 INTERPRETATION OF DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.
   The following rules shall be used to determine the precise location of any
zoning district boundary unless such boundary is specifically indicated on the
Zoning Map of the Village of Mingo Junction.
   (a)   Where Boundaries Approximately Follow Streets, Alleys or Highways.
Where district boundaries are so indicated as approximately following the
center lines, right-of-way lines, or street lines of highways, streets, or
railroad lines, such center lines, right-of-way lines or street lines shall be
construed to be said boundaries.
   (b)   Where Boundaries Approximately Follow Lot Lines. Where district
boundaries are so indicated that they approximately follow the lot lines, such
lot lines shall be construed to be said boundaries.
   (c)   Where Boundaries Parallel Street Lines, Alley Lines or Highway Right-
of-Way Lines. Where district boundaries are so indicated that they are
approximately parallel to the center lines, right-of-way lines, or streetlines
of highways, streets, or railroad lines, such district boundaries shall be
construed as being parallel thereto and at such distance therefrom as indicated
on the Zoning Map of the Village of Mingo Junction. If no distance is given,
such dimensions shall be determined by the use of the scale shown on such
zoning map.
   (d)   Where Boundaries Approximately Follow Municipality Limits. Where
district boundaries are so indicated that they follow or approximately follow
the limits of the municipality, such boundaries shall be construed as following
such limits.
   (e)   Extension of District Where Lot Divided. Where a district boundary
line established in this Planning and Zoning Code or as shown on the Zoning Map
divides a lot which was in single ownership at the time of enactment of this
Planning and Zoning Code, the use authorized thereon and the other district
requirements applying to the most restricted portion of such lot under this
Planning and Zoning Code shall be considered as extending to the entire lot.
   (f)   Vacation of Public Ways. Whenever any street, or other public way is
vacated by the action of the Planning and Zoning Commission and with the
approval of the Village Council, the zoning district adjoining each side of
such thoroughfare, street or other public way shall automatically be extended
to the center of such vacation, and all areas within that vacation shall
thereforth be subject to all regulations appropriate to the respective extended
districts.
   (g)   Resolving Disputes. Any dispute regarding a zone district line shall
be heard by the Board of Zoning Appeals. In the event the Board finds the zone
district line is not consistent with the purposes and intent of this Planning
and Zoning Code, the Board shall prepare an appropriate recommendation to
Council.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1131.05 ANNEXATION.
   Upon annexation of township territory to the Village of Mingo Junction the
township zoning regulations then in effect shall remain in full force and shall
be enforced by the township officials until the Mingo Junction Village Council
adopts zoning regulations for the property. As an alternative to the procedures
set forth in Chapter
1117, Council may, after a report and recommendation by the Mingo Junction
Village Planning and Zoning Commission, by resolution made at or prior to the
time of its acceptance of township territory for annexation, classify all or
any part of territory annexed to the Village in such other district or
districts as Council may determine. Such resolution shall be passed by a
majority vote of all members of Council, except when the classification of
districts by Council is contrary to the report and recommendation of the
Planning and Zoning Commission, in which event the same shall not become
effective except by the favorable vote of four-fifths (4/5) of all members of
Council. Such resolution shall not be passed as an emergency measure. (Ord.
2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1133
Residential District Regulation
1133.01   Purpose.
1133.02   Permitted uses.
1133.03   Schedule of permitted uses.
1133.04   Lot area and width requirements for principal uses.
1133.05   Minimum yard requirements for principal uses.
1133.06   Height requirements.
1133.07   Additional requirements for multi-family dwellings.
1133.08   Accessory use regulations.
1133.09   Family day care home, type “B”.
1133.10   Home occupations.
1133.01 PURPOSE.
   The R-1 A, R-1, R-2 and R-3 Single-Family, Two-Family and Multi-Family
Residential Districts are established to accomplish the general purpose of this
Planning and Zoning Code as stated in Chapter
1101 and to achieve the following objectives:
   (a)    To promote the stability of existing residential development and to
protect adjacent properties from unreasonable construction.
   (b)   To regulate the bulk and location of dwellings to obtain proper
privacy and useable open spaces.
   (c)    To provide for proper location of institutions and other community
facilities so as to increase the general convenience, safety and amenities
within the community.
   (d)   To carry out the following specific purposes:
      (1)    The R-lA Single-Family Residential district is intended to provide
for single-family residential development having a minimum lot size of 12,000
square feet to provide locations for new single-family residential development.
      (2)    The R-1 Single-Family Residential district is designed to retain
and provide areas of medium density development characteristically and
exclusively for single-family dwelling units.
      (3)   The R-2 Single and Two-Family Residential district is designed to
retain and provide areas for the co-mingling of single-family dwelling units
and two-family dwelling units.
      (4)   The R-3 Multi-Family Residential district is intended to provide
locations for multi-family dwelling units.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1133.02 PERMITTED USES.
   In the R-1 A, R-1, R-2 and R-3 Residential Districts, land shall be used or
occupied, and structures shall be erected, reconstructed, enlarged, moved or
structurally altered only in accordance with the schedules and use regulations
of this Planning and Zoning Code.
   (a)    Uses Permitted by Right. A use listed in Schedule
1133.03 shall be permitted by right as a principal use in a district when
denoted by the letter "P" provided that all requirements of other Village
ordinances and this Planning and Zoning Code have been met.
   (b)    Conditional Uses. A use listed in Schedule
1133.03 shall be permitted as a conditional use in a district when denoted by
the letters "CU", provided the Planning and Zoning Commission first makes the
determination that the requirements of Chapter
1161 have been met, according to the procedures set forth in Chapter
1111.
   (c)    Accessory Uses. A use listed in Schedule
1133.03 shall be permitted as an accessory use in a district when denoted by
the letter "A". Such use shall be permitted as a subordinate use when it is
clearly incidental to and located on the same lot as the principal building or
use. Accessory uses are further regulated in subsequent sections of this
Planning and Zoning Code.
   (d)    Uses Not Listed in Schedule. Although a use may be indicated as a
permitted, principal, conditional or accessory use in a particular residential
district, it shall not be approved on a parcel unless it can be located thereon
in full compliance with all of the standards and other regulations of this
Planning and Zoning Code applicable to the specific use and parcel in question.
Any use not specifically listed as either a permitted, principal or conditional
use shall be a prohibited use in these zoning districts and shall only be
permitted upon amendment of this Planning and Zoning Code and/or the Village of
Mingo Junction Zoning Map as provided in Chapter
1117, or upon a finding by the Planning and Zoning Commission or Zoning
Inspector that a use is substantially similar to a principally permitted or
conditionally permitted use in the district according to the procedures set
forth in Section
1111.10.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)

specified in Schedule

   (b)    Front Yards on Partially Built-up Blocks. Whenever fifty (50%)

1133.05, then the minimum required front yard shall be the average of the

   (c)    Each yard shall be unobstructed by any structure except as otherwise

zoning lot not covered by permitted structures, shall be landscaped with grass,
trees, shrubbery and, or other appropriate ground cover or landscaping
material, which shall be adequately maintained, so as to assure absorption of
rainfall, and to prevent erosion from rapid runoff of surface water.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1133.06 HEIGHT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   In the R-1 A, R-1, R-2 and R-3 Residential Districts, the height of
principal buildings shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet and the height of
accessory buildings and structures shall not exceed eighteen (18) feet, except
as otherwise permitted below.
   (b)    The height limitations in this Chapter shall not apply to restrict
the height of chimneys, water towers, scenery lofts, cupolas, domes, spires,
belfries, antennae and necessary mechanical appurtenances when attached to and
part of a permitted structure, provided the height of such appurtenances does
not extend more than ten (10) feet above the height limitations of the zone
district.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1133.07 ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR MULTI-FAMILY DWELLINGS.
   In the R-3 Multi-Family district, when more than one principal building is
located on a lot, the buildings shall be designed and arranged in accordance
with the following:
   (a)    For the purpose of determining the yard requirements, the development
shall be considered as one building occupying one parcel and shall comply with
the setback requirements set forth in Schedule
1133.05.
   (b)    In order to ensure reasonable privacy and separation, the distance
between building walls shall comply with the following:
      (1)   A minimum separation of forty (40) feet between buildings shall be
required when one of the adjacent walls contains primary window(s) of a living
area or has access to terraces, decks or patios.
      (2)    A minimum separation of ten (10) feet between buildings shall be
required when neither of the adjacent walls contains primary window(s) of a
living area.
   (c)    For the purposes of this section:
      (1)    Living areas shall include the following rooms or spaces:
bedrooms, dens, living rooms, etc. Kitchen and dining areas are not subject to
these requirements.
      (2)    Primary windows shall be those windows on the wall of the living
area that has the largest amount of area. When two (2) walls have equal window
area either wall may be considered as having the primary windows.
   (d)    There shall be a minimum separation of ten (10) feet between
principal buildings and accessory buildings and structures.
   (e)    All accessory buildings, carports and parking areas shall comply with
the yard requirements set forth in Schedule
1133.05.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1133.08 ACCESSORY USE REGULATIONS.
   Only accessory uses that are incidental to a principal use are permitted,
provided such accessory use complies with the provisions set forth in this
Section.
   (a)    Minimum Yard Requirements for Accessory Buildings and Structures.
Accessory buildings and structures shall comply with the minimum yard
requirements set forth in Schedule
1133.08. Any accessory building attached to the dwelling unit shall conform to
the yard requirements of the lot.

Notes to Schedule
1133.08:
(a) Including all lot lines that abut a street on a corner lot.
(b) But in no case shall such structure extend more than ten (10) feet into a
required front yard.
(c) See also Section
1133.08(d) for regulations governing the height of fences.
   (b)    Maximum Coverage of Rear Yard. The total area of all detached
accessory buildings and structures, including garages, swimming pools. patios,
and storage sheds that are located in the rear yard shall not exceed thirty
percent (30%) of the rear yard area. For the purposes of this section, all
measurements shall be based on the foundation.
   (c)   Minimum Distance Between Accessory Buildings and Structures. No
accessory building or structure shall be built within five (5) feet of any
other accessory building or structure on the parcel.
   (d)    Walls and Fences. Fences and wails shall be constructed according to
the requirements set forth in this subsection.
      (1)   Permit Required. A fence or any extension thereof, in either height
or length, shall be deemed a structure and shall require a permit. A plot plan
showing lot lines, the location of the fence and any other structures on the
plot shall be presented before any permit is issued.
      (2)   Fence Requirements.
         A.    Rear and Side Yard. Any fence erected behind the front building
line shall not exceed six (6) feet in height.
         B.    Front Yard. Any fence erected in front of the building line
shall comply with the following requirements:
            1.    The fence shall not exceed three (3) feet in height.
            2.    Fences shall be designed with at least fifty percent (50%) of
the vertical surface open. Openness is the percentage of the fence surface that
is void of material and through which both light and air may pass when viewed
from a ninety (90) degree angle. The openings of fences shall be evenly spaced
throughout the vertical surface. Examples of such fences include but are not
limited to, picket and ranch style fences, including split rail fences.
            3.    Chain link, light wire mesh (such as "chicken wire"), "snow
fences" and fences made of similar materials shall not be permitted in front of
the building line.
      (3)    General Standards.
         A.    All walls and fences shall be located entirely on the property
of the owner of the fence.
         B.    Fences, gates, doors and other obstructions shall not swing
across or over a sidewalk or public right-of-way.
         C.   No fence shall be constructed, without Village authorization,
within a utility right-of-way. Any fence constructed within a utility right-of-
way or inhibiting access to such right-of-way may be removed by the Village and
the cost of such removal may be charged against those parties having an
interest in the fence.
         D.   All fences shall be designed, constructed and finished so that
the supporting members face the property of the owner of the fence. All fences
shall be maintained in good condition, be structurally sound and attractively
finished at all times.
   (e)    Swimming Pools. Private swimming pools for the exclusive use of
residents of the premise may be located in any Residential District provided
they comply with the accessory building setback requirements set forth in
Schedule
1133.09 and the supplemental regulations set forth below.
      (1)   All swimming pools, together with adjacent walkways, shall be
enclosed by a wall or fence having a minimum height of four (4) feet.
      (2)    All fences and other pool enclosures shall be constructed so as to
have no openings, holes, or gaps larger than three (3) inches in width, except
for doors, gates or windows, which shall be equipped with suitable locking
devices to prevent unauthorized access. Secured accessory buildings and walls
of principal buildings may be used in place of, or as part of, the enclosure.
      (3)    The construction and operation of a pool shall meet all other
applicable Village regulations.
   (f)   Signs. Signs shall be permitted in accordance with Chapter
1165.
   (g)    Parking and Storage of Vehicles. Parking and vehicle storage shall be
provided according to Chapter
1167.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1133.09 FAMILY DAY CARE HOME, TYPE "B".
   This Planning and Zoning Code recognizes that the availability of safe and
affordable, good quality child day care is important to the well being of
parents and children. Furthermore, it is the purpose of this section to
regulate the operation of child day care in a manner that preserves the
residential character of neighborhoods.
   (a)    A type "B" family day care home is a permanent residence of the
provider where child care is provided for one (1) to six (6) children and where
no more than three (3) children are under two (2) years of age. For the purpose
of this definition, any children under six (6) years of age who are related to
the provider and who are on the premises of the day care home shall be counted.
   (b)    According to ORC §5104.054, any type "B" family day care home,
whether certified or not certified by the county director of human services,
shall be considered to be a residential use of property for purposes of zoning
and shall be a permitted use in all zoning districts in which residential uses
are permitted.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1133.10 HOME OCCUPATIONS.
   The purpose of this section is to set forth regulations which control the
establishment and operation of home occupations. The intent of these
regulations is to control the nonresidential use of a residential dwelling unit
so that the nonresidential use is limited to an accessory use, and shall not in
any way adversely affect the uses permitted in the residential district of
which they are a part. Compliance with these regulations is expected to result
in all home occupations being located and conducted in such a manner that their
existence is not detectable in any manner from the outside of the dwelling
unit.
   (a)    The home occupation shall be clearly incidental and subordinate to
the residential use of the property.
   (b)    No sign or display, except for a nameplate sign shall be permitted
which indicates, from the exterior, that the building is being used for any
purpose other than that of a dwelling.
   (c)   Only persons residing on the premises shall operate or be employed in
the home occupation.
   (d)    A home occupation shall occupy no more than twenty-five percent (25%)
of the floor area of the dwelling.
   (e)    No commodity shall be sold on the premises, except that which is
prepared on the premises.
   (f)    The business activity, including the storage of equipment, supplies
or any apparatus used in the home occupation, shall be conducted entirely
within the dwelling unit.
   (g)    The operation of the home occupation shall not be injurious, noxious
or offensive to the neighborhood.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1135
Planned Residential Development Regulations
1135.01   Purpose.
1135.02   Approval of planned residential developments.
1135.03   Minimum project area.
1135.04   Dwelling types.
1135.05   Density and open space regulations.
1135.06   Restricted open space requirements.
1135.07   Development and site planning standards.
1135.08   Street, drive and walkway requirements.
1135.09   Supplemental requirements.
1135.10   Homeowners associations.
1135.11   Phased development.
1135.12   Development plan approval.
1135.01 PURPOSE.
   Planned residential developments (PRDs) shall be permitted in an R-lA or R-
1 residential district to encourage and accommodate creative and imaginative
developments that provide alternative housing types and the preservation of
open space in a unified project. These regulations are designed to achieve,
among others, the following objectives:
   (a)    To encourage the flexible arrangement of a residential development.
   (b)    To promote creative and efficient use of land in a unified
development.
   (c)   To promote economical and efficient use of land and reduce
infrastructure costs through unified development.
   (d)    To permit the flexible spacing of lots and buildings in order to
encourage the provision of readily accessible open space and recreation areas;
and the creation of functional and interesting residential areas.
   (e)    To ensure that planned residential developments are compatible with
surrounding single-family neighborhoods and comply with these objectives by
requiring the submission of development plans and establishing a review process
to ensure that all developments are consistent with these regulations.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.02 APPROVAL OF PLANNED RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENTS.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall review a proposed PRD to ensure
that:
   (a)    Buildings and uses within the development shall be located so as to
reduce any adverse effect and to protect the character of the neighborhood and
adjacent property, and the property values in the area.
   (b)    The plan will incorporate adequate safeguards, screening, fences and
landscaping to protect and maintain harmony with the surrounding area.
   (c)   The plan will provide traffic access ways, interior circulation ways
and parking spaces as required for the district in which it is located and the
layout of such shall be designed and located to protect the residential
character of areas adjacent to the development.
   (d)   The plan provides for the use and continuous maintenance of the
restricted open space as public park or playground if Council will accept such
land, or as land common to all properties or controlled by a nonprofit
corporation composed of all present and future owners of all property within
the proposed development and provision is made for the recording of such with
each deed and a bond posted to assure compliance.
   (e)   The property is provided with adequate access to transportation, a
public water supply, waste disposal, fire and police protection, and other
needed public facilities and services.
   (f)   The plan will cause no undue traffic congestion or create unnecessary
traffic hazards in the surrounding neighborhood than would otherwise be created
with conventional subdivision development.
   (g)   The plan will not otherwise impair the public health, safety, morals,
convenience, comfort, prosperity or other aspects of the general welfare.
   (h)   The plan is in accordance with the general intent of this Planning and
Zoning Code.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.03 MINIMUM PROJECT AREA.
   The area proposed to be developed as a PRD shall be in one ownership, or if
in several ownerships, the application shall be filed jointly by all owners of
the properties included in the proposed PRD boundaries. The gross area of a
tract of land in a PRD shall be not less than five
(5) acres. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.04 DWELLING TYPES.
   The types of dwelling units that may be included as part of a PRD are listed
below in Schedule
1135.04, for the district in which the PRD is located.

1135.05 DENSITY AND OPEN SPACE REGULATIONS.
   The number of dwelling units permitted and the amount of restricted open
space provided as part of a PRD shall comply with the following:
   (a)    Maximum Density. The gross density of a PRD shall not exceed the
maximum number of dwelling units per acre set forth below in Schedule
1135.05 for the district in which the PRD is located. The maximum number of
dwelling units permitted for a particular site shall be calculated by:
      (1)   Deducting from the total project area any public right-of-way
within the project boundary existing at the time the development plan is
submitted.
      (2)    Multiplying the result of subsection (1) by the maximum number of
dwelling units set forth in Schedule
1135.05.
   (b)   Minimum Restricted Open Space. A portion of the total project area
shall be devoted to restricted open space in compliance with the minimum
requirement set forth below in Schedule
1135.05 for the district in which the PRD is located.
Schedule
1135.05

2. Minimum restricted open 20% of project area       15% of project area
space
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.06 RESTRICTED OPEN SPACE REQUIREMENTS.
   The restricted open space shall comply with the following:
   (a)   General Standards.
      (1)    The restricted open space shall be located and designed to the
satisfaction of the Planning and Zoning Commission and shall:
         A.    Be sufficiently aggregated to create large areas of planned open
space;
         B.    Conserve significant topographic and landscape natural features
to the extent practicable;
         C.    Be easily accessible to residents of the PRD;
         D.    Be not less than fifty (50) feet in width at any point;
         E.    Be connected by open space corridors with open space areas on
abutting parcels wherever possible.
      (2)    Land area devoted to the following shall not be included as
meeting the restricted open space requirement:
         A.    Public rights-of-way and private streets;
         B.    Parking areas, access drives, common drives and driveways,
except as otherwise permitted by the Planning and Zoning Commission when
providing access to the restricted open space;
         C.    Required setbacks from the project boundaries and public streets
for buildings and parking areas unless the required setback is contiguous to
and part of a larger area of restricted open space;
         D.    Required spacing between buildings and between buildings and
parking areas;
         E.    Private yards within subdivided lots;
         F.    A minimum of fifteen (15) feet between buildings and restricted
open space.
      (3)    Areas designated for restricted open space purposes may be:
         A.    Preserved in their natural state as woodlands, meadows, historic
lands, environmentally sensitive areas, or similar conservation oriented areas;
         B.    Used for outdoor active or passive recreation for the use and/or
enjoyment of the residents of the proposed development. Any restricted open
space intended to be devoted to recreational activities shall be of a usable
size and shape for the intended purposes as determined by the Planning and
Zoning Commission. Where deemed appropriate by the Planning and Zoning
Commission, recreation areas shall be provided with sufficient parking and
appropriate access; or
         C.    Utilized for fanning when authorized in a conservation easement
or in the Association's covenants and restrictions.
      (4)   Any area within the restricted open space that is disturbed during
construction or otherwise not preserved in its natural state, shall be
landscaped with vegetation that is compatible with the natural characteristics
of the site.
      (5)    Such restricted open space, including any recreational facilities
proposed to be constructed in such space, shall be clearly shown on the
development plan.
   (b)   Prohibition of Further Subdivision of Restricted Open Space.
Restricted open space shall be prohibited from further subdivision or
development by deed restriction, conservation easement, or other agreement in a
form acceptable to the Mingo Junction Village Solicitor and duly recorded in
the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Jefferson County.
   (c)   Ownership of Restricted Open Space. Subject to such permanent
restriction as set forth above, restricted open space may be owned by an
association, the Village, a land trust or other conservation organization
recognized by the Village.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.07 DEVELOPMENT AND SITE PLANNING STANDARDS.
   The following specific development standards shall be adhered to in the
design and layout of any PRD.
   (a)   Minimum Setbacks. All buildings, structures and parking areas shall
comply with the minimum setbacks set forth in Schedule
1135.07 for the district in which the PRO is located.
   (b)   Minimum Spacing Between Buildings. In order to ensure reasonable
privacy and separation, individual buildings including terraces, decks and
patios shall be separated by the minimum spacing set forth in Schedule
1135.07. These distances may be reduced when the Planning and Zoning Commission
finds that adequate landscaping and screening is provided to ensure privacy
between units and that sufficient space is provided for the proper maintenance
of the area, and for landscaping (including ground cover) to survive.

   (c)    Lot Requirements.
      (1)   Dwelling units are not required to be on lots. However, when lots
for standard detached single-family dwelling units or sublots for single-family
cluster or attached dwelling units are included as part of a PRD, such lots or
sublots shall be of sufficient size and shape to accommodate dwelling units in

      (2)    The applicant shall depict on the development plan the maximum

         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.08 STREET, DRIVE AND WALKWAY REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   General Street Design Criteria.
      (1)    The area of the proposed project devoted to streets and related
pavement should be the minimum necessary to provide adequate and safe movement
through the development.
      (2)    Street alignments should follow natural contours and be designed
to conserve natural features.
      (3)    The design and layout of the public streets, private streets and
common drives shall provide adequate and safe access to the intended units, as
determined by the Mingo Junction Police and Fire Departments.
   
   (b)   Street and Drive Requirements.
      (1)   All streets shall be required to be a public, dedicated street when
such street:
         A.    Provides access to detached single-family dwellings on a
subdivided lot.
         B.    Is a major street that connects two (2) existing public streets,
is intended to provide a future continuing street system beyond the project
boundaries, or is expected to accommodate pass-through traffic going to and
from adjacent developments.
      (2)    Streets that are not otherwise required to be public streets
pursuant to subsection (1) above may be approved as private streets.
         A.    The Planning and Zoning Commission may approve private streets
when the private street is not planned or expected to be extended to serve
property outside the planned residential development.
         B.    All elements of a private street that are to be provided in a
planned residential development shall be constructed in accordance with the
construction standards set forth for public streets in the Subdivision
Regulations.
      (3)    Common drives shall be permitted in compliance with the following
requirements:
         A.    A common drive shall serve no more than four (4) units.
         B.    A common drive shall extend from a public street and shall not
connect to any other existing or planned public street.
         C.    All common drives shall be paved and have a minimum width of
twelve (12) feet.
      (4)    Right-of-ways are not required for private streets and common
drives; however, a utility easement may be required along the length of the
common drive.
      (5)    Whenever a private street or common drive is included in a planned
residential development, deed restrictions shall be required and shall
specifically include the following language:
         "The undersigned grantee(s) hereby acknowledge(s) that (he, she, they)
understand that the premises described herein is located upon a nondedicated or
common drive. And further, the grantee(s) understands that no government body
is responsible for care and maintenance of said common drive."
   (c)   Pedestrian Circulation and Walkways. A pedestrian circulation system
shall be included in the PRD. The system shall provide convenient pedestrian
access throughout the PRD. Walkways shall be constructed according to the
standards set forth in the Mingo Junction Subdivision Regulations. (Ord. 2002-
2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.09 SUPPLEMENTAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Privacy for individual principal buildings shall be maintained through
the use of landscaping and screening.
   (b)   Street lighting and street signs shall be adequate for safety and
security.
   (c)   Stormwater detention shall be required for any development.
   (d)   All utilities required to serve a development shall be located
underground.
   (e)   Additional development requirements formulated to achieve the
objectives of this Chapter may be established at the time the PRD development
plan is reviewed. Any such development requirements adopted with such plan
shall become binding land use requirements for the proposed PRD.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.10 HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATIONS.
   As part of a planned residential development, a homeowners association,
community association, condominium association or similar legal entity shall be
created so that such association is responsible for the maintenance and control
of common areas, including the required restricted open space, private streets
and common drives.
   (a)    The Village Solicitor shall determine that, based on documents
submitted with the development plan, the association's bylaws or code of
regulations specify the following requirements:
      (1)   Membership in the Association shall be mandatory for all purchasers
of lots in the development or units in a condominium.
      (2)    The association shall be responsible for maintenance, control, and
insurance of restricted open space and common areas.
      (3)    The Association shall have the power to impose assessments on
members for the maintenance, control and insurance of restricted open space and
common areas, and have the power to place liens against individual properties
for failure to pay assessments.
   (b)    The Association shall not authorize its dissolution or the sale,
transfer or other disposal of any common area. including restricted open space.
Without (i) an affirmative vote of seventy-five percent (75%) of its members,
(ii) having established a successor entity to take over said property pursuant
to the Village's Planning and Zoning Code; and (iii) the approval of the
Village Council.
   (c)   The Association shall convey to the Village and other appropriate
governmental bodies, after proper notice, the right to enter any common area
for emergency purposes or in the event of nonperformance of maintenance or
improvements affecting the public health, safety and welfare. Such governments
shall have the right, after proper notice, to make improvements and perform
maintenance functions. In addition, the Village shall have the right to proceed
against the Association for reimbursements of said costs, including the right
to file liens against individual condominium units, houses and vacant building
lots.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1135.11 PHASED DEVELOPMENT.
   If development is to be implemented in phases, each phase shall have
adequate provision for access, parking, storm water management, and other
public improvements to serve the development in accordance with the applicable
criteria set forth above. Each phase shall be provided with temporary or
permanent transitional features, buffers, or protective areas in order
to prevent any adverse impact on completed phases, future phases. and adjoining
property.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
   1135.12 DEVELOPMENT PLAN APPROVAL.
   The applicant for a planned residential development shall submit development
plans in accordance with Chapter
1107.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1137
Business District Regulations
1137.01   Purpose.
1137.02   Use regulations.
1137.03   Schedule of permitted uses.
1137.04   Lot requirements.
1137.05   Building setback, spacing and height requirements.
1137.06   Off-street parking regulations.
1137.07   Outdoor display.
1137.08   Supplemental regulations for gasoline stations and auto service
stations.
1137.09   Accessory use regulations.
1137.10   Landscaping and screening requirements.
1137.11   Development plan review.
1137.01 PURPOSE.
   The B-1, B-2 and B-3 Business Districts are established to accomplish the
general purpose of this Planning and Zoning Code as stated in Chapter 1101 and
to achieve the following objectives:
   (a)    To provide appropriate and convenient locations for business
activities and the exchange of goods and services.
   (b)    To protect residential neighborhoods adjacent to business uses by
restricting the types of establishments, particularly at the common boundaries,
that would create congestion, noise or other objectionable influences.
   (c)    To protect and stabilize both residential and nonresidential
developments from traffic congestion.
   (d)    To carry out the following specific purposes:
      (1)   To provide a B-1 Downtown Business District that recognizes the
historic, compact and unique character of the downtown.
      (2)    To provide a B-2 Limited Business District that accommodates a
variety of retail and service establishments where only limited outdoor sales
are permitted.
      (3)    To provide a B-3 General Business District that accommodates a
wide range of commercial uses including automotive uses and outdoor activities
in a manner that does not intrude upon residential areas.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1137.02 USE REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Uses Permitted by Right. A use listed in Schedule
1137.03 shall be permitted by right as a principal use in a district when
denoted by the letter "P" provided that all requirements of other Village
Ordinances and this Planning and Zoning Code have been met.
   (b)   Conditional Uses. A use listed in Schedule
1137.03 shall be permitted as a conditional use in a district when denoted by
the letter "CU", provided the Planning and Zoning Commission first makes the
determination that the requirements of Chapter
1161 have been met according to the procedures set forth in Chapter
1111.
   (c)   Accessory Uses. A use listed in Schedule
1137.03 shall be permitted as an accessory use in a district when denoted by
the letter "A". Such use shall be permitted as a subordinate use when it is
clearly incidental to and located on the same lot as the principal building or
use. Accessory uses are further regulated in subsequent sections of this
Planning and Zoning Code.
   (d)   Use Not Listed in Schedule. Although a use may be indicated as a
permitted principal, conditional or accessory use in a particular business
district, it shall not be approved on a parcel unless it can be located thereon
in full compliance with all of the standards and other regulations of this
Planning and Code applicable to the conditional use and parcel in question. Any
use not specifically listed as either a permitted principal or conditional use
shall be a prohibited use in these zoning districts and shall only be permitted
upon amendment of this Planning and Zoning Code and/or the Village of Mingo
Junction Zoning Map as provided in Chapter
1117, or upon a finding by the Planning and Zoning Commission or Zoning
Inspector that a use is substantially sin:iilar to a principally permitted or
conditional use in the district according to the procedures set forth in
Section
1111.10. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)

1137.07 OUTDOOR DISPLAY.
   Outdoor display of merchandise for sale other than for automotive sales,
shall comply with the following:
   (a)    Outdoor display and sale of merchandise shall be limited to products
that are customarily associated with the operation of the principal business
located on the premises and conducted by employees of such principal business.
There shall be no outdoor display or sale of merchandise by any person
operating or conducting a business that is different or distinct from the
principal business conducted at that location.
   (b)   Location.
      (1)    Areas devoted to outdoor display shall comply with all building
setback requirements set forth in Schedule
1137.05 for the district in which they are located as set forth in this
Chapter.
      (2)    No outdoor display area shall be permitted to occupy or interfere
with traffic circulation, required parking areas, public sidewalks or
pedestrian access.
   (c)   Area. The area of the lot devoted to outdoor display shall not exceed
twenty-five percent (25%) of the ground floor area of the principal building.
   (d)   Signs. No signs shall be permitted in conjunction with outdoor display
areas except those otherwise in compliance with the sign regulations in Chapter
1165.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1137.08 SUPPLEMENTAL REGULATIONS FOR GASOLINE STATIONS AND AUTO SERVICE
STATIONS.
   In addition to the regulations contained in this Chapter, all gasoline
stations and auto service stations shall comply with the following standards.
   (a)    Fuel pumps and associated access aisles and canopies shall comply
with the parking setback requirements in Schedule
1137.06.
   (b)    Canopies shall have a maximum height of twenty (20) feet.
   (c)    Except while being serviced at a pump island, no vehicle shall be
parked between the pumps and the front property line.
   (d)    No junk or unlicensed motor vehicles shall be permitted to be parked
or stored on the property. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1137.09 ACCESSORY USE REGULATIONS.
   Accessory buildings and structures shall comply with the development
standards established for principal buildings and uses in Section
1137.05 except as otherwise set forth below:
   (a)    Walls and Fences. Fences and walls shall be constructed according to
the requirements set forth this subsection.
      (1)   Permit required. A fence or any extension thereof, in either height
or length, shall be deemed a structure and shall require a permit. A plot plan
showing lot lines, the location of the fence and any other structures on the
plot shall be presented before any permit is issued.
      (2)   Height.
         A.    Walls and fences in a side or rear yard shall not exceed a
height of six (6) feet measured from the natural grade, unless otherwise
required for screening.
         B.    Wall and fences in a front yard shall not exceed three (3) feet
in height.
      (3)   Location.
         A.    Walls and fences may extend into the required side, rear and
front yards as established in Section
1137.05 and shall be located entirely on the property of the owner of the
fence.
         B.    Fences, gates, doors and other obstructions shall not swing
across or over a sidewalk or public right-of-way.
         C.    No fence shall be constructed, without Village authorization,
within a utility right-of-way. Any fence constructed within a utility right-of-
way or inhibiting access to such right-of-way may be removed by the Village and
the cost of such removal may be charged against those parties having an
interest in the fence.
      (4)    Materials. Chain link fence shall be permitted. Light wire mesh
fencing such as "chicken wire", shall only be permitted in areas subject to
flooding.
      (5)    Design, Construction and Maintenance. All fences shall be
designed, constructed and finished so that the supporting members face the
property of the owner of the fence. All fences shall be maintained in good
condition, be structurally sound and attractively finished at all times.
   (b)    Off-Street parking shall comply with the regulations set forth in
Chapter
1167 and in Section
1137.06.
   (c)    Signs shall comply with the regulations set forth in Chapter 1165.
      (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1137.10 LANDSCAPING AND SCREENING REQUIREMENTS.
   Landscape buffers shall be provided to reduce the impact between one zoning
district and another and between contrasting uses in the same district, to
obscure the view of accessory uses and minimize potential noise and visual
clutter.
   (a)    Buffer Yard Required Adjacent to Residential District. Screening and
buffering shall be required along the entire length of a common boundary
whenever a lot in a business district abuts any residential district.
      (1)   Screening Materials. When the natural vegetation within the
required buffer yard does not form a solid, continuous, visual screen or does
not have a minimum height of six (6) feet along the entire length of the common
boundary, screening shall be installed in one of the following forms:
         A.    Dense vegetative planting.
         B.    A non-living opaque structure such as a solid masonry wall, or a
solid fence that is compatible with the principal structure.
         C.    A fence with openings accompanied by vegetative planting the
combination of which forms an effective visual screen as determined by the
Zoning Inspector.
      (2)   Location. The location of the wall, fence or vegetation shall be
placed within the buffer yard to maximize the screening effect as determined by
the Zoning Inspector.
      (3)   Height. Screening shall be a minimum of six (6) feet in height
measured from the natural grade, except for screening located along a common
side lot line in the area extending from the parking lot to the street where
the required screening shall not exceed a height of three (3) feet.
      (4)   Buffering Effect. The desired buffering effect shall be achieved
not later than twelve (12) months after the initial installation. The Zoning
Inspector may extend this twelve (12) month period where a hardship would be
created because of lack of expected growth or material shortages, but the
Zoning Inspector shall not extend such period beyond two (2) years from the
time the initial installation was to have been or has been completed.
   (b)    Parking Setback. The area within the parking setback shall be
landscaped with a minimum of grass groundcover and maintained in a suitable
manner.
   (c)   Screening of Accessory Uses. In all Business Districts, screening of
accessory uses shall be provided to obscure the view of such areas according to
the following:
      (l)    Waste Receptacles. All solid waste products, including empty
packing boxes, that result from any permitted principal, conditional or
accessory use shall either be disposed of, stored in buildings, or completely
enclosed in containers. Such container or dumpster shall be:
         A.    Located in a side or rear yard and shall comply with the minimum
parking setbacks established in Schedule
1137.06.
         B.    Screened from view. Screening material shall extend at least two
(2) feet above the storage container.
      (2)    Loading and Service Areas. Each loading area shall be adequately
screened so as not to be visible from the street right-of-way.
   (d)   Maintenance. All landscaping and buffering shall be maintained in good
and healthy condition at all times.
      (1)    All screening shall be free of advertising or other signs, except
for directional signs and other signs for the efficient flow of vehicles.
      (2)    The required landscaping shall be maintained in healthy condition
by the current owner and replaced when the Zoning Inspector determines that
such landscaping is no longer viable or no longer effectively achieves its
original purpose. Replacement material shall conform to the original intent of
the landscape plan.
      (3)    Vehicle parking shall not be permitted in landscaped areas.
         (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1137.11 DEVELOPMENT PLAN REVIEW.
   All uses in a Business District shall be permitted only after development
plans have been reviewed and approved by the Zoning Inspector according to the
procedures set forth in Chapter
1107.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
CHAPTER 1139
Industrial District Regulations
1139.01   Purpose.
1139.02   Use regulations.
1139.03   Schedule of permitted uses.
1139.04   Lot requirements.
1139.05   Building setback spacing and heights requirements.
1139.06   Off-street parking and loading regulations.
1139.07   Outdoor storage.
1139.08   Accessory use regulations.
1139.09   Performance standards.
1139.10   Landscaping and screening requirements.
1139.11   Development plan review.
1139.01 PURPOSE.
   The I-1 and I-2 Industrial Districts and their regulations are established
in order to achieve, among others, the following purposes:
   (a)    To provide convenient and sufficient zoning districts for industrial
activities and for the production, distribution, and exchange of goods and
services in order to serve and promote the economic development of the
community.
   (b)    To provide areas for industrial and wholesale activities which desire
both convenience of location and a reasonable amount of usable space sufficient
to meet the needs of parking, loading and unloading.
   (c)    To protect residential neighborhoods adjacent to industrial uses by
restricting the types of uses, particularly at the common boundaries, which
would create congestion, noise or other objectionable influences and by
preventing the encroachment of incompatible land uses, such as residences and
heavy industry.
   (d)    To carry out the following specific purposes:
      (1)   The I-1 Light Industrial Development District is intended to
provide areas for manufacturing, and warehousing which by their inherent
characteristics and the operations involved are not obnoxious to one another.
      (2)    The I-2 Heavy Industrial District is designed to retain and
provide areas for industrial uses which may produce dust, smoke, fumes, glare
and other objectionable influences and to provide locations for outdoor
activities and outdoor storage in association with a principal use and which
because of the nature and extent of the operations shall not be located in
close proximity to residential activities. (Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
1139.02 USE REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Uses Permitted by Right. A use listed in Schedule
1139.03 shall be permitted by light as a principal use in a district when
denoted by the letter "P" provided that all requirements of all other Village
ordinances and this Planning and Zoning Code have been met.
   (b)   Conditional Uses. A use listed in Schedule
1139.03 shall be permitted as a conditional use in a district when denoted by
the letter "CU", provided the Planning and Zoning Commission first makes the
determination that the requirements of Chapter
1161 have been met according to the procedures set forth in Chapter
1111.
   (c)   Accessory Uses. A use listed in Schedule
1139.03 shall be permitted as an accessory use in a district when denoted by
the letter "A". Such use shall be permitted as a subordinate building or use
when it is clearly incidental to and located on the same lot as the principal
building or use. Accessory uses are further regulated in subsequent sections of
this Chapter.
   (d)   Use Not Listed in Schedule. Although a use may be indicated as a
permitted principal, conditional or accessory use in a particular industrial
district, it shall not be approved on a parcel unless it can be located thereon
in full compliance with all of the standards and other regulations of this
Planning and Zoning Code applicable to the specific use and parcel in question.
Any use not specifically listed as either a permitted principal or conditional
use shall be a prohibited use in these zoning districts and shall only be
permitted upon amendment of this Planning and Zoning Code and/or the Village of
Mingo Junction Zoning Map as provided in Chapter
1117, or upon a finding by the Planning and Zoning Commission that a use is
substantially similar to a principally permitted or conditional use in the
district according to the procedures set forth in Section
1111.10.
(Ord. 2002-2. Passed 1-24-02.)
